name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the statements by the Council and the Commission on the first anniversary of the signature of the Istanbul Convention: state of play (2018/2753 (RSP)). Before that, I would like to conclude an agreement with you, because at At 10.00 we must finish this item on the agenda. It will be followed by a strategic, traditional debate with the participation of prime ministers - this time it is the prime minister of the Netherlands, so I will very much want to strictly respect the speaking time. I would also like, bearing in mind the advantage of the catch-the-eye formula, that I will not give my consent to blue-card speeches, but we will leave time for the catch-the-eye form. We now have 45 minutes - 5 minutes for introductions by the Commission, for the political groups and for the speeches of Members, so there would be 10 minutes for catch-the-eye, so please accept this format for today's debate on this agenda item . I understand there is acceptance. Therefore, I would like to ask Minister Monika Panayotova to speak on behalf of the Council.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for having this important debate on the agenda today. Indeed this is not the first time I had the opportunity to discuss with you this very important topic. I would like to use the opportunity to reiterate the points which I have made previously. Combating all forms of violence against women and young girls is a core element of the respect for fundamental rights. These crimes have no place in the Union, and the Council is clear on zero tolerance of violence against women.   The Istanbul Convention is a comprehensive framework on violence against women and domestic violence. It constitutes a concrete tool to eradicate all forms of violence against women, protect its victims and prosecute the perpetrators. Finally, it contributes to the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women and promotes equality between women and men. All 28 Member States have already signed this Convention, and 18 of them have already ratified it. The Council has, on several occasions, encouraged those Member States who have not done so yet to ratify the Istanbul Convention. On 11 May 2017, the Council adopted the decisions on the signing of the Convention on behalf of the European Union. Our Presidency is carrying on the work on the conclusion of this important instrument. This includes reaching agreement on internal rules in the form of a code of conduct for the implementation of the Convention. According to the EU-wide survey on violence against women conducted by the Fundamental Rights Agency in 2014, one—in—three women, which means 33%, has experienced physical and/or sexual violence since the age of 15. One—in—five women, which means 18%, has experienced stalking; every second woman has been confronted with one or more forms of sexual harassment. Violence against women cannot be seen as a marginal issue that touches only on some women’s lives. Last but not least, gender-based violence also has a significant impact on economies and societies as a whole, for example in terms of health, legal and social services. In 2014, the European Institute for Gender Equality has estimated that the cost of violence against women in the European Union could amount to billions, or to be more precise, EUR 109 billion per year.  As President Tajani strongly affirmed, ‘the struggle for the elimination of violence against women is a fight that each and every one of us must take part in. It is our duty to stand up for women by drawing awareness to this injustice.’ The Council has repeatedly expressed its commitment to preventing and eliminating all forms of gender-based violence. We all know that only our joint efforts and a message of unity will help to improve the situation of all women and girls in Europe.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, one year ago, the European Union signed the Istanbul Convention, and since then we have seen women’s marches and the ‘#Me Too’ campaign confirm once again that violence against women is a global issue that continues to affect women and girls in every part of the world. We know that this violence is part of an effort to keep women in their place as lesser citizens and this is unacceptable. The Convention is the first legally binding international instrument with enforceable provisions to prevent and combat violence against women. The Commission’s intention is to conclude EU accession as soon as possible. Since the signature, we have been working intensively with the Member States and the Council to reach an agreement on a Code of Conduct that sets out the practical arrangements for implementing the Convention. The Code should accompany the Council’s conclusion decision and describe the division of roles between the EU and the Member States in implementing the Convention. We have been discussing legal competence issues, as well as issues such as reporting and sharing information.  Some Member States, regretfully, are still reluctant to support EU accession to the Convention. Let me reiterate again that the EU will accede alongside the Member States and will not replace Member States. Substantial aspects of the Convention, such as those related to substantive criminal law, remain under Member States’ exclusive competence. However, the advantage is that, if the EU becomes a contracting party in its own name, alongside the Member States, certain obligations set out in the Convention will be legally binding for the EU’s institutions, bodies and agencies and will therefore protect their staff. For example, the Convention requires that staff are protected through the internal rules of the institutions to prohibit violence and harassment in the workplace and provide for procedures and services to support victims and to sanction offenders. The Commission is currently in the process of analysing the relevant obligations in the Convention, screening the existing internal rules, regulations and practices of all EU institutions, agencies and bodies, and determining whether there are any gaps in the current system. This is a task which will require the full engagement of all European institutions and bodies, and I warmly welcome the European Parliament’s cooperation in this regard. Unfortunately, achieving EU compliance with these international standards is not enough. Despite the fact that all EU Member States have signed the Convention and that 19 Member States have so far ratified it, we see strong opposition against the Convention in a few countries. A lot has been said about this Convention, some of which is frankly untrue. I would like to be very clear: this Convention is about protecting women against violence. Nothing more, nothing less. One—in—three women in Europe has experienced violence at least once in their life simply because she is a woman, and one—in—three women in Europe has experienced either physical and/or sexual violence. This is unacceptable.  The Istanbul Convention is the first binding and comprehensive international instrument in Europe that addresses violence against women. It is not about imposing new social standards. It is about banning violence. The misconceptions and misleading arguments voiced in the public debates about the Convention need to be confronted. The Commission is working on a communication strategy to rebut fears that the Convention would challenge conventional family or religious norms or introduce an obligation to allow same-sex marriage or a new refugee status for transgender or intersex persons. I would really like to know in which universe social conventions or religious norms would allow for violence against women. Which religion does that? (Applause) Gender equality is not a quick fix. We all know that. But unless we take concrete steps and move ahead together on this, we won’t achieve the behavioural and cultural shifts that allow change. I say this: I’m a son, I’m a husband, and I’m a father of two girls. I find it completely unacceptable that my mother, my wife or my kids – my girls – would not be better protected against violence. This is a duty shared by men and women. It’s not only up to women to make this happen, and this is a duty we should all take very seriously indeed.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the signature of the EU on the Istanbul Convention was a historic step to strengthen our tools to prevent violence, combat impunity and protect victims. Since then, Estonia, Cyprus, Germany and now Croatia have ratified the Convention, but 10 Member States are missing, including the Presidency. I am asking them: how many women have to be harassed, beaten up and killed? How many girls have to be married away, mutilated or trafficked for prostitution before they ratify and enforce?  All women and girls should feel free and safe in Europe, and no tradition or culture can justify men’s violence against women. The EU accession to the Convention strengthens accountability for Member States and external action of the EU in promoting women’s rights globally. It is about building a culture of respect for women and girls involving men and boys. The Convention not only provides for sanctions, training, support for victims, but also measures to combat stereotypes and sexism.  So together today, let’s call on the Presidency to put the Istanbul Convention on the agenda of the European Council for as long as it takes, and call on all countries – Bulgaria, Hungary, Slovakia and Ukraine – to engage with civil society, with religious leaders, across political parties based on facts. Thank you, Vice-President for what you said. Let’s also call on the Commission to open a dialogue on the misleading interpretation of gender in the Convention. The Convention is not against family – Mr President, I’m finishing – it is against violence that is against families. As co-rapporteur of the Istanbul Convention, I will remain committed to zero tolerance to any violence against women and girls.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, we are gathered today to celebrate an anniversary, that of the signature by the European Union of the Istanbul Convention one year ago to the day. It's a nice birthday, we congratulate ourselves, we look in the rearview mirror and we see how women are now better protected, because the Istanbul Convention is a legally binding treaty and the best tool possible to prevent violence , protect victims and prosecute those responsible. But this anniversary is by no means a celebration, because after a year of negotiations between the Commission and the Council, no significant progress has been made. You can feel that the negotiations are progressing and that some of the Member States are of good will, I sincerely thank them. But here we need unanimity. Poland or Hungary - to name a few - refuse any progress on the file. These governments have turned their backs on half of their populations, who risk becoming victims, denying our right to live free from violence. And what force of conviction of the Bulgarian presidency of the Council, which withdrew a bill for the ratification of its own country. No wonder the negotiations at European level are dragging on. The Council has already restricted the scope of the Union's accession to the Istanbul Convention. He chose to limit it to a few specific areas, while this Parliament called for the widest possible membership. The legal arguments to justify these regrettable restrictions were also rejected by our Legal Department. So stop there, stop opposing what can really help women in Europe, what can end the impunity of those responsible. The European Union must ratify this convention as soon as possible, as must the ten Member States which have not yet done so at national level.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - (NL) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to make a fiery plea today for the ratification of the Istanbul Convention. Any instrument that protects women a little more from violence is of great importance. I emphasize that these are the worst crimes against women, such as genital mutilation, forced abortion and forced sterilization, child marriage, rape and honor murder. People can and should have religious beliefs, but this should never stand in the way of protecting women. I cannot understand and accept that culture, customs, religion, tradition or so-called "honor" can be an excuse to oppress and abuse women. I ask all of you: What is honorable about violence against women? And how can fighting violence not be in line with traditional values? I deeply regret that it is proving so difficult in the EU to send a strong signal against violence together. Violence against women, and by extension against all genders, has no place in our European society. We love to beat ourselves up for our European values ​​and fundamental rights, but have a hard time condemning the most blatant form of discrimination. I think this is unworthy of the European Union.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, dear Commissioner. All around the world, in every country, women and girls still struggle to exercise their full human rights. Violence against women and girls is perhaps the most obvious manifestation of the deep imbalances empowering our societies and the vulnerabilities and limitations that follow them, especially for the most marginalised groups when vulnerabilities are at their peak and protections at their lowest point. This year marks the first anniversary of the signing by the European Union of the Istanbul Convention, and it is an opportunity for us to reflect on the steps that have been taken so far. But it is also a possibility for a wake-up call. Only robust action can ensure women a life free from violence. I welcome the steps that have been taken in the negotiations of the Code of Conduct, which lays down the rights and obligations of the EU and the Member States under the Convention. This gives me the opportunity to call on the next EU Council Presidency, Austria – my country – to conclude the Code of Conduct and to find a political agreement with the remaining problematic Member States who keep blocking the ratification by the European Union of the Istanbul Convention. For those Member States I have a crystal clear message: I urge you to stop spreading outrageous misinformation about the Convention and its content. Gender is not a threat; domestic violence is.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the 13th of June will go down in history. It will go down in history as the day when the European Union truly stood up against violence against women and for the protection of women against violence. And fighting against violence should actually not even be a debate here, because, despite our political differences, shouldn’t we all agree that all women in the European Union should be able to live a life free from violence? Still there is opposition to this Convention. There are politicians who are spreading lies in order to block the ratification of this very important Convention, and these politicians only have one pre-condition under which they actually care about violence against women, and that is when the perpetrator is a Muslim, when the perpetrator is a refugee, when the perpetrator is a stranger – when the perpetrator is somebody who they can politically instrumentalise. And I say to you today: stop these disgusting political campaigns. Start doing something for the protection of women against violence, start campaigning for the Istanbul Convention, because this is the real political tool that you should use in order to prevent violence from happening. Stand up for women in Europe: support the Istanbul Convention now!

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: for the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President! Gender-based violence kills. It reduces living space and threatens. Sexualized violence, harassment, violence in close relationships, threats in public places and spaces. Those who are exposed are women and girls but also those with norm-breaking gender identity or sexuality such as LGBTQ people. But I think it's even more important to make visible who is committing the violence. These are men. We have a kind of "toxic masculinity" that in the worst case generates violent men. The good news is that this does not have to be the case. It is a construction of masculinity that does not belong in this century, and that we can change. That's what feminism and gender are, that's what it's about. And in that sense, of course, I welcome many more feminist men who distance themselves from that kind of masculinity. We who are here today, we who follow the work of ratifying the Istanbul Convention, we know what an important tool it is. We know what a valuable political and legal instrument it is, and we will not give up, because this fight is not over until we are all protected from violence against women and girls. We will not give up, we also have human rights.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a year has already passed since the European Union signed the Istanbul Convention and we are here today to remember it.As in any self-respecting anniversary, we also do an initial assessment to see if we have done enough with respect to expectations.The answer is: no, we haven't done enough.Of course, we know, it is not with a signature that things can change.A signature does not stop the violence or discrimination that women suffer every day across Europe.So we do more, we press the governments of the Member States to do more, to legislate in the most effective way and to deploy all the necessary forces because the violence against women does not stop and we are frankly tired of waiting.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, a little over a year ago, the European Union signed the Istanbul Convention. You have succeeded in Parliament, with a great deal of demagoguery, in getting this text accepted by a large majority of our colleagues. Is. So now, a year later, it's time to do the math. You claim to save women and girls victims of violence and you highlighted, during the EYE event dedicated to European youth a few days ago, women defending the Islamic veil, a symbol, I say, of the threat that really hangs over European women today. You claim to defend equality between men and women by promoting what you call gender equality. Do you really think that imposing the ideology of gender, as you are doing, on all and especially on our children, will reduce violence against women? You finally claim to bring the light of European democracy to all the women and girls of Europe, and when the Bulgarian, Hungarian and Polish governments, among others, sovereignly refuse to adhere to your little red book of the kind, they are lynched in the public square. They are especially aware that this Istanbul convention will in no way protect European women from the real dangers which threaten them today.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen! I would like to start by recalling that the Polish government signed the convention in 2012 and ratified it in 2015. And while expressing my appreciation to Anna Maria Corrazza Bildt, who is leading this subject in parliament with great determination, I would also like to remind you that the convention was drafted in 2011 and in just a few years it was signed by all the countries of the Council of Europe except Russia and Azerbaijan. It has also been signed by all countries, including the European Union, and most of them have ratified the convention. Croatia has recently done so, which deserves great applause. The Istanbul Convention is recognized by the United Nations as the gold standard of anti-violence policy. It includes a chapter on prevention which says that promoting equality between women and men is the best way to prevent violence. The convention recognizes that nothing can justify violence: neither tradition, nor religion, nor culture. Some religious customs, such as circumcision of women, are considered to be violence and a punishable offense. This convention is a roadmap for national anti-violence policies. While expressing my appreciation for the fact that the European Union as a party to the Convention in 2017, I call on the European Commission and the Council to extend the scope of EU ratification and to prepare a draft anti-violence directive with binding force as EU law.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: - Mr President, one out of every three women in the European Union has been a victim of some kind of violence, and, therefore, holding this debate today, when the European Union signed the Istanbul Convention a year ago, I believe that A fundamental signal to convey the need to continue committing ourselves and continue working in the fight against violence against women. I want to thank Mr Timmermans for his very committed speech on this matter, because it is true that we need many united voices in this regard. I also acknowledge that I was surprised to hear the voice of the Presidency on this issue, when Bulgaria is among the countries that have not yet accepted the need to ratify the Istanbul Convention. It is a moral obligation. It is an obligation of all the Member States of the European Union to fight against violence against women, because we need legislative measures that commit us, because we need to implement each and every one of the actions at the different levels to end the greatest scourge social that the world has at the moment. Women are being murdered for the mere fact of being women, and that does not deserve anyone's impassivity. Therefore, let us assume our obligations, assume our commitments and launch a fight that must be started from the unity of all democrats and from the unity of those who consider that a more equal Europe is necessary.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Mr President, of course, no one wants to approve of violence against women, no one wants it, nor is it right. But at the same time, it must be seen that many countries have problems with this document, and I think it is important that this must be respected. Research shows that the causes of violence against women are not what you keep saying in this document: that men attack women because they are women. That is not true after all. These are alcohol, gambling, partnership problems, and many countries see an ideological problem in this document. Specifically, point C states that you want to redefine the understanding of the role of men and women in society. But this is not the case with international documents. Also, the elimination of this violence is not done through restrictions and orders, but through education and respect in families, in schools, towards the woman as such, to the ability she has - to bring life. The convention was ratified in Turkey, but when there was a case of a man who raped a woman, it was enough to introduce a law that if he married her, he would be released from prison. Please, the Istanbul Convention needs to create a new one. A new document that will suit the state.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I would like this anniversary of the signing of the Istanbul Convention by the European Union to be a cause for celebration, but I am afraid that it is a reason for denunciation. In March, Mrs Panayotova, the Bulgarian Government reversed its decision to present the Istanbul Convention for ratification in the midst of the European Presidency. Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico said in February that he refused to ratify it. According to Viktor Orban, the way to defend women is to prevent immigration into Hungary. Ten Member States have yet to ratify the Convention and some, such as Poland, have been threatening to reverse that ratification for years. Even the countries that have ratified it, like mine, Spain, have not yet properly incorporated the provisions into their national legislation, so that it becomes effective. The Istanbul Convention is the most complete and integrated legal tool that we have equipped ourselves to comprehensively combat gender-based violence against girls, against women and also domestic violence, but it has been in force for four years now. I trust that the Austrian Presidency will complete the compromise that the Council made a year ago.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: - Mr President, one year after the signing of the Istanbul Convention by the European Union, we have not yet achieved the obvious: the provisions of the Convention apply in all Member States. This is because the Commission is turning a blind eye. While it seeks to threaten and even impose fines on Member States when they infringe Community law, as is the case in fiscal, trade, environmental matters, it does not do the same when it comes to human rights, which are its basis and core society. Worst of all, it allows false news about the text of the Convention to be recycled, demonizing it and turning the world against it. I ask the Commission: firstly, what steps does it intend to take to ensure that the Convention it has signed enters into force? Second, how will it refute the false news surrounding the Convention?

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear members of the other over 60 artificial sexes! We are talking about “One Year Istanbul Convention”. All EU member states have effective national laws and procedures in place to combat violence against women and men - otherwise they would not have become members of the EU or the Council of Europe. That is why the Istanbul Convention is completely superfluous. It is a politically correct pretext for deepening the absurd gender ideology and nothing else. The Istanbul Convention rightly meets with rejection and distrust. That is why the Council of Europe is even considering printing lots of colorful brochures with taxpayers money to gloss over the gender nonsense. The Istanbul Convention is the wrong instrument in the hands of the wrong people. For the record: We stand very clearly against all gender-based violence against both women and men. But that is the task of national criminal law, not this superfluous gender convention. Commissioner Timmermans, please do not complain about violence against women in the EU! You are one of the key actors whose policies even massively promote violence against women. With your absurd migration policy, you are attracting multitudes of misogynistic and often excessive violence against women who are actively preparing young men from foreign cultures to join the EU. More hypocrisy has seldom been found, Commissioner. That is not to be excused with naivety!

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: - Mister President! On the one hand, it is regrettable that some Member States have not yet ratified the Istanbul Convention, but on the other hand, it has been shown time and again that the ratification of the treaty does not go hand in hand with the protection of women. An example of this, Commissioner Timmermans, is Turkey, where almost every second woman suffers from domestic violence. In 2017, as many as 409 women were murdered in Turkey under these circumstances. They are all silent witnesses of an archaic Islam, as the Turkish President Erdoğan obviously would like to have. It is therefore not surprising that the Turkish state religious authority suggested at the beginning of this year that children should be allowed to marry as soon as they reach puberty. For us, ladies and gentlemen, a wake-up call to prevent Islamist parallel societies with their archaic image of women in our midst. Commissioner Timmermans, you obviously need tutoring in religious studies if you are here today to ask which religion obviously allows violence against women. Condemning violence against women is right and important. But combating them preventively, Commissioner, is far more important in my opinion.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President. I just want to say very clearly that if you ever have listened to a victim of domestic violence recalling their experience, you would have no doubt of the importance of this issue. And the tragedy is that in our so-called developed world, domestic violence is everywhere. And this is a frightening reality for women and indeed their children.  My country, Ireland, has signed the Istanbul Convention but has not ratified it yet; that needs to be done. I support the call made here in this debate on this very sensitive issue. It is a shocking sight and a shocking reality. I listened very recently to a woman describe the circumstances of her experience and how difficult it was for her to extract herself from that. This House can only support this initiative absolutely.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the signing by the European Union of the Istanbul Convention was a fundamental step in offering legal instruments to prevent violence, prosecute perpetrators and provide support to victims. A year after the Union's accession, however, it is important to note that not all States have effectively applied the Convention and that, even where the provisions have been implemented, violence is still a sad and dramatic reality for many women. Evidently, legislation alone, however effective and complete, is not enough. It is not enough to resolve the many problems linked to gender-based violence in a clear and definitive way. An even more effective change of pace is needed, through the provision of preventive tools of an educational nature, to spread a new culture focused on respect for women, and the adoption at European level of a new integrated policy against any form of violence against women. of women, who urge so-called zero tolerance in all countries, to finally create a truly equal society.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, we have repeatedly discussed the Istanbul Convention and of course it is important that it has been signed. Cases of violence against women are on the agenda and steps must be taken to stop violence against women. Of course, there is a social dimension to everything that happens, there are various causes, alcohol, gambling, but the phenomena of domestic violence are intensifying daily due to the economic crisis. The key, then, is to implement the Istanbul Convention. But in order to be implemented, it must be ratified by the Member States. We see that even Bulgaria, which currently holds the Presidency of the European Union, has not ratified it. It is therefore necessary to ratify the Convention, to implement and take harsh measures against those who use violence against women.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr Chairman, I want to draw a parallel.It may seem extreme to you, but I am deeply convinced that it is true.Those who do not want to ratify the Istanbul Convention, they want to take us back to the Middle Ages.They still think the earth is a flat plate, they still think many women might need to be at the stake.I want to talk about it like that because what we are talking about here today is really amazing: that in this European Union we still have countries, we have politicians in power, who do not want to ratify the Istanbul Convention.Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Macedonia and Serbia have ratified the Istanbul Convention, and the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary and some other countries, and some wishing to withdraw their ratification, are in a way witches of the European Union.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: - Mr President, today marks one year since the signing of the Istanbul Convention. Unfortunately, the phenomenon of violence against women continues to intensify and manifest itself in many forms, including psychological, physical and sexual harassment, forced abortion, human trafficking and honor crimes. At the same time, neoliberal austerity policies are exacerbating other forms of oppression, such as oppression at work, cuts in wages and benefits, the abolition of all forms of state welfare, the dismissal of pregnant women and asylum, where thousands of women are forced to survive in adverse conditions. to protect their children. It is therefore necessary to take drastic measures and take decisive action, both at Union level and by each Member State. There are no reservations, no savings and no obstacles to the ratification and implementation of the Convention. As the GUE Group we will continue to fight to the end for a society free of violence, exploitation, inequality.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: - Mr. President, in Spain, thanks to the feminist movement, we not only have the government with the most women in the world and in the history of Europe, but the fight against gender violence is a social and political priority. That is why I am pleased that the European Union signed the Istanbul Convention a year ago. But, at the same time, I regret that the ratification process remains stalled. Faced with the macho and homophobic attacks against the Convention, I ask the Council and the Commission: What are you doing to unblock this situation? How do you plan to counter disinformation campaigns? Is there an initiative on the table? We demand that the ratification process be concluded successfully, but I also want to remind you of something else. As this Parliament has stated, the Convention is a necessary step, but not a sufficient one. To end violence against women we need a directive against gender violence. Do not lose sight of this, please.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, it is of great significance that one year ago the Council approved the signature of the Istanbul Convention. But can we really celebrate today in terms of facts and figures? Violence against women is an extremely serious crime and a serious breach of human rights. Still, it is a persistent issue in the Member States. The numbers are alarming, as every third woman has been a victim of physical or sexual violence in the EU. In Romania there have been more than 20 000 reported cases in 2017, but we know that the majority of incidents do not even come to the attention of the police. There is still a long way to go until real practices follow ratification acts and the different forms of gender-based violence diminish in our societies. The Istanbul Convention is not only about numbers but also about changing current attitudes in our households as well as shaping the future behaviour of the next generation. Member States can no longer tolerate abusive behaviour towards women and need to join forces to implement action to combat such violence.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: - Let's face it, thousands of women and girls in the European Union are experiencing violence, both economic and psychological, and sexual and physical violence.Every third, statistics say.And if we look deeper, perhaps thousands of women are even afraid to report that violence they have experienced.So the reality is even worse, here in the European Union.And that is why we must take all measures immediately to change the situation so that women and girls are not harmed.I call on the Bulgarian Presidency to lead by example and to ratify the Istanbul Convention without delay.I appeal to you, Mr Timmermans, and to the Commission to take the possibility of presenting a directive on the basis of violence very seriously, because otherwise we will not change the situation.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman! Ladies and gentlemen, The Istanbul Convention is not an anti-violence convention. This is the convention on the application of gender ideology. She ignores the key causes of domestic violence, violence against women, such as, for example, the pansexuality of our culture (as we have repeatedly discussed, for example, in the committee on concrete examples of what is happening on the Internet) or the family crisis - because we have data that the vast majority of towards children takes place where the child does not live with both of its natural parents. It is characteristic that when we consider, for example, forced marriages, they occur much more often in countries that have ratified the Istanbul Convention than in countries that have not ratified it. President Timmermans completely ignores the competences of the European Commission contained in Art. 17. He talks about coordination, while we only hear attacks on a third of the European Union countries which do not want to conform to this ideology.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr President, on this anniversary I want to launch a reflection: no Member State of the European Union can refuse to ratify the Istanbul Convention, at least if it believes in the values ​​that unite us; at least if it applies in its territory the principles of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. It is time to ask whether a State that does not sign this Convention can belong to the Union. And, of course, it is time to propose that no State that aspires to join the Union can do so without having previously signed this Convention. The most dramatic expression of inequality is gender violence, and the Istanbul Convention is the first effective international instrument to effectively combat sexist aggressions, which cause more victims, deaths and injuries per year than terrorism. If we had observed a minute of silence in this plenary session for each victim of sexist violence registered in the last decade, we would have had to be silent for five full days, a thunderous silence that should shame all those who, based on lies, seek excuses so as not to face the problem of stereotypes and domination on which sexist attacks are based.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, the evidence and extent of violence against women will probably never have had so much media coverage and visibility. There are also a number of strategic instruments for combating violence, of which the Istanbul Convention will perhaps be the most far-reaching. Despite this, the trend of worsening violence against women does not seem to show signs of being reversed. Not by chance: the policies of austerity, economic and social divestment, attack on rights - promoted with the benefit of the European Union - and the consequent increase in inequality, poverty, labor exploitation, other expressions of human violence, were followed higher levels of violence against women. It will perhaps be the greatest evidence that it is impossible to dissociate violence from the socio-economic model and the political options that define it, and that diplomas, recommendations, laws are not enough to change reality. Other policies are required. The scythe cut, as some now claim in Portugal, cannot ignore other ignoble forms of violence, such as prostitution, seeking to legitimize it on the pretext of false freedom of choice or conceptualizations of work, which we reject.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: - Mr President, how important is this tool against violence against women, against patriarchal and sexist violence. Welcome to the first international legal instrument that covers all forms of violence against all women of all ages in times of war and peace. About nine million women in Europe were raped before they turned fifteen. It is a shocking number. Equally alarming is the fact that few countries in Europe take this crime seriously. We women want to return home without looking back, we want to be respected at home, at work, in life, we want our daughters to live without fear and for economic means to exist, because economic violence also exists. Therefore, zero tolerance for violence, zero tolerance for Member States that have not ratified the Istanbul Convention and zero tolerance for male and female deputies in this chamber, which, unfortunately, are many.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, from the statement of the Commissioner, but also of many of you, it follows that if we do not adopt the Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence, the Istanbul Convention, then we do not have the tool, we do not have a legal basis to combat violence against women. women. But I want to strongly defend myself against this falsehood. Because we have here the European Convention on Human Rights, which clearly fights against torture, inhuman treatment, protects the dignity of human life and respect for family and private life. Citizens ask me, "What happens if we do not accept the Istanbul Convention?" And I tell them: "The Istanbul Convention does not bring anything new in the Czech Republic. "The Czech Republic has had a law against domestic violence since 2006. Ladies and gentlemen, I understand that this may be important in some countries, and I respect your opinion, but please also respect subsidiarity and the decisions of other Member States.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think that - at least those who have stayed here, not the colleagues who have left - we agree that the signing of the Istanbul Convention was a first step. Ratification in other states by some Member States was the second step. But it is very important if we take into account what is written in this Istanbul Convention. We need to do prevention and I'm surprised that a colleague here says it depends on the country. Violence does not depend on nationality, it does not depend on anything. Violence is violence and we must fight it with all measures: prevention - through education, punishment - must be a harsh punishment for those who dare to rape women, young people, children, for cases of forced marriage. We have many hideous forms of violence and I strongly believe that we must be united in this endeavor and I am glad that yesterday, before the anniversary of the signing of the Convention, we had a report on our own initiative on education. I believe that we must correlate education and include in education and the fight against violence.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, allow me to reflect very briefly on the nature of violence against women. Violence against women, sexual violence against women, is about power, it’s not about sex. Violence against women is an instrument of submission of women, and those who belittle violence against women believe in a society where women are under submission.  What I find mind-boggling, of the extreme right, is that they would attack the Istanbul Convention and, at the same time, say that we should be doing more in attacking violence against women in the Islamic community. If you are serious about that, then the Istanbul Convention will give you additional instruments to do that.  I believe that if you oppose the Istanbul Convention with such force, it is based on an ideology that says that submission of women is part of our traditional values, and I refute that vision of our society. The Istanbul Convention, at the end of the day, is about equality between men and women. It is about making it clear that using violence, simply because you are stronger and because you can, to create the submission of women is unacceptable in a European society based on our common values, which demand equality of men and women.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, I have to justify that I am here today in the capacity of the Presidency of the Council representing all EU Member States, therefore I am not in a position to enter into details about the current situation in Bulgaria. Nevertheless, I would like to underline that it is beyond any doubt that Bulgarian society is firmly opposed to any form of violence against women, as they had the opportunity to underline during the plenary debate on the stalking crimes on 2nd May. The fact that the Convention law was included as a priority in the programme of our Presidency is a clear demonstration that the Bulgarian Government is convinced of its importance. The process of ratification of the Convention by the Member States requires respect of the procedures according to the specific national public debates and constitutional arrangements. We are currently still waiting for clarifications from the Constitutional Court concerning certain aspects of the Convention in relation to the Bulgarian Constitution, and I am convinced that this will contribute to a better-informed public debate on the topic. We will assess the situation in the light of the Court’s ruling once it is available. As the Presidency, I would like to underline that we are fulfilling our duties and investing our utmost efforts to achieve progress, and we will continue to work in closer cooperation with our Austrian colleagues to finalise the discussions on the code of conduct towards conclusion by the European Union. I would like to conclude by stressing that we share the view that violence against women and young girls and the protection of its victims is an issue of common concern that touches upon the core values of the European Union. It needs to be addressed with a high level of commitment, both by the European Institutions and bodies and also by our Member States.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - One in three women has suffered some kind of physical and / or sexual assault in the EU. A year ago the EU signed the Istanbul Convention. Although all the Member States have signed it, we cannot allow that there are still eleven Member States that have not ratified it. The Istanbul Convention is the most far-reaching international treaty to address violence against women as a serious violation of human rights. It is the first instrument that makes the prevention and fight against gender violence legally binding and establishes a zero tolerance towards violence against women. It is surprising to hear the voice of the Presidency on this issue, when Bulgaria is among the countries that have not yet accepted the need to ratify the Istanbul Convention. It is an obligation of all Member States to fight against gender violence, because we need legislative measures that commit us, we must launch all actions at different levels to end the greatest social scourge that the world is currently facing. Women are being murdered for the mere fact of being women, and that does not deserve anyone's impassivity.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. – 13 June marks one year from the signing of the Istanbul Convention by the EU. It is sad for me to say that my own country, Ireland, has yet to ratify this Convention. In Ireland today, some 15% of women have experienced abusive behaviour from a partner at some point, according to national statistics, while two out of five people know someone who has experienced domestic violence. Today, Parliament is sending a very strong political message on its commitment to end violence against women and girls, and I urge the Minister to sign the Istanbul Convention, and ensure its immediate ratification and implementation once this decision is made.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - A year after the signing of the Istanbul Convention, we can safely say that it is a political act that is absolutely unnecessary. I support the fight against violence against women, but I am firmly against using this pretext to promote gay marriage, to introduce the idea of ​​'gender' and, above all, to see gender as a social role. Bulgaria is one of the countries that has not ratified the Istanbul Convention and I think this is the right decision. This unnecessary document does not help to combat domestic violence, on the contrary, it shifts the focus and hinders the imposition of an effective policy to combat domestic violence and support for families.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: in writing. - Unfortunately, there are various misconceptions and misunderstandings about this Convention. Therefore, we make it clear that the Convention does not oppose the roles of the sexes nor does it fight against the family and its values. The Convention combats violence, and in particular violence against women due to racial inequality. In addition, the Convention combats the unseen, usually but brutal domestic violence, "silent" oppression and psychological violence, where victims have no choice but to flee because of their weakness to the powerful perpetrator. In Cyprus, important steps have been taken for the legislative framework and there is an increased sensitivity to the issue in order to prevent and combat violence against women and domestic violence. However, we are still struggling to identify victims in a timely manner, especially children, the elderly and the disabled. To anyone who attempts to cover up domestic violence against women in a religious guise or in so-called traditional behavior, I conclude: any social behavior or religion that conceals or favors such cruelty has no place in the modern civilized world. So we support the Convention, because we support human beings and we hate violence of any kind.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - It is indisputable that the EU, just like every member state, strongly condemns any type of violence and applies a zero tolerance rate to it. Each Member State has legislation and related mechanisms to combat violence against women and domestic violence. It is the Member State that adopts measures and mechanisms that prevent violence, it is the one that reacts promptly in cases of violence because when violence occurs, there is no time to wait, no time for European control mechanisms. Many Member States already have anti-violence systems in place. Among them is Croatia, which already has all the mechanisms provided for in the Istanbul Convention for the Suppression of Violence built into its legislation. The key to solving the problem of violence of any kind is in prevention. Croatia ratified the Istanbul Convention on April 13, 2018, but the citizens of the Republic of Croatia recently collected 377,635 signatures for a referendum on the deratization of the Convention. These are not signatures for violence, these are signatures against an ideology that seeks to impose itself under the guise of fighting violence. Considering that ten Member States have not ratified the Convention, we must ask ourselves why and show understanding, not impose on our citizens what they do not want and determine for Member States how to act in areas where they have exclusive competence.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: written.- A year ago, the EU signed the Istanbul Agreement to Prevent and Combat Violence against Women and Domestic Violence.This was an important step.Work must continue to implement the agreement.Member States that have not yet ratified the agreement should do so as soon as possible.Efforts must be made to implement the agreement in the Member States in cooperation with the various branches of government.Among other things, victim support services and shelters need to be increased so that there are enough services for everyone who needs them.The protection of victims must be strengthened.This starts with the victims feeling safe to report the violence they are experiencing.This is influenced by the high-quality training and skills of professional staff in dealing with victims of violence.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: written. - Today we celebrate the first anniversary of the signing of the Council of Europe Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence. Ten Member States, including Bulgaria, which is currently holding the Council Presidency, have not yet ratified the convention. It is a moral duty to go beyond declarations of will for the protection of women. Even with all the progress that we have made in recent decades, there are dangerous tendencies towards a misogynist backlash, and not just in Poland and Hungary. Too many women still face the greatest threat to their own home. In Austria, every fifth woman has experienced physical or sexual violence once in their life, and in the EU even every third woman. With the Istanbul Convention we took a first step towards greater protection for women, but now we have to go further and fight for the legal protection of women against violence to finally have a binding effect in the EU. I expect the Austrian Presidency to take decisive action.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - Today is a year since the Istanbul Convention, a breakthrough in international action against violence against women, was signed by MEPs, and nine months after the European Parliament welcomed the Convention by a large majority and urged the EU and its Member States to for ratification. Since then, this Parliament has been the only one of the EU institutions that has reminded it: it is the obvious and one of the most important political and human duties of all state powers and governments to protect the weak, the vulnerable and to guarantee their security. Now, looking back at the ineffectiveness of the first year, the deteriorating statistics, we are forced to repeat our warning. It is unacceptable that the blocking behavior of some EU Member State governments that stubbornly refuse ratification or try to reduce the scope of the Convention is tolerated and even served by the Commission and the Council by legitimizing the obvious obstruction through endless institutional legal consultations. Common sense seems incomprehensible to the governmental, political interest behind the opposition to the Convention, but in the case of my own country, the Orbán government, this also reflects the worldview of the ruling party leaders, which has raised the contempt for women and social oppression as a political program. Even with the dangers of such an attitude and policy that still exists in the EU, it is important for the EP to reassure the Member States and the European institutions that there is no room for tolerance in the case of violence against women!

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- The trend of worsening violence against women does not seem to show signs of being reversed.It is not by chance that the policies of austerity, of economic and social divestment, of attacking rights, promoted with the benefit of the EU, and the consequent increase in inequality, poverty, labor exploitation, other expressions of human violence, were accompanied byhigher levels of violence against women.It will perhaps be the greatest evidence that it is impossible to dissociate violence from the socio-economic model and the political options that define it.And that diplomas, recommendations, laws are not enough to change reality.Other policies are required!The scythe cut cannot, as some claim in Portugal, ignore other ignoble forms of violence, such as prostitution, seeking to legitimize it under the pretext of false freedom of choice or conceptualizations of work that we reject.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: in writing. - The Istanbul Convention, which has not yet been ratified by all Member States, takes a comprehensive and targeted approach to tackling gender-based violence. EU accession to the Convention secures the link between national and European law and strengthens the Union's role in international fora. However, Member States are not exempt from the obligation to transpose the Convention into national law. Despite the progress that has been made, there is a long way to go to eliminate gender discrimination. The facts are clear: 1/3 of all women in Europe have been physically or sexually abused at least once in their adult lives, 20% have been harassed online, one in twenty women have been raped and more than 1/10 has been sexually abused using physical violence. The main factors that favor the occurrence of cases of violence against women are the fear of social derailment and the lack of education. Dealing effectively with all forms of gender-based violence requires coordinated prevention, information and awareness-raising activities, as well as encouraging victims to report any acts of violence, away from fear, shame, social stereotypes and financial or emotional dependence on perpetrators.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the discussion with Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte on the future of Europe (2018/2728 (RSP)).It is my pleasure to greet the Prime Minister of the Kingdom of Holland, Mr. Rutte.Thank you for accepting our invitation to a debate with MEPs on the future of Europe.We are interested in knowing the proposals of the government of the Kingdom of Holland.We are interested in involving all the Prime Ministers of our Union in Parliament, which is the heart of European democracy, in order to have a serene, frank and constructive discussion on the future of Europe.So I am very pleased that the Dutch Prime Minister has accepted our invitation and I immediately give him the floor.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Prime Minister of the Netherlands. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you, President Tajani, for your kind introduction, and thank you, the Members of the European Parliament, for giving me this opportunity to contribute to this series of debates with members of the European Council on the future of Europe. It is a pleasure and a privilege to be here. Winston Churchill once said: ‘Politics is the ability to foretell what is going to happen tomorrow, next week, next month and next year. And to have the ability afterwards to explain why it didn’t happen.’ Churchill was right, we can’t predict the future. Unexpected events will always occur. But as politicians, it’s our job to lead and to chart a course. It’s our job to set goals and make choices that help achieve those goals. And looking at Europe and the world today, it’s clear: the European Union needs to make choices. Choices about its course and its role in the years to come. I must say, my personal views on the importance of the EU have evolved over the years. Yes, there is a transactional, ‘bread and butter’ element. Member States all benefit from the Single Market, the monetary union and the free movement of people. But it’s just as important that the EU ensures security, stability and the rule of law. The mere fact that we work together, that we are embedded in this Union, makes us stronger, safer and more effective. More and more, I’ve come to view the EU in this light. It’s something we in the Netherlands felt in the aftermath of the downing of flight MH17 in 2014, and yet again after the decision to hold Russia accountable for its part in it. The EU united behind us, jointly calling for Russia to accept responsibility and cooperate with efforts to establish the truth and achieve justice and accountability. We are grateful for the support and unity shown by this Union.  Russia has continued in its denial; its baseless criticism of the investigation and its obstruction of the truth are a stark reminder of how much we depend on all parties uniting to achieve justice for the victims and their loved ones, and of the importance of upholding an international, rules-based system aimed at fostering peace and justice.  So today, I stand before you with a real sense of urgency. Because recent developments make it very clear that we cannot take our way of life, our way of doing business, or our way of conducting international relations for granted. The multilateral order is being challenged in a way that we haven’t seen in decades, and the geopolitical balance of power is shifting. This global dimension of Europe’s future is the first thing I’d like to highlight today. Because if we want to be able to act, if we want to determine our own future, Europe must stand united. Now, more than ever. We must deal with the fact that Russia has chosen to distance itself from its neighbours in the West. We must deal with the ongoing conflict in Syria, and the arc of instability around Europe. With countries like China and India, which are stepping up their presence on the world stage, projecting greater self-confidence and a clear agenda. And with all the challenges and opportunities this brings for the EU, as the world’s biggest trading bloc and as a leading force for peace, stability and development. Even the relationship with our most important ally is no longer self-evident. The USA has unilaterally pulled out of the Paris Climate Agreement and the Iran nuclear deal. It has imposed import duties on steel and aluminium, triggering a debate we thought was obsolete. But of course, we remain friends and allies. I personally have always been a strong believer in the transatlantic bond. We need to keep working as closely as possible with the USA. But we must also deal with the fact that the rules-based multilateral system is under severe pressure. Since 1945, that system has greatly benefited Europe as a whole and the world around us. Indeed, the EU is the most successful example in world history of how multilateralism and the willingness to compromise can bring about unprecedented security, stability and prosperity. The EU is the ultimate example of the power of international cooperation and free trade. We know from experience that progress requires give and take. We know the value of seeking common ground, shared interests and sensible compromise.  So let us broadcast a strong message to the world: that Europe’s belief in the power of multilateral cooperation and free trade is as firm as ever, and that the EU Member States stand united in this, however much pressure we face. I like to compare it to the wagon trains in those John Wayne westerns that I watched as a boy. The settlers made a conscious decision to jointly undertake the difficult journey westwards. Before setting off, they agreed to stick to certain rules. Rules on conduct, speed of progress and care of the sick. And when evening fell, or danger threatened, the settlers circled their wagons. Their unity gave them strength, stability and security. It’s the same with the EU. Unity is the bedrock of our strength. Unity defines our ability to act.  Sadly, Brexit will leave a big hole in our circle. The only positive effect is that it has made the other 27 Member States even more aware of the importance of unity and working together. As a founding member, the Netherlands is committed to ensuring that our circle stays strong; that the EU remains successful and effective, that it continues to improve the lives of hundreds of millions of people. For the Netherlands, EU membership is self-evident. Because the Single Market has brought greater prosperity for more people than the founders of the EU could ever have imagined. Thanks to our shared values, most Europeans and more Europeans than ever before, enjoy legal certainty and protection. But I must be frank. I firmly believe that a truly strong and unified Europe must embody that famous quote by Goethe: ‘In der Beschränkung zeigt sich der Meister.’ ‘Mastery is revealed in constraint.’ Or, to put it another way, ‘less is more.’ More and more Europe isn’t the answer to the many problems that people face in their daily lives. For some, ‘ever closer union’ is still a goal in itself. Not for me. ‘Unity’ and ‘ever closer union’ are not the same. You don’t achieve unity by simply doing more in more areas. You achieve it by doing things really well in a few important areas.  So I believe we should be working towards a more perfect Union, which safeguards our way of life and delivers practical results. The EU needs to under-promise and over-deliver. Because focusing on our core tasks will promote the Union’s effectiveness, strength and identity. And it will boost unity. I believe that the future of Europe should essentially be about the original promise of Europe: the promise of sovereign Member States working together to help each other achieve greater prosperity, security and stability. But we can only deliver on this promise if a deal is a deal, and if the difficult compromises we have to make apply to everyone, and in full. Europe isn’t a menu you can pick and choose from. That is – and always has been – the basic promise and the basic premise of our unity. So let me be very clear: the debate about the future of the European Union should not be about more or less Europe. It should be about where the EU can add value. Where can cooperation achieve more than the Member States can achieve in isolation? Where does it make sense for sovereign Member States to make a positive and conscious choice to work together?  Originally, it was the Single Market and international trade policy. Then came EMU and the euro. Then, more recently, we added the common migration policy, joint control of our external borders and our collective security. Of course, there’s climate policy – by definition a cross-border issue. These are the areas where the EU needs to focus, because here Europe can achieve more than the sum of its parts. The challenge is to ensure that we do confine ourselves to these areas. And that we actually deliver on them. A Europe that adds value, sticks to its core tasks and achieves visible results can count on public support. That is why, once again, we need to under-promise and over-deliver. So for me, the debate on the EU’s future starts with the questions: Is the EU still doing the right things? What new priorities are emerging? Where does the EU need to do things better, or differently? When it comes to new priorities, climate policy and climate policy is a case in point. The current EU target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 40 % by 2030 predates the Paris Climate Agreement. But it isn’t enough. Not if we’re to play our part in keeping global warming below two degrees. Let alone aim at one-and-a-half degrees, as we agreed in Paris.  So for a Paris-compatible EU target. we need to raise the bar. I am proposing a 55 % reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030. (Applause)  Not only to meet our obligations, but also because a competitive and forward-looking Europe is, by definition, a sustainable Europe. Can it be done? Absolutely! As long as we, the Member States, Commission and European Parliament, all make it our goal.  That’s what I’m asking you today. Together with countries like France, the Netherlands wants to lead the way on this new climate ambition, and to work with you to achieve it. Exactly as we’ve done before. I still have a very clear memory, dating from the Dutch Presidency in 2016, of how we tackled the refugee crisis in record time through a big, concerted effort. As co-legislator on border control measures, you played a major role. Let us show once again, in this other, more insidious crisis, that Europe can take responsibility, and that together we can achieve a great deal. And this brings me to what we need to do better. It’s an important question, because the EU has a tendency to make new agreements before existing agreements have been fully implemented. We all know the ultimate example: the Single Market. There is so much more we can achieve in the field of services and the Digital Single Market. According to this Parliament’s estimate of the cost of non-Europe, we’re missing out on over a trillion euros a year. So, with respect to the EU’s original promise and its future: this is what it’s all about. Here, too, I have something to ask of you, especially the representatives of the larger Member States that are at this moment in no hurry to open up the market for services. I hope you won’t hold it against me, as Prime Minister of a country with a smaller domestic market and a long history of international trade, for mentioning the elephant in the room. We need to team up to unleash the full potential of the Single Market. Because we can’t pass up an extra trillion euros a year. (Applause) Another area where we could do better is the eurozone. We’ve come a long way, and the EU has shown that it can take action when it has to. But we are not sufficiently prepared for another crisis. The basic promise of the euro was that it would bring us all greater prosperity – not a redistribution of prosperity. That together we would achieve greater affluence. The pleas now being made to establish a transfer union fly in the face of this promise. Yes, I know that a currency union needs stabilisation mechanisms at times of crisis. But if the 19 eurozone countries were to put their own budgets and national debts in order, this would probably be stabilisation enough. That, too, is simply an existing agreement under the Stability and Growth Pact. A deal is a deal.  Of course, if – after putting its house in order – a country suffers a financial crisis and there’s genuinely no alternative, we should help each other, as good neighbours. We created the ESM, our collective safety net, precisely for that purpose. But we need to do things in that order. Let’s not forget, we already have hundreds of billions of euros available in the EU budget to support structural reforms at national level. I strongly believe that we should use these resources, these existing resources, to fulfil the original promise of the euro, a higher level of convergence and competitiveness for all. Let’s use the tools we already have in place. Let’s make sure that the Commission and the Eurogroup work together to achieve this goal.  And yes, of course we must do better on migration. We must be prepared to tackle the next migration crisis. We must resist the unchecked influx of migrants and work harder on return. We really must take steps now to make the European asylum system fair and effective. If we fail to take these measures – collectively – we risk losing the advantages that Schengen has brought us. I applaud the work done by the Bulgarian Presidency on migration, and by the way, I congratulate Boyko Borisov on his birthday today! Mr President, Members of the European Parliament, the debate about the future of Europe, about old and new priorities, is also at the heart of the debate on the next multi-annual budget. To the Netherlands, it is only logical that the budget should shrink after Brexit. And within that smaller budget, it is only logical that wealthy states should pay more – but not disproportionately so. The Netherlands is willing to pay its share, but countries with a comparable level of prosperity must make a comparable net contribution per capita. Member States’ financial contributions need to be proportionate and reasonable: that’s how we see it. But figures aside, the Netherlands sees the next budget above all as a chance to show that the EU is serious about reform, by re-assigning funds to tomorrow’s priorities. We can’t solve today’s problems with yesterday’s solutions. We can’t face the twenty-first century with a budget that reflects the realities of decades ago.  At present, agriculture and structural funds swallow up 70 % of the budget. Spending less in these areas will make room for new priorities. We also need to reform the very substance of these policy areas, to make them fit for the future. That, too, is only logical; and it’s necessary. We must show the people of Europe that we practise what we preach. Because, as the old Dutch saying goes: trust arrives on foot and leaves on horseback.  In many countries, the EU’s democratic legitimacy, as well as public trust and support, are under pressure. For the future of Europe, perhaps our most important task is to regain that trust one step at a time. Of course, the democratic legitimacy of the EU has various dimensions. There’s the formal, institutional dimension. And that centres on the fine balance between the members of national parliaments and you. I’m not giving away any secrets when I say that the Netherlands attaches great importance to the role of national parliaments. Because that is where we must address the question of what Member States can do better themselves, and what should be a matter for the EU as a whole. In other words, how taxpayers’ money should be spent.  Here, in the European Parliament, proposals for European laws and rules are discussed, amended and adopted. Here, implementation is monitored. And here, plans and proposals by the Council and the Commission for the future of the EU are weighed and discussed. In this way, national parliaments and the European Parliament together provide the EU’s democratic legitimacy. But there’s also a less institutional dimension. Because legitimacy and realism are extensions of each other. So the EU needs to listen to what the citizens of the Member States want from it. And especially, what they don’t want. And it has to act on that. I believe that delivering on the EU’s basic promise is crucial if support for the EU and unity are to be preserved. Yes of course, there can be no democratic legitimacy without the rule of law. Let me be crystal clear on that point: ours is a union of laws and values. Membership of the EU is not a statement of intent. It means opting unconditionally for freedom of the press, an independent judiciary, legal certainty and all those other democratic achievements that bind us together as a community of values. (Applause) It’s literally part of the deal. When you’re in, you’re in all the way. This is a pressing issue for this Parliament too, I’m happy to say. Those who say that the rule of law is a purely national matter are wrong. The people of Europe can flourish only if the rule of law applies in all Member States.  (Applause)  Our citizens need to trust each other’s legal systems. And businesses need to know that their investments are safe, and that any disputes will be resolved by an independent judiciary. That’s why it’s vital that countries do what they agreed when they signed up as members of the EU, and that the Commission monitors this rigorously and independently. Ladies and gentlemen, friends, one of the founding fathers of the European Union was Johan Beyen, a post-war Dutch Minister of Foreign Affairs. In his memoirs, published in 1968, he refers to the story of the giraffe that Julius Caesar brought back to Rome from one of his campaigns. It’s said that the Romans weren’t sure what to call this strange animal. Eventually they settled on ‘camelopard’, because it had a neck like a camel and spots like a leopard. Beyen wrote: ‘Europe is like a giraffe: an animal difficult to define, but easy to recognise.’ And fifty years on, that’s still a good description. Because Europe’s wealth lies in the diversity of its Member States and the regions, the histories, and all the different languages and cultures. That can’t be summed up in a few words.  At the same time, Europe is easy to recognise as a community of values and as a united partnership. It’s a circle of covered wagons that gives strength and protection, and that’s my core message. We don’t have to agree on everything – and we probably won’t today – in order to recognise the value of unity in a fast—changing world. That unity, ladies and gentlemen, is the future of Europe: our future. (Sustained applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you very much, Mr Rutte. The first reaction is positive. I think that a standing ovation is a good message from the European Parliament.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to start by thanking Prime Minister Rutte for praising former Dutch Foreign Ministers. That’s always a good thing to do. Listening to Prime Minister Rutte, I was thinking about one of the most important contributions the Dutch nation has made to Europe, as it now stands. I have to take you back to 1581 when, after a long struggle with the Spanish King, the Dutch Parliament (if you could call it at the time the States General) declared that, since the King did not perform his duty vis-à-vis the Dutch population, he had in fact left the throne – vacated the throne. This ‘Act of Verlatinghe’ is the first document in European history where it said that sovereignty is in the hands of the people, and for them to give to the rulers. I think this has later also been the inspiration for the Declaration of Independence in the United States and for the Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen in France, and therefore it constitutes, I believe, an essential element of today’s Europe and our values. I wanted to take you back briefly to the Dutch Republic because the Dutch Republic, once it had obtained its independence and freedom, flourished incredibly to become a world power. And the elements of that were openness; entrepreneurial attitudes; audacity (to try and sail all over the world), but also respect for diversity; curiosity about what is different; openness to other religions and other beliefs; putting an end to persecution of people who had different beliefs. It’s interesting, if you follow Dutch history, that in those times when we were open towards what is different, we did well. And in those times when we became introspective, we became afraid of what is different, we set our backs to the outside world, we declined and we became irrelevant in world politics. I think this applies to Europe today, and I really, on behalf of the European Commission, want to thank the Prime Minister for the sense of urgency he has expressed today before this Parliament. This sense of urgency should be guiding what we do right now, because the unthinkable has become possible. Who would have said five years ago that the European Union can break up and disintegrate? Nobody. It was gratuitous to attack the European Union and its institutions, because they were unbreakable anyway. And now we’ve seen, as a consequence of the fourth industrial revolution, as a consequence of all these crises we’ve had, that the European Union is not unbreakable – which means that it’s valuable. Something that is breakable and fragile can be extremely valuable, and that is the European Union. So this is the time for people who believe in the European Union to stand up and come together and show unity, and this is precisely what the Prime Minister has advocated today. And I warmly welcome that. What is creating this brittle element in our Union? I believe, to sum it up, it is, arguably, moral hazard. The Union functions because Member States trust each other that they will do what we agreed collectively. This trust has been eroded over the last ten years: between north and south, east and west, within the west, within the east. If we do not confront the issue of moral hazard, if we do not take that away, if we do not take that out of our Union, how could we ask our Member States and our people to share their destinies? I can only share a destiny with someone I trust and can rely on when I’m in trouble. If that is not the case, I will withdraw, because it is too risky for me. I believe that is where it starts, and that’s my own very urgent call upon the Prime Minister, as a Member of the European Council. If I look back over the last couple of years, what is the issue that has brought the European Union to the brink? It’s the issue of migration.
