We need to get back to basics, Minister. You mentioned one father from Europe, and I would like to quote another: Mr De Gasperi. I went to see you again. He said back in 1954 that we need a European architecture that can dominate from base to top, where we incorporate all thoughts, and not, as Verhofstadt says so many times: you are good, you are bad, you are included, you are out the door, no! And look, then the situation was not easy. We were after the war, there were still so many fascinated by Bolshevik totalitarianism. Today we must take back that Europe in order to build a common home, where citizens want to enter, from the bottom up. Top to bottom doesn't work.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, I appreciate, like many colleagues, a huge contradiction in your speech, because we share this geopolitical and geo-economic scenario of concern about Europe. There are a huge number of defensive challenges, in terms of digital agenda, in the area of migration.  Everyone puts huge challenges on the table; you too, but you say you have to reduce the budget of the European Union. You say that when the UK leaves, we have to reduce the budget and we don't have to give one more euro from the states that can do it. This is an absolute contradiction.  In my opinion, you have to answer us if you think it is credible, that it is plausible, that it is possible to face the challenge of Europe's future with all these great challenges without a budget and without further economic contribution. And my specific question is: Do you believe in the European Union's own resources? Do you think it is possible for the European Union to establish its own resources to finance the future of the Union?

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Prime Minister and Vice-President, you have both mentioned the principle of the rule of law. It can also be said that if the rule of law does not exist, then there will be no Europe for a long time to come. But let us look at the euro zone. Mrs Christine Lagarde said that we had to break the treaties in order to save the euro. And everything I see in the euro zone is not constitutional. The question is always: what do we have to do to keep the euro zone together – even against the law? And now we know how fragile this institution is because it has been misconstructed. And we are not saying that we need to get rid of the wrong construction, but that we are now introducing funds. We introduce funds when people have broken the law so that they do not break the law in the future. All I can say is that anyone who develops this euro zone in this way will have a moral hazard all the time, Mr Timmermans. What should I make at home if others cover up my mistakes and reward me for them?

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: – Prime Minister, good afternoon. I am in the back of this in the angel box of this Parliament, right in front of you. Yes, you'll see me. We had a debate here yesterday on the future of economic and monetary union. And the consensus was actually pretty big. Emu was and still is a historic project, but is far from finished. We knew that, but we still looked the other way for years, actually up to and including the financial crisis of 2008. Recovery works on this EMU are now really needed. But there are still very different opinions on this. I would like to return briefly to the creation of EMU. Many economists and academics agreed at the outset that a monetary union cannot work without fiscal capacity. Nor is there any other monetary union in the world without such a budgetary and political link attached to it. Yet we have started this shaky construction. Political interests prevailed, economic laws had to be undermined. Therefore, this question: What do you think went wrong in the creation of EMU? If you had been on the Delors Committee yourself in 1989 to draw up the blueprint for EMU, how would you have handled it to ensure that we were able to continue today?

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, (inaudible as the microphone is not switched on) ... a more united Europe in the current world, but unity should be based on all Member States getting a sense of benefit from belonging to the European Union. And something is unbalanced now, because some Member States get a benefit from having a geographically-central position in Europe, combined with good exchange rates regarding the euro launch, plus using tax rates which are low to attract more resources. This creates unbalanced conditions in which to invest and to create jobs. So we need to rebalance the situation, and the minimum we need to do is to have a European budget keeping a strong commitment with cohesion and to equip our monetary zone with a fiscal capacity. I really agree that we can no longer continue with the situation of a monetary zone – the only one in the world – that does not have a fiscal capacity. These are decisions for the next European Council, so we count on you also to move in this direction.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, two are the problems I wish to bring to your attention, namely: your country has permanently opposed the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into the Schengen area in the Council, even though we have fulfilled all the technical conditions, being providers of security and stability in the region. I would like to ask you clearly: what is your position today on the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into the Schengen area, because I find the current situation deeply unacceptable and incorrect towards the Romanian people. The second issue is the European Union budget. The Netherlands today opposes increasing the national contribution to the European Union budget to a level that allows adequate funding for cohesion policy, the common agricultural policy, but also to face challenges such as migration or border security. In this context, I ask you, Prime Minister, how do you think we can make a strong European Union without the necessary financial resources to do so?

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Prime Minister, thank you for being here today. In your speech, you spoke of solidarity and of improving life in the European Union. I have to ask you: is it in solidarity that 40% of the group's profits are spilled into tax havens? Or is it in solidarity that we take the money into our hands and ensure better living conditions for people within Europe? Is it in solidarity that we are investing more money in ERASMUS? Is it in solidarity that we invest more money in an Interrail ticket? And is it in solidarity that we end youth unemployment in Europe and not place corporations in tax havens? That is my definition of solidarity. That is why I have a clear question: do you believe that it is necessary to tax companies fairly in countries throughout Europe in order to help Europeans?

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome Prime Minister Rutte to the  European Parliament. Prime Minister, I think if you were to answer all our questions, you’d be here for the next week, so can I give you just one reflection, as an Irish colleague? You said earlier that you need the support of the European Parliament. Can I say to you that the European Parliament and the pro-European forces in the European Parliament need the support of the European Council to get more of Europe working? There is a majority in this House for an ambitious European project. We come from the centre right and the centre left, from the centre ground, and we represent the majority of European citizens who are ambitious and want the European project to succeed across the 500 million citizens. That’s the message I want you to bring back to the European Council: that, if you want our support, we look for your support as well. On the EU budget, can I ask you this? Let’s be ambitious for a change. Let’s do something differently for a change. Let’s agree the EU budget before next year. That would send out a strong message that we are serious about reform, serious about new contributions and serious about making sure that Europe works.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: – Mr President, Mr Prime Minister – here. It’s good to have you back in the Parliament, and I am referring to this, in particular, because I remember you were here in January of 2016, and at this point you said: ‘we have two months more in order to settle the resettlement issue’. And now it’s been, I think, 29 months since you said this, and we still haven’t a solution for that problem. So I ask you: why did you fail, and what kind of hopes do you have for the next presidency, which will also have to tackle that issue?

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, as a member of the European Council you have declared yourself an opponent of the integration of Romania and Bulgaria into the Schengen area, while Romania is already acting de facto, defending more than 2 000 kilometres of the Eastern European border. Your opposition has strengthened and fueled a speech by some Eurosceptics in Romania, linking this decision to certain protectionist economic policies and the delay of the competition of the port of Constanta in Romania with other ports in the European Union. In the previous plenary session, the European Parliament reiterated its call for Romania and Bulgaria to be immediately integrated into the Schengen area and - as you well mentioned in the example of the Roman Empire - the great empires fall apart if they fail to secure their borders. Two weeks after the European Parliament's decision, I would like to ask you: what position do you have on Romania and Bulgaria's entry into the Schengen area?

name: Ana GOMES
text: – (inaudible as the microphone is not switched on) …the EU ensures security and the rule of law when Member States, including the one that you lead, function as laundromats to kleptocrats, oligarchs, the corrupt and criminals from around the world. According to Europol, your country accounts for one fourth of actions reported as suspected instances of money laundering, mostly related to drug-trafficking. Senhor Presidente, a Holanda é o principal paraíso fiscal para os evasores do meu país, Portugal. A sua desculpa de que a fiscalidade é matéria de soberania nacional não serve para dar cobertura ao papel holandês na corrida para o fundo na fiscalidade na União Europeia, que põe em causa a solidariedade, o mercado único, regras de concorrência, justiça, boa governação e a segurança de nós todos. Qual é a sua posição sobre o CCCTB? Why delay the VAT reform, and why delay an EU tax on digital platforms, financial transactions and polluting industries? Why obstruct these ways to increase the EU’s own resources and favour economic convergence and political cohesion in the eurozone and in the European Union?

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Prime Minister Rutte, welcome and thank you for your contribution to this important discussion.   Like you, I see the Union as a community of sovereign countries that cooperate with each other on issues to which a European level can provide better answers than national level. But both you and I know that subsidiarity is a principle that the EU institutions too often forget.   I am glad that you are one of the few leaders who has said loud and clear that we do not need more Europe. We need a better Europe that will have confidence in member states and only intervene in those areas where it can offer added value.   What are these areas must be the fruit of consensus. You said the Union wasn't to me from which anyone could take only what suited it. I agree, with the addition that the rules that apply equally to all should nevertheless be accepted unanimously, not imposed on anyone.   This Union must be based on good faith otherwise there is no future. And by the way, John Wayne did what the scriptwriters told him him to do, and so far the scriptwriters for the EU are not doing such a good job.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Prime Minister that in my country there is still a lot of sympathy for his beautiful tulip country. But don’t forget, Prime Minister, that these tulip flowers come from East Europe. We share the same values in our history and we ask you to share the same values in the European Union, to respect the Treaty of Schengen acquis and to respect all the Treaties, because for us the rule of law means respect for the Treaties of the European Union, including the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Prime Minister Rutte, thank you very much. Yes, again in Dutch you can do it again. First of all, I would like to congratulate you, because after many years you recognise that Europe is more than market and currency. I think that has been the slogan of GroenLinks for 20 years. But it doesn't matter. It's a great thing that that step has been taken, so congratulations. You are also taking very good steps in the field of climate change. I can tell you that the European Parliament supports the Netherlands in reducing emissions by 55%. So we're already behind you. Now that we're getting a few more countries into the Council. That's another job. But what we are missing from the debate and in your story is the next step in your love for Europe, which is a social Europe. Where is the story of social Europe? As you know, we have created a single market and a Europe with a single market of workers, but in the area of taxation we are still national islands from which the countries can benefit. I have a very simple question: are you going to support the initiative to get a minimum corporate tax rate within Europe in order to reduce this levelling?

name: Jiří PAYNE
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, the EU is not working. The world of European institutions and the rhetoric that makes everything pink is not a world in which people live. This is a world of endlessly changing regulations, increasingly strict and brutally ruthless yet useless. This is a world of prohibitions, orders, obligations and fines. A world in which established traditions and nods do not apply. Spread butter is just spread, the bulb must not be hot and vacuum cleaners do not vacuum.  Instead of democracy, we have a democratic deficit, instead of free trade, we have a single market. While free movement of capital is a great thing, the vast majority of Europeans have no capital.  Hostility towards the UK, which has decided to exercise its legitimate right, can be seen at every turn. And migration has shown that the EU cannot cope with its own existence and wants to address its failures with the solidarity of the Member States.  This is a world in which citizens have absolutely no influence over what is happening, and we need to change that. We must create an alternative, a viable path that will fix the European continent, a plan to base cooperation on better foundations.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, thank you, Prime Minister, for being with us today. Since this is a debate about the future of Europe, I will refer to young people. We all know the advantage of the Erasmus programme, but I think it is also necessary for young people to study in depth the background, objectives and functioning of the institutions of the European Union, that 'camelopardo' so difficult to define which you were referring to a minute ago. I therefore welcome the recent approval by the Council of the Commission's recommendation on the promotion of education on European issues in European schools. I find this European subject very convenient, and I hope that the Member States will soon implement it. Secondly, I would like to underline a serious problem which affects europe as a whole today: the low birth rate and therefore a future with fewer young people. I would like, or would have liked, that in the multiannual financial framework this demographic decline which already affects the whole of Europe would have been more present when it comes to distributing funds between regions. In her country the birth rate is already low, it is 1.66 per woman, although it is still higher than that of other countries. I would like to know your assessment of these facts.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister, you have told us that Europe must be less in useless things – and I can agree that we must reduce the invasiveness of certain detailed rules – but at the same time you have made it clear that we need a strong European Union in foreign policy, defence, security and economic policies and therefore in the defence of the euro area.  So do you not think that on these issues we need a real transfer of sovereignty, and therefore more Europe? Secondly, do you not think that we need an adequate budget? You are certainly right when you say that moral hazard is wrong, but I would like to see what you would do if you were with 30, 40 or 50 % of young unemployed or unemployed people, whether you would choose austerity first or whether you would choose instead to answer the questions of your citizens.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, I would like to address the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, first I want to join the call from my colleagues for the Council to find a solution to the migration issue next week. Second, you said we need to regain the trust of citizens. Yes. Last week, Chancellor Angela Merkel and Prime Minister Kurz took a clear stand: the work of the European Parliament should be in one location. Don’t you think that, as EU leaders engage in talks on key reforms and on the budget, the time has come to put the issue of the single seat on the European Council agenda? Are you willing to take a stand and to open a constructive dialogue with your colleagues and with us for a roadmap for treaty change; for a more effective, a less costly, a climate-friendly European Parliament close to citizens? You said, Prime Minister: ‘Let’s show the people that we practise what we preach’. Are you going to do it? (Applause)

name: Răzvan POPA
text: – Prime Minister, Romania deserves Schengen. I have listened carefully to your speech, and in the spirit of what you have said, especially about solidarity, I ask you to support the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into the Schengen area. I appeal because for Romanian citizens it is incomprehensible that the Netherlands' opposition to Romania's entry into Schengen is incomprehensible. There is a current in my country that the Netherlands opposes Romania's accession to the Schengen area so that the port of Constanta does not become a direct competitor of the port of Rotterdam. Because Romania has met all the accession criteria - and I am not the only one saying so, the Commission says, the European Parliament knows it - and if there were other reasons, other states would certainly have opposed Romania's entry into the Schengen area. That is why, in conclusion, Prime Minister, I ask you to support Romania's entry into the Schengen area, as well as Bulgaria.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, dear Prime Minister, let me tell you very frankly: I was delighted to listen to the first part of your speech. You were in the line of the best Dutch tradition of Huig de Groot, pleading for a geopolitical global role for the European Union. But then you have to explain to us how this is compatible – this giant external European Union – with an internal dwarf European Union. Because you don’t care about MFF, about eurozone reform. You plead for more subsidiarity, so how do you make compatible a very, very weak internal European Union with a giant in the global landscape? This is not sustainable. This is a major contradiction, Mr Rutte. And let me put a final question: do you really believe that one per cent of the budget, one per cent of GDP, is the fast track – the big way – for the big government of the European institutions? One per cent, Mr Rutte? Please, be reasonable. I would say, like Mr Verhofstadt: come on, Mr Rutte.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister Rutte, we got your message: focus on added value and what the European Union can do best by acting together. That is the case with external borders, migration and refugees. So, you take the floor in the next European Summit and state three principles. Number one: the situation of the Aquarius is not only immoral, it’s against humanitarian law and European law. It’s about time that the Council fingers point not at those who act like the new government in Spain but at those who do not act. Number two: the question cannot be externalised and the answer cannot be simply repressive. It has to be holistic and preventive. And number three: it’s got to be political. No country can be left alone; not Malta, or Spain, or Italy can be left alone. The question is political. You quoted Winston Churchill by saying that politics is about foretelling the future and explaining eventually why it didn’t happen. But the best Churchill quote is that politics is first and foremost about action, and no action at all is the worst failure for the European Union.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Prime Minister of the Netherlands. – Mr President, I am so happy that the whole Parliament has now come together to listen to my final reply. Thank you all for participating in this debate. I believe it is an excellent opportunity to discuss the big issues of the European Union and how we can work together. There were so many questions, I cannot answer all of them but I have tried to bring them back to basically four key issues. The first of them, of course, is the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). Ms Schreijer-Pierik, I am of course in favour of the common agricultural policy. It has to stay, but it also has to modernise and the whole budget has to modernise. We, as politicians, have to make choices in scarcity. We have to make choices about what we are going to spend our money on. I am absolutely convinced that we cannot just say there are new tasks which have to be funded and, at the same time, we cannot find savings in the existing budget. That is the plea I am making here. That is exactly what all the Member States have to do. I believe that simply saying we have to go to 1.3% again will only fuel the extremists who are saying that Europe is not making the necessary choices.  Secondly, on migration: here today I reach out my hand to Italy because I know that they have to deal with an extremely difficult situation. But I also eagerly await the Italian Government’s national measures because they have to do a lot in order to manage the inflow of illegal migrants better, and then they know that we stand ready to show solidarity and, as the European Union, to work collectively to address this issue, which no doubt will be with us for years to come. Ms de Lange rightly alluded to the Common European Asylum System, and we need, as part of that, to take out the root causes of migration. This is also my answer to Mr Bashir on this issue: better guarding of our borders and working on better return mechanisms for rejected asylum seekers. Again, I hope that I will be successful, with my colleagues at the European Council in June, in taking the necessary decisions although, looking at where the debate is now, it is not an absolute given that we will be successful on this. Many of you alluded to or discussed Schengen and the accession of Bulgaria and Romania. Let me be very clear on this: I welcome the fact that both Bulgaria and Romania have the aspiration fully to join the Schengen acquis. We acknowledge the work which has been done in Bulgaria and Romania on this issue, but we also know the work is not yet finished. Romania and Bulgaria need to meet several conditions that stem from joining the EU, as defined in the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism, one of the benchmarks of which concerns corruption – and, here too, a deal is a deal. We cannot have countries entering the Schengen area if they do not fulfil all the criteria. Another issue is that of which tasks the European Union should be working on. For example, one of the tasks raised by the S&D Group is the issue of a social Europe. I believe that social affairs have to stay at a national level, but when social affairs have a cross-border impact then Europe also needs to get involved. Therefore, for example, this issue of making sure that people get paid the same amount of money in the same circumstances for the same type of work is an issue where Europe has a role to play, as it does in the area of transportation. I know that one of the speakers was the chair of the biggest Dutch union and I am absolutely convinced that, in those days, she would have fully agreed with what I have just stated. As I said in my speech, the European Union has to concentrate on its core tasks: those being, of course, the internal market, economic and monetary union (EMU), external borders, the issue of migration and, yes, the big issue of climate change. Finally, regarding the eurozone and EMU: as you know, a particular subject on the agenda for the European Council meeting at the end of June is the banking union. I believe that we need to take the necessary next steps on the banking union. But let me also go back to what was the basic promise of the euro, namely that it was not a redistribution of wealth but that our cooperation makes the cake bigger for everyone. That was the basis of EMU. I believe that EMU can deliver on this only if all the Member States get their house in order, which means aiming for sound and sustainable budgets and competitive economies through the implementation of structural reforms. When you do this, you will have not one big European mechanism to absorb macroeconomic shocks, but rather mechanisms at national level – 19 shock-absorption funds – and then you will not need additional stabilisation funds at European level. We also have to remain focused – and this is crucial – on structural reforms. They are essential for competitive and shock-resistant economies, and here, as I said in my speech, already at the moment in the MMF, we are spending hundreds of billions of euros within the eurozone on cohesion funds, on a common agricultural policy and on structural funds. My plea would be that the eurozone countries, together with the Commission, would give much clearer guidance on how to make better use of that already existing money in order to ensure that it fuels and supports structural changes in our national economies, because that would mean we were making better use of the existing money. The idea of the Commission proposals is to put some extra money in for the eurozone, but here I would say that we already have hundreds of billions of euros on the table and we can make better use of them. So, in terms of EMU reform, the main issue on the agenda at the end of June will be the banking union but also we will no doubt discuss some wider themes, and this will be part of my input to that debate. Thank you again for hosting me and giving me this opportunity. I thank the whole Parliament for this wonderful initiative and I will tell all my colleagues – six have already been here, I was number seven – that they should all come because it is useful, it is invigorating and it is also great fun. So thank you. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you very much, Mr Rutte, for the timing. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – I hope, Prime Minister, that neither you nor the Council focus on the last part of the quote! I listened carefully and agreed to some of your statements, but you contradicted each other in many ways! You said you want a better Europe, but you don't want to support a bigger budget for cohesion. You said that states must work with each other, that you understand the value of compromises and shared interests, but at the same time you support tax havens in your country and do not support interests for all European citizens! An eloquent example is the systematic opposition of Romania and Bulgaria's entry into Schengen, although for seven years they have met all the technical conditions! You said that the EU must take into account the position of national parliaments, but in the Council you take this into account, even though you said that the EU must listen to its citizens! All citizens, Prime Minister! Then listen to the millions of Romanians and Bulgarians, but also the citizens of other countries who are demanding the admission of Romania and Bulgaria to Schengen! You talked about unity, but add solidarity! What Union can it be that ignores social cohesion?

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. This is the u u u u,000th time we have come together to discuss the future of Europe together with one of the Prime Ministers of the Union. We usually argue about beautiful and noble principles, but I am increasingly under the impression that we are constantly disconnected from reality. From above, we are trying to tell European citizens what their future will look like and what is important in their lives. I think that is contrary to our mandate. We're sitting here representing people, not controlling their thinking. In April this year, the Eurobarometer conducted an EU-wide survey in which, among other things, they asked what the issues that are most important for the future of the Union should be, what the forthcoming European Parliament election campaign should be about. The survey clearly shows that the three most important themes are migration, terrorism and unemployment. I believe that these issues are far from being dealt with according to their weight, and when we do talk about them, we offer the rarest real solution. I find it difficult to imagine that the European citizens who are following this debate would sit back contentedly in their seats, because once again they feel a little safer about their future. I ask you to talk about these issues in a real and constructive way, because that is what democracy is all about.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – In times of difficult questions and major challenges, Dutch Prime Minister Marko Rutte reminds us of the importance of the European project and why it is worth fighting for. The EU is one of the most successful projects in our modern history, where a tangle of different nations, cultures and languages seeks to seek compromises and jointly achieve goals that we, as individuals, would not be able to achieve. Of course, our Union is going through a difficult time, be it Britain's departure, a difficult economic situation or a complex refugee crisis, but the answer is certainly not indifference or closure. I agree with Mark Rutte that we need to look more consistently for where the EU can help improve our lives, and also fully appreciate the value of unity in this rapidly changing world.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – It has so far been emphasised by all Prime Ministers in their speeches to the European Parliament the importance of cooperation and trust. Unfortunately, this cooperation and unity is not felt. When it comes to the key issues of our future, some still insist on their ideas, even though they have proved unacceptable for others. We have heard today that there is no need to accept new agreements if even the old ones are not implemented. It is right to look to the future, but at the moment it is more important to unify on solutions to the challenges of the present. The security situation, the migrant crisis, the state of the economy, the ageing of the population, the patchy and ineffective foreign policy, Brexit are themes where we should find common language and act immediately. The answers to these questions will also have a major impact on what our future will be like. I do not want us to lose confidence in democracy, the rule of law and human rights. I also don't want you to lose your identity.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. – Thank you for your speech, Prime Minister Rutte. It is great that you have highlighted the unity of the European Union in international relations and the importance of free trade. Both of these are important to my country, Finland, and to me. A united Europe is needed more in this time of the world than it has been for a long time. Europe must act as a global leader and take its due weight on the international field. Europe must promote and defend common values: the rule of law, democratic values, democracy, equality. The EU must act for peace and stability. In trade policy, too, it is possible for the EU to take leadership. With the United States withdrawing and China strengthening its grip, it is vital that Europe, as the world's largest trading area, shows direction in world trade and is active in drawing up trade agreements.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: Written. "The future of Europe is decided today. Europe, with its different cultures and nation states, is what we Europeans call our home, we have no other home. If this home is razed or changed beyond recognition by other cultural customs taking over where should we, our children and grandchildren go? The EU was launched as a solution to strengthen Europe through peace, trade and cooperation. Instead, this has now developed into a machinery that, among other things, tries to persuade Member States to take in huge numbers of illegal migrants, especially economic migrants, often from the world's most dysfunctional and violent states and cultures. This happening fundamentally transforms many of Europe's countries at such a rapid pace that we have lost control. There is no room, time or incentive for the assimilation of these groups and soon no room for indigenous European cultures. The EU must now stop all migration in addition to a limited proportion of quota refugees, and stop any expansion of the EU. This is what a majority of Europeans want and what is required as a first step if we are to continue to manage the common European cultural heritage and the specific national European cultures and to give prosperous, safe and democratic states in the heritage of our children and grandchildren.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Before I move on to a few procedural issues, I would like to inform you that a few hours ago It was announced by Prime Ministers Alexis Tsipras and Zoran Zaev in Athens and Skopje an agreement that is important not only for the two neighbouring countries, but also for the whole Of the European Union. Already the President of the Council of the European Union, Mr. Tusk, the Commission and the UN have warmly welcomed the agreement, describing it as a "historic" and a "great victory for diplomacy."  The European Parliament, we, have consistently sought over the years such an agreement mutually acceptable to both countries. The dozens of resolutions we have adopted with a very large majority and the consensus of all the political groups attest to this. This is an important, positive development, which we in the European Parliament have been working on for years and I think I express the European Parliament by welcoming this agreement and welcoming it.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I refer to Rule 158(2) of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure, which states: 'All Members have the right to speak the official language of their choice in Parliament. The speeches in one of the official languages shall be interpreted simultaneously in all the other official languages and in any other language which the Bureau deems necessary.' In order to guarantee this fundamental right of Members to provide the highest quality services, interpreters must find adequate working conditions. The European Parliament must ensure that these services to European democracy take place on good terms, that work and private life are well reconciled and that the physical and mental health of staff are not jeopardised. As a left-wing group of the GUE/NGL, we therefore stand behind the interpreters who oppose the deterioration of their working conditions. No matter how difficult negotiations are, in the end there must be a result that can be supported by both sides. (Applause)

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Madam President, I note your speech, as well as the applause that accompanied it. We have discussed this in the Bureau of the European Parliament. We will discuss this again in pursuit of a consensual solution.

name: Patricia LALONDE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to draw your attention to the assault that has just been launched by the Saudi-led coalition in Hodeida, Yemen's main port. This port is the main source of humanitarian aid delivery. We are in danger of witnessing an unprecedented humanitarian catastrophe without witnesses, as UN personnel and major NGOs have been asked to leave.  Europe should use diplomacy and support the efforts of Martin Griffiths, the UN special envoy, to reach a negotiated solution.

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: – Mr President, under Rule 11(3), I wanted to point out we’ve had two unelected Commissioners come to this Parliament and insult elected Members of this Parliament, calling them ‘extreme’. Under Rule 11(3), you are meant to show mutual respect and not be defamatory. This is a disgrace. We are the elected; they are the unelected. They should show us some respect. (Applause and cheering from certain quarters)

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: Mr President, I would like to make a statement on the resolution of the Skopje issue. Who doesn't want to solve a problem that's been pending for thirty years? Of course we all want to. But what Parliament needs to know is that this is a memorandum of understanding, without any governmental decision from any country, and it basically refers to a 'Macedonian nation' and a 'Macedonian language', which must be clarified and cannot be accepted by anyone. We will not solve the problem of Skopje in order to create a problem and division in my country, Greece.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Several colleagues in the Chamber note, as before, that the matter is not a matter of procedure.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have been in this Chamber for four years and I listen very patiently to all my colleagues when they ask for the floor. Please listen to me for only thirty seconds, because for you it may not be a serious matter, but for us Greeks it is of paramount importance. I'll just say two words. Mr President, you forgot to say in your communication on such a serious issue concerning Greek society, the Greek people, that the agreement reached, as you mentioned, is in breach of every rule of democracy, precisely because the Greek Parliament has not been informed or any body that you should seriously inform.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues for their patience. I would just like to thank you for this vote. I think we have just taken one more very important step toward the European elections of 2019. I also believe that we have found a good solution for the composition of the future Parliament that is fair and objective and also respects European law. It has also been agreed by unanimity by the European Council. This decision, I would like to remind you, comes on top of our earlier decisions on setting the dates for the European elections, amending the Regulation on the financing of European parties and also outlining Parliament’s position on the Spitzenkandidaten process. I also hope that during our next plenary session, we will finalise our reform of European electoral law, also adopted by unanimity by the Council.  So now the challenge for all of us is to spare no efforts to increase citizens’ participation in the elections to the European Parliament and strengthen the ownership of Europe.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as co-rapporteur I will not take much time for you, but I would also like to mark this moment when Parliament is making a final decision on its future composition. I would like to thank everyone for their cooperation and, above all, for their strong support for our report, because it is not every day when such a broad consensus can be formed on a sensitive issue in this Parliament and also in the Council. And we have good reason to be satisfied: a fairer representation of the states in this Parliament, complying with the Treaty of Lisbon, a smaller parliament with 705 seats and room for future enlargements, and also the guarantee that no state loses seats. This is a good day for European democracy and the European project.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Mr President, I have an oral amendment: ‘the Finance Minister for Ukraine was dismissed on 7 June; the Finance Minister had objected to government payments on the grounds of corruption’.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: We shall now proceed to the explanations of vote. I would ask everyone to be strictly consistent in the 1 minute available in accordance with Rule 183 of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: – Mr President, a real circular economy requires systemic change, so we should ask ourselves whether a true circular economy is possible within this European Union trade policy and free trade agreements. We believe that it does not, because an economy that closes cycles has to be structured around precisely the short circuits, and this economy must also be diverse, neither hyperspaceized nor productivist. Solidarity, feminist or environmental economies have proposals and practices that are very useful for this systemic shift towards the circular economy, but they also involve political changes. There is no circular economy without wealth sharing, without real democratization.  To talk about a circular economy is to talk about energy and food sovereignty, social equity and human health; is to talk about transformative municipalism; to recover the learnings of the rural world, in which nothing was was wasted; is to reconnect countryside and city; is to talk about proximity consumption. It is, in short, to talk about building a much more livable Europe among all.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – The issue of the circular economy and cohesion policy is extremely important, especially since it needs to be intestructed into, in fact, the entire cycle of the so-called cohesion policy, which must be targeted and one of these important objectives must also focus on the protection of the environment, including health and nutrition. And here we come to one of the pressing problems of our future, and that is waste management, plastic management, which represents one of the biggest challenges, including for the circular economy, and if we tackle it with all seriousness and also with the resources we have, we can bring down plastics as a dangerous resource very strongly, and that also means a better future for food, for health and also for the environment. That is why, of course, it is also important to understand the circular economy and also to understand cohesion policy through concrete objectives.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I voted in favour of this report and congratulate the reporter and all the colleagues who have been involved in this very important work. We Socialists are committed to a sustainable and economical circular economy, and Monika Smolková has successfully represented this in the dossier. I am pleased that we are also approaching the circular economy from the point of view of cohesion policy, because we are talking about a new political priority for the financial cycle. Cohesion must not only reduce regional differences between cities and regions, but it should be noted that rural areas are a strong part of cohesion policy, such as rural settlements. We know smart cities under regional policies, but the new Smart Villages initiative also has a lot to do with this policy in addition to rural development policy.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Cohesion policy is one of the most interesting and valuable financial instruments we have. I am very pleased that it has been defended. First of all, because its main recipient is local governments. On the point where we voted today, However, I must say that I am not optimistic. It seems to me that we are not keeping up with the mass production of various packaging in any element, and this is particularly evident in large cities. It seems to me that this instrument should be accompanied by additional elements, thanks to which we will indeed be able to cope with the growing amount of rubbish. This can be seen not only in large cities, but above all in landfills, where the selection of garbage falls out, in short, not the most interesting.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! I abstained in this vote because some of the provisions of the report raise my doubts. Polish government is of the opinion that we should promote fair market access. Therefore, we cannot agree with granting the advantage of renewable energy in the form of priority shipping. This would mean that this would come at the expense of energy produced from coal, gas or cogeneration, which, unfortunately, is still underestimated in the European Parliament. I believe that this is contrary to the market approach and the security of supply of our network. The depletion of resources, the increase in their prices and the increasing dependence on suppliers from third countries pose a serious threat to the further development of the European Union. Although I support the transition towards a circular economy model, I believe that we should take these measures very prudently so that they do not disrupt energy security.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The report on the circular economy voted on in the framework of cohesion policy, despite the peans that were delivered during yesterday's debate, is controversial. It's about recycling, and it's more widely achieved than ever before. Firstly, its objectives are combined with financial support from cohesion policy, for which the European Commission is currently drastically reducing its resources. So where will the money come from? The report foresees an increase in the cost of base products, i.e. natural products, to cover the costs of recycled products. One of the most important provisions of the report explicitly states that this project brings greater benefits to more developed regions. I come from the Lublin region, which does not belong to this category of regions, so I could not support this report.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: "I think everyone basically thinks there is something positive about recycling and recycling. It is good for the environment, it is good for health, yes it is good for the way we organise our society. However, as we can hear from several of the speakers who have debated here today, socialism is immediately easy to do. All of a sudden, it is no longer about the environment and health and consumer protection. Instead, it is a question of allocating the values between people. It is about creating a new tax system, a new way of democratically adapting our economy, as they call it. This has been experimented with in Eastern Europe over the years. I must therefore say that I am very surprised that we cannot stay on track and simply say: let us do something good for the environment, let us do something good for public health. All the talk about the EU being about to collect taxes from some places and some countries and distribute to other places and other countries and so on - it's not anyone outside this house who wants! That is why, of course, I am voting against this report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this report. I consider it to be of high quality because, unlike some other reports, it contains a number of concrete measures that can help in the fight to protect the environment and to combat the recovery of the resources we use.  The issue of plastics is a huge environmental problem today, and it is clear that no country alone is able to solve this problem. This is precisely, in my view, a competence to be addressed by the EU, and the EU should be a world leader in this area of plastic recycling, the circular economy.  I am therefore pleased that this report has passed, and we should have a great debate in the future about what to do to protect the environment and how to deal with waste, plastic waste, which I believe is a huge environmental burden today.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, fáiltím roimh an tuarascáil seo, agus dar ndóigh vótálas ar a son mar tá a lán moltaí an-mhaith ann a dhéanfaidh maitheas dúinn amach anseo. Mr President, the proposals themselves help to build the foundations of a separate economy at regional and at local level, with an investment potential of EUR 5.5 billion. This policy creates great potential for new forms of employment where it is needed most. It is important that waste is dealt with at local level. This is for the best insights which are available to local challenges and opportunities while creating local value and sustainable jobs – and indeed, we have plenty of waste to be utilising. As a rapporteur for the Plastics Directive in the Committee on Fisheries, I think our proposal will help to reduce the amount of waste plastics over the years and, indeed, eliminate them. Indeed, also as rapporteur for the Renewable Energy Directive, I think again our proposals to increase sustainable and local energy production will help in this aim.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, I don’t know if you’re familiar with Orwell’s concept of Duckspeak, which he introduces in 1984. He defines it as being able to ‘make articulate speech issue from the larynx without involving the higher brain centres at all’. We’ve heard an awful lot of that in the debate about the circular economy. One after another the hackneyed phrases have been coming out, without thought or consideration: ‘protecting the environment’, ‘social justice’, ‘building a better Europe’ – as though anyone is against building a better Europe or as though anyone is against the environment!  What does this actually mean when we translate it into policy? Politicians have every right to cost externalities. They have every right to regulate final outcomes. If we think that there is environmental damage caused by waste or by pollution, it is absolutely our role to say ‘this is the minimum level, now over to you to see how to meet it’. But that isn’t what this debate is about. It’s all about shovelling public money around as an exercise in a kind of massive collective virtue—signalling to show that we’re nicer than the other guy. It’s not the economy that circular, it’s our ridiculous debates in this Chamber!

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, I welcome the report and I welcome the inclusion of the circular economy in cohesion policy post 2020. I was also interested in the debate and the reference by the Commissioner, Mr King, to the need to support the transition of communities reliant on linear economies and extractive economies to the new circumstances of a circular economy. I support that need for transition, but a need for transition requires money. It’s a shame that specific budget lines concerning transition funding have not as yet been included in the post-2020 MFF. I, along with my colleagues, will continue pressing for that, because if you want a model of how not to do transition from one economy to another, it exists in the way the United Kingdom got out of producing coal.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I supported this draft report because I consider it very important that cohesion policy also responds to the current challenges of the times. Among other things, it is a problem of the circular economy and the return of raw materials to circulation. This report also met my expectations because it addresses specific projects that are important for waste prevention, recycling, energy efficiency improvements, reducing consumption, indeed returning raw materials to circulation so that they are not just used once. I am very happy that a specific report is also responding to these issues, which calls on cities, municipalities and farmers to cooperate in the event of bio-waste. I think this is very important, and it is also important to me that this shows that cohesion policy is not a Cinderella, but is the dominant policy of the EU and has a link to the other innovations and technologies with which we come.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this motion because I believe that there is a clear urgency to promote the circular economy as one of the main measures in the fight against climate change. In addition, the waste of some can and should be used as the raw material of others. There are many examples of this use. In this spirit, I believe that we must give clear incentives to Member States and regional and local powers to invest in the bioeconomy and reduce waste through environmentally friendly solutions.  I think this must be the path that European citizens and Member States must take in unison for well-being, in short, in so that we can have a more sustainable planet and leave our children a better world than the one that has been bequeathed to us.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The report deplores food waste. 183 kilograms of food per person per year is, of course, regrettable, but I wanted to remind Parliament of its own regulations, such as the order to unload all the fish caught, including the undersized fish, which are then disposed of and killed simply, the destruction of crops, which results from the quotas imposed by the European Union on food production, and the huge overproduction of paper that results from the overproduction of regulation by this parliament. This parliament itself generates as much waste paper as many cities in Poland, and its excessive production of the law leads to many other people also wasting time, paper, resources and electricity to get acquainted with it. Therefore, the measure of sincerity would be to withdraw from these regulations, and for now to command something else when it is not done by itself... (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, I visited Kiev and Maidan in 2014 when the revolution was going on. I remember these people in the audience who were standing in front of the stage longing for peace, stability, democracy and the EU. They were longing to decide their own future by themselves and not have it imposed by some bigger players in the region. Four years later we have to say: yes, we have delivered a bit. The agreement between the EU and Ukraine is in force. We have the mutual assistance, we have the reform that shows considerable progress in the country, and we have the Ukrainian citizens who have been granted visas for short visits to the EU. Some things might be better, of course. We have to help Ukraine get rid of the occupants in eastern Ukraine, in the Crimea. But these agreements and the cooperation have made us both stronger, and I believe that this new macro—assistance in Ukraine will be a further step on that path.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, in Ukraine, the law for the establishment of the anti-corruption tribunal has been adopted. This success is due to the firm attitude of the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the European Union, which refused to allocate funds until the adoption of this anti-corruption tribunal law. We must also mention the efforts of civil society and responsible politicians in Ukraine. yes, we see that conditionality works. Therefore, the Union no longer has to give money until it sees results. Today we have given the green light for another billion euros to be transferred to Kiev. I call on politicians there to use them responsibly for reforms, for people and against corruption.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, we are talking about the fourth assistance programme for Ukraine and it is very clear the extent of the disaster that the European Union and NATO have caused to ukraine. For geostrategic reasons, the European Union decided to sponsor an illegal coup d'état that destroyed historical, trade and economic ties between Ukraine and Russia, completely disorganizing that economy and creating a situation of total dependence on said foreign aid. But worse, this diplomatic adventure has objectively damaged very important sectors of our agriculture that are still paying the bill for the Russian embargo. We are sensitive to the issue of corruption, but this does not erase the democratic rights that take place every day in Ukraine and, in particular, the government's intention to outlaw the Communist Party of Ukraine. We want peace and democracy to return to that country, but this means ending external interference and letting the people of Ukraine decide their future.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am speaking today primarily because of the highest quality of yesterday's debate. On the one hand, there have been naïvy beliefs that the legislative solutions that have been taken in Ukraine will solve the problem of corruption. On the other hand, there were expectations that the conditions set by the European Union would be so closely guarded, under such a regime, that Ukraine would not de facto receive financial resources and assistance. I reject these extremes. In this matter, it is necessary to show, firstly, consistency, secondly, interest and, thirdly, readiness to provide assistance in genuine conditions. Ukraine is too big, too important a country to underestimate the tasks that we set it as the European Union, but let us do so taking into account the conditions under which these tasks are carried out in Ukraine and not in France or Germany.  In short, I demand, above all, consequences, a far-reaching interest, a certain integrity, but also realism in the application of certain instruments, above all political ones.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I voted in favour of this report and congratulate the reporter and all the colleagues who have been involved in this very important work. I agree with the further disbursement of macrofinance aid to Ukraine, mainly because it is a key tool for stabilising the ukrainian economy, which remains weak under war pressure. At the same time, we must constantly monitor that EU assistance really stimulates the Ukrainian reform process and that the Ukrainian side fully fulfils its commitments in this respect. As Vice-Chairman of the European Union's Parliamentary Association Committee in Ukraine, I am well aloomed from the scene for the many problems arising from the contradictions in the fight against corruption and the slow pace of reforms, and I appreciate the concerns expressed here in the European Parliament. In addition, the joint declaration by the three EU institutions on the enforcement and strict control of conditioning against the Ukrainian side, as well as the continued reform efforts of our Ukrainian partners, most recently the long-awaited decision of the Verkhovna Rada to establish a high-level corruption tribunal, provide sufficient guarantees for the efficient and orderly use of the macrofinancial aid provided by the EU.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! I am in favour of providing further macro-financial assistance to Ukraine. In view of the crisis caused by Russian aggression in the East and the annexation of Crimea, such assistance is very necessary for Ukraine. The European Union should help Ukraine overcome its economic weaknesses and encourage the necessary reforms as soon as possible. I support the solution that this is not unconditional aid and that Ukraine must take concrete action to receive another pot of money. Financial support must be targeted and deliver tangible results. I hope that this mechanism will implement the conditions previously agreed with the European Union, such as reforming public finance management, reducing corruption or lifting, for example, the ban on timber exports.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, during yesterday's debate on macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, Mr Dombrovskis referred to the so-called 'success story' of the Ukrainian economy. What he has failed to mention is that the international community, the International Monetary Fund and the European Union have restructured Ukraine's public debt. So we had a 20% haircut and repayment of the remaining debt with a development clause. In other words, the international community essentially accepted the 1953 model for the write-off of the public debt of then West Germany. The question is: why do the European Union and the International Monetary Fund refuse to restructure public debt in Greece? Why are they refusing to cut the shameful debt that exists for Greece? Why, instead, do they impose a fourth memorandum with pension cuts, with the storage of public property? This question must be answered by Mr Dombrovskis.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: – I think most people - at least that is how I feel - find it very difficult to see what is actually happening and going on in Ukraine. That is why I have also chosen and abstained - I voted flatly on this report. On the one hand, of course, it is very good if we can contribute to economic stabilisation and structural reforms that can modernise the economy, and so on. On the other hand, I cannot help but sit back with the question: does it really work? I think we have been talking about Ukraine for an incredibly long time, that we have spent unimaginable sums, and it is very difficult to track whether there is actually value for money. That is why I am also pleased that a so-called sunset clause has been included in this report, simply insisting on the verification of the programmes - whether taxpayers' money is being spent properly or whether it is wasted. It is a step in the right direction, but still not enough to convince me.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this resolution. I understand my colleagues saying that money in Ukraine is not always used effectively. I understand that corruption is a major problem for Ukraine. On the other hand, I believe that we must geopolitically support Ukraine so that at least some functioning regime in that country works, because it is our geopolitical need, our interest in Russia.  On the other hand, the money we will provide for the future needs to be much better controlled and really used to support the development of Ukrainian society, the Ukrainian state. So the money doesn't get lost in the pockets of the oligarchs.  So there is a geopolitical interest in supporting this country, but on the other hand, we should find mechanisms to better control the money we lend.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – Mr President, I supported the resolution to provide further macro-financial assistance to Ukraine because, as a Slovak who lives near Ukraine, I think that the people of Ukraine deserve our help in building a fairer, more stable and prosperous country. However, I must also express my great concern that the Commission has suspended the financing of the modernisation project for the crossing of borders with Hungary, Romania and Slovakia due to the long delay in the construction of the modernisation of border crossing points without the possibility of other solutions. If we have allowed the ukrainian people to travel to EU countries without a visa with a time limit, then we must find solutions to ensure that the border crossing points meet at least the basic standards, because today the conditions at the Ukrainian-Slovak crossing point are alarming. I believe that it is the Commission that has the opportunity to control and guide the Ukrainian authorities so that the funds they receive from the European Union are used effectively and for the benefit of their people.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report because I believe that, in addition to boosting economic stabilisation and higher financing needs in this two-year period, this macro-financial assistance is a powerful incentive for the Ukrainian administration to strengthen its institutional structure to combat the endemic problem of corruption within the framework of the Venice Commission's recommendations and, above all, because this approval in this House consolidates relations as a strategic partner within the framework of the Eastern Partnership and strengthens our support for its european trajectory at a critical, political moment, of particular fragility and when trying to relaunch the peace process. I also believe that, in the face of successive and permanent territorial aggressions against Ukrainian sovereignty by Russia, this macro-financial assistance will also serve as a clear sign that the European Union does not accept this kind of interference and aggression and that it fully supports the Ukrainian people.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The report we are talking about at the AFET committee meeting was passed by a 45 to 0 vote ratio. It's hardly surprising. Chile is, I would say, a "piece of good Europe" in South America. This is also a very important Member State of the Union of South American Nations and of the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States. The European Union and Chile have not only history and tradition, but also strong social and economic ties. We also have our own interests and common goals. It is therefore very important to carry out and implement a project to modernise the cooperation agreement between the European Union and Chile. In fact, this becomes obvious, as we see after the vote in committee. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Can I not start by asking - to the Minutes - why should we sit and look at flags from a territory located in the Middle East? There are not even any members sitting behind the desks. Couldn't they be removed? I did not think that would make visual markings in this Chamber.  Having said that, in relation to free trade, this report is certainly a step in the right direction. In the next 10-15 years, 95% of the world's growth will take place outside the EU. That is why it is absolutely essential that we have trade agreements made, both with the emerging economies of Mercosur, but certainly also with the United States and Asia and elsewhere on the planet. Even if you sometimes believe it when you hear speeches from this Chamber, we cannot simply isolate ourselves in the small core of countries that are now the European Union. Growth and the way forward will happen in many places other than in the EU in the future. That is why this is a small step in the right direction.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The world has undeniably become much more uncertain, more anxious and unpredictable in recent years. Russian activity in the Baltic Sea is increasing, aggression against Georgia and eastern Ukraine, Crimea, has taken place, aggressive actions have been noted against Moldova and Armenia and the tone towards us in the Nordic countries has changed completely.  Last year, President Putin said that Swedish NATO membership would pose a threat to Russia. We Swedes are therefore expected to behave and choose our future based on what any other country thinks about it, how it affects any other country. It's unbelievable, it's actually unbelievable. Based on this, those who oppose Swedish NATO membership can no longer claim nonalignment. It is impossible to be nonaligned when Russia behaves as it does. Our troubled world requires us to come to NATO and demand that we obtain all security that no one else guarantees. We should have no illusions, because illusions in security policy are paid very expensively.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, a key point of next month's NATO summit is the defence against cyber-attacks, which are increasingly common. Recent events show that cyber attacks are part of hybrid warfare, and NATO must respond effectively and quickly. In addition, we must be prepared for crisis situations. Transport infrastructure, roads, bridges, railways need to be upgraded in all Member States. And bureaucratic barriers must be removed, so that the flow of transport of personnel and equipment works, not stopped by bureaucracy. We must work definitively and very clearly with NATO on all these issues that concern our defence.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I support the strategic approach of this important report, because it not only gives a comprehensive picture and calls for a sincere face to the security challenges facing Europe, both qualitatively and quantitatively, but also signals a path for the European Union to respond to it. I would like to highlight three of the changes that already require a unified decision and EU action in the near future: the emergence of hybrid security risks, including cyber warfare, which makes it urgent to exploit EU-NATO synergies. Two, in the wake of Brexit, the reduction in the weight of EU members within NATO, which should be compensated in the coming years by making dialogue and cooperation with NATO more flexible and effective, while strengthening the strategic autonomy of the European Union. The continued Russian expansion policy of Putin is the third that regularly tests the strength of the alliance at the EU's immediate border, from Ukraine and elsewhere, while seeking to share the EU by all means, and unfortunately finds a partner in the leaders of some Member States. A more striking, truly common EU... (The President withdrew the word).

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The North Atlantic Pact guarantees defence and security not only for Europe, but also for other countries in the world. The vast majority of EU countries are NATO members. When formulating ambitious targets for the Union's relationship with NATO, the report does not ignore President Donald Trump's repeated call for 2% of GDP to be spent on defence. Many EU countries are doing this, such as Poland, but countries such as Germany, for example, are lagging behind. On this report, our GROUP of THE ESC expressed doubts that have not been fully dispelled. However, we have chosen to vote in favour, strongly stressing that NATO is the foundation of European defence and its role should not be duplicated.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are debating not only on a very important subject, but also at an important moment. The next NATO summit in Brussels will take place soon, on 11 and 12 July, the first after the summit held two years ago in Warsaw, Poland. Only two years have passed and the world has changed a lot in terms of security and this has changed for the worse. Therefore, this must be taken into account. The threats that have been lurking in peace in Europe and around the world are changing radically. We are now dealing with actions, with threats that we call hybrid threats. There are unconventional threats. All this makes us think, firstly, about the future of NATO and, secondly, on the future of European security, of the European Union. Let us remember that six European Union countries do not belong to NATO and seven NATO countries do not belong to the European Union. There has been a complete change in the political situation in the United States and Turkey. This must influence our position on this issue.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, I was a supporter of NATO when 6,000 Soviet tanks camped a night on the road from our borders, when the Soviet Union held half of the Europe that the Americans had delivered to it to Yalta under the demonic grip of communism, that it was a menacing power, that communism continued its ruthless progress through subversion or by the conquest of the armed Latin America. But today, what about? Communism collapsed, the Soviet Union withdrew from Eastern Europe, from former countries that were part of the Tsarist Empire, it gave freedom to the Baltics, to the Caucasus countries, even though there is still a problem in Abkhazia, to Belarus, to Ukraine, even though there is still a problem in Crimea. NATO is no longer justified, it is the instrument of our strategic and political submission to the United States...  (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Mr President, are you blind, have you not seen what has just been played out at the G7? Have you not seen Donald Trump's contempt for all his European allies, including his close neighbour, Canada? Did you not perceive the isolation of the United States? Have you not understood that this is a unique, historic opportunity for Europe to exist? When Justin Trudeau, in a dignified reaction, says no to Donald Trump, you propose in your report that we continue to play the servants in NATO and continue dangerous policies of tension with Russia. It is despairing, and that is why I voted against this report; basically, those who want the Europe of peace, it is us, when you, you want the Europe of war through NATO.

name: Stefano MAULLU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report repeats a completely old and wrong cliché. This is a cliché which sees a revanchist attitude on the part of the European Union towards the Russian Federation. This attitude runs counter to the new world order, which is punching itself in the face with what the United States is proposing towards Europe, a contradictory and aggressive attitude from a commercial point of view. Above all, I believe that it does not take account of the new world balances, it does not take into account specifically what is moving in the Pacific and this kind of isolationism that we are in danger of having. I believe that using NATO as a scheme to re-propose this Russophobic attitude against the Russian Federation is not in Europe's interests, nor in the interests of our citizens, nor in the interests of a strategic dimension that we must have. Above all, I believe that we cannot continue to disregard what is happening in the rest of the world, in an increasingly wide, increasingly global competition. That is why I did not vote for this report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, European Union-NATO relations are important, as is the future enlargement of these two organisations. Yesterday's despicable and shameful Tsipras-Zaev agreement on Skopje paves the way for Skopje to join the European Union and NATO. It is an agreement that sells out the name of our Macedonia and our history, because Macedonia is one and Greek. There is no so-called 'Northern Macedonia', so-called 'Macedonian language' and so-called 'Macedonian citizenship'. The Tsipras-Zaev agreement harms the Greek national interest, it is an unacceptable national retreat to skopje's unspeakable and unsymphatic demands. Because the epitome of Skopje altruism is in the name "Macedonia". We are calling for a referendum on Skopje here and now, so that the Greek people who do not tolerate humiliation can finally speak! The river of rallies doesn't go back! No retreat in Skopje!

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, I believe support for today’s report is important, and my party has always stood firmly behind the collective defence of Europe. And at this time, which is a dangerous time in our history, I believe that it’s important that European nations step up to the plate and contribute that 2% that is essential to our future defence in the face of isolationism in the United States. We can’t have it both ways. We can’t on the one hand suggest that we should be relying on the United States and on the other hand suggest that we shouldn’t step up to the plate and contribute to our own defence. It is indeed a dangerous collection of forces that we face, and I find it remarkable that we have a very, very strange form of patriotism going on when people are prepared to sit behind the flag of their country and seek to demolish the structures that have defended their country over the last 70 years.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, cyber threats range from politically motivated attacks funded by states such as the Russian Federation to forms of terrorism. Moscow is using billions of dollars to pay for the thousands of experts launching attacks on computer systems in member states and overseas. Terrorist groups use cyberspace, which is a cheap and affordable way for recruitment and radicalisation. In virtual space, the military domain cannot be clearly separated from the civilian field, and those who want to attack us take advantage of our hesitations. There are solutions. I hope that NATO, at next summit next month, will find even more. But it is clear that we need European and international databases to be interoperable, to communicate with each other and to have a coordinated platform, so that information is transmitted and analysed quickly and efficiently.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Historically, we are accustomed to the fact that it is land, sea, air, recently the cosmos are theaters of warfare. In recent years, cyberspace has certainly joined this directory. So it's very important. This is demonstrated by the evidence that we have from many countries, and not only on conflicts, but also on political action, including those that concern issues that are important for democracy, such as elections. That is why the European Defence Union must take cyberspace and defence very seriously in this area. In addition, the European Defence Agency or the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security must prepare certain projects for the security of the future of the European Union, europe and therefore of the world, which is why I was in favour of this report.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am in favour of strengthening cyber defence in the European Union and of the European Union's cooperation with NATO. Cases of cyber attacks on critical infrastructure, cyberespionage, disinformation campaigns are an absolutely real threat. Member States should cooperate on cybersecurity both within the Union and with NATO. It is a very good direction to place a clear emphasis on improving this cooperation between the European Union and NATO in the cyber field, and in particular on the precise definition of priorities for strategic communication, situational awareness measures, the exchange of classified information, the suppression of illegal immigration, the removal of obstacles to the rapid and efficient movement of military personnel and resources within the Union. I believe that we should all take action to implement these solutions.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
