text: – Mr President, I support this report because the subject of cyber attacks is essentially a new topic. Our defence forces have not yet been prepared for such attacks and we must work with this problem. Especially on the part of Russia, as some of my colleagues have mentioned here, we can expect cyber attacks to increase rather than decrease in the future, and if the EU is not prepared for this, then these attacks can hit us noticeably. I believe, and it has already been said here, that we need to work with NATO on this issue, cyber attacks must be one of the key priorities for NATO, and we should coordinate with NATO as our partner at the most. NATO should present a concrete plan and concrete ways to respond to cyber attacks.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, I am happy to support the report – this very timely report that we have today. During the debate I heard a really rather remarkably daft remark, and it was that nation states have to be given the means and equipment to defend their cyberspace – their cyberspace – something which by definition has no borders. And if we have something that by definition has no borders but is the public space, it is incumbent on cooperation and the economies of scale that we have through the European Union to contribute to that defence. It’s worth remembering that most military analysts regard a massive cyber-attack as the likely prelude to warfare, and it is in fact alternative warfare. Those who seek to exclude the United Kingdom from future security arrangements will in future be seen as what they are – Putin’s useful idiots.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: – The first item on the agenda is the debate on the basis of statements by the Council and the Commission on the independence of the judiciary in Poland (2018/2761(RSP)). Let me inform you, first of all, that it will not apply to this debate, the procedure for an incidental request for the use of the word ('catch the eye') or that of the 'blue card'.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it is not the first time the Council has been asked to intervene in this House on the situation in Poland. This shows again that the protection and promotion of rule of law – including its core element, the independence of the judiciary – is a constant endeavour. It requires unwavering attention and efforts across different policy areas. Common values, such as human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights, are the cornerstone of the European Union. Each Member State must therefore respect, protect and promote them. The Bulgarian Presidency, and indeed all of us, agree that the protection of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in our Union cannot be taken for granted. The Commission triggered, on 20 December 2017, the procedure foreseen by Article 7(1) of the Treaty on European Union. This procedure is designed to assess if there is a clear risk of serious breach by Poland of the values referred to in Article 2 of the Treaty.  The Council is regularly updated on the outcome of the dialogue between Poland and the European Commission. The dialogue is ongoing, and the final assessment has not yet been presented. The issue is on the agenda of the upcoming General Affairs Council meeting on 26 June. At this stage, I cannot prejudge and draw conclusions as regards the next step. The Presidency has acted, and will continue to act, as an honest broker considering all circumstances and positions. Let me conclude by saying that the issues raised in the debate go to the heart of our commitment to this Union. We therefore trust that all sides will act responsibly and constructively to reach an outcome that leaves no doubt about our core values.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: (First Vice-President of the Commission). – Mr President, I will have to ask your indulgence because I cannot deliver my message in five minutes, because I want to give Parliament exactly the same information that I have given to Council. So might it take a bit longer, and I do apologise for that. The last time we discussed the issue was on 12 February, and I thank the Parliament for the wide support for the Commission’s actions expressed in the resolution adopted on 1 March. Let me now give you an update on the current situation and developments which took place during the last months. First, a number of exchanges between the Commission and the Polish authorities took place at different levels. In particular, I travelled to Warsaw on 9 April, where I met the Polish authorities and members of the judiciary. On 3 May, I met with Foreign Minister Czaputowicz in Brussels. This meeting was followed by further technical exchanges on the new amendments by the Polish Parliament. On 16 May, President Juncker met with Prime Minister Morawiecki at the informal Leader’s meeting in Sofia. Now what about the concrete measures taken by the Polish authorities? Three laws were adopted in April amending the law on the Supreme Court, the law on ordinary courts organisation and the law on the National Council for the Judiciary. A fourth law was adopted by the same on 10 May. I welcome the change of the law, which provides now for a uniform retirement age for female and male judges, now fixed at 65. Also, the amendment on the assistant judges goes in the right direction. I also welcome the fact that there has been a willingness on the side of the Polish authorities to amend the laws on a number of other issues. However, I regret to inform you that, overall, and despite all of these legislative changes, key concerns which the Commission identified in the Reasoned Proposal remain unaddressed. I can summarise the situation as follows. First, despite the new amendments, the discretionary power given to the authorities in charge of deciding on the prolongation of the judicial mandates of Supreme Court judges and of ordinary court judges remains a key concern from the point of view of upholding the principles of the separation of powers and judicial independence. The current judges still have no right to serve their full term as originally established. Judges affected by the lowered retirement age cannot simply notify their intention to continue to adjudicate, together with a health certificate, and continue to work. The President of the Republic has wide discretion to decide on the prolongation of Supreme Court judges’ mandates. There are no specific criteria and there is no judicial review of his decision. Whilst the transfer of the power to decide on the prolongation of ordinary courts judges to the National Council for the Judiciary is a step in the right direction, this is undermined by the politicisation of the National Council for the judiciary. In addition, there is a very wide discretion, and again – sadly – no judicial review. Second, the risk of creating irreparable damage fully remains. On 3 July, 27 out of 72 Supreme Court judges will face the risk of being forced to retire. As you may know, the current Supreme Court judges were asked to declare their intention to remain in the court by 4 May. 13 judges reacted in one way or another to the new prolongation regime. Some judges submitted a formal declaration requesting prolongation of their mandate, whilst other judges made a general statement that they are fit and ready to continue to occupy their posts without making a formal declaration requesting prolongation, due to the unconstitutionality of such a procedure and its humiliating character. In its opinion, the Supreme Court explicitly stated that the lack of declarations of the other 14 judges cannot be identified with the lack of their will to further adjudicate. The situation of the First President of the Supreme Court is also very worrying. She is affected by the new lowered retirement age, and her mandate of a six-year term of office would be prematurely terminated two years early, despite the fact that it is the Polish Constitution itself which sets the period of her term of office. A forced retirement of these Supreme Court judges would constitute an irreversible violation of the rule of law. The Commission is at present examining this issue. Third, the reforms brought forward have only served to underline the crucial role of the new National Council for the Judiciary, yet there has been no corresponding increase in the judicial influence over the election regime of the judges’ members of the Council, so it still does not comply with European standards. Also, no remedy is foreseen to address the premature termination of the mandates of the former judges’ members established in the Constitution. The politicisation of this body that has occurred undermines its role as an effective safeguard of judicial independence. Fourth, I would like to recall that the new legislation offers no solution for those judges who have already been concretely affected by the reform measures contested by the Commission. I am referring to the Court Presidents dismissed by the Minister of Justice. I am referring to ordinary court judges already forced to retire by the lowering of the retirement age, including female judges subject to the provisions that are in violation of EU anti-discrimination law – and by the way, now they have announced they will change that: no misunderstanding on that. I am also referring to judges’ members of the former National Council for the Judiciary whose constitutional mandate was prematurely terminated. Fifth, recent changes do not eliminate the broadness of the criteria governing extraordinary appeal. They remain almost the same. In particular, they still refer to social justice, albeit in a different wording. The Venice Commission explicitly criticised such references. Also, the 20-year reach of the extraordinary appeal has not been eliminated, which means that the extraordinary appeal could result in the repeal of final judgments dating back to October 1997. A new condition was introduced, which aims at avoiding the extraordinary appeal resulting in the repeal of judgments infringing international obligations. This condition lacks real impact, as such repeal is nevertheless possible if justified by principles or rights established in the Polish Constitution. This could even justify, for example, the repeal of final judgments by Polish courts applying EU law as interpreted by the case law of the Court of Justice of the EU. Sixth, also other key issues underlined in the recent proposal and the fourth rule-of-law recommendation have not been addressed. As to the disciplinary regime, new provisions render it in practice highly possible for current Supreme Court judges to participate from the start as judges in the Disciplinary Chamber. The three Constitutional Tribunal judgments of 2016 remained to be published as such, without any additional qualifications about their legality from the legislative or executive powers. They have been published now, but with a disclaimer that they are, and I quote: ‘findings delivered in breach of law’. No legislative changes were made to address the concerns expressed in the recent proposal in order to restore the independence and legitimacy of the Constitutional Tribunal. Sadly, the Commission can only conclude that the four new laws adopted in April and May are not by themselves sufficient to remove the existing concerns and are not sufficient to eliminate the clear risk of a serious breach of the rule of law. The measures the Polish authorities have continued to implement over the past six months have already created damage and are continuing to do so. After the Constitutional Tribunal and the National Council for the Judiciary, it is now the Polish Supreme Court which is at risk of coming under political control. Last week, the Commission therefore asked the Council to organise a formal hearing of Poland in the context of the Article 7(1) TEU procedure. Finding a solution urgently is a matter of common interest for all Member States and all EU institutions. It is the Commission’s sincere hope that Poland will now urgently address the key concerns identified by us. In particular, it is indispensable that urgent action be taken by the Polish Government to address the situation of the Supreme Court judges before 3 July, because that is when the decisions about the retirements become final. I will travel to Moscow on Monday to continue the dialogue with the Polish Government in an attempt to find solutions for the issues I’ve just outlined. (Interjection from the floor, off mic: ‘You said Moscow’ and other comments off mic, to which Timmermans reacts by saying: ‘That is an incredible mistake – that has never happened to me before. I do apologise. Sir, if you knew anything of my personal history, you would not have made that remark.) As I said, I will travel to Warsaw on Monday to talk to the Polish government. You know the Commission is the guardian of the Treaties. That is our role. But we do this in a cooperative sphere. I continue to believe that it is through dialogue that we need to solve these problems. But I also continue to believe that dialogue needs to lead to concrete results so that we can remove the threat to the rule of law and restore the independence of the judiciary.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today, the European Parliament, standing up for an independent judiciary and a constitution, is on the side of Polish citizens, and my vote should be a warning about the fate of Poles and Poles if the dismantling of the rule of law is brought to an end. Because these are institutions that guarantee freedom, which protect against abuses of power, and if they are lacking, you are vulnerable to the machine of the state. Poles know this, whose personal data was written down by a police officer only because they asked awkward questions to one of the ministers. This is known by a young man who unhappily appeared on the route of a column of government cars, and now is blamed for the crash of a government limousine. Anyone who enters into a court dispute with a neighbour will find out if the neighbour belongs to the ruling party. We also know what a misfortune political interference in the judicial system can be. The case of Thomas Command. The then Minister of Justice, today at the monuments, found him guilty in advance, as a criminal. Fast process. Annuity. After eighteen years in prison, it turned out that he was a completely innocent person. Fortunately, he is in the wild. The protection of independent courts is the protection of ordinary people. But there is more, because it is also the credibility of the Polish judicial system in the European legal area, also in the common market, where it is necessary to be sure of investing and obtaining investments. And the truth is known. It is contained in the documents of the Venetian Commission, the UN Human Rights Committee, in all the bodies and expertise that Western democracy has set up to establish the rule of law in a country. Unfortunately, the Constitutional Court is a façade incapable of assessing the constitutionality of laws. Unfortunately, there are more and more presidents in the courts who are more and less independent and less independent. Unfortunately, the National Council for the Judiciary was formed from a party key. But there is the last bastion – the Supreme Court. Only it is already wooing, because in fact already on 3 and 4 July 4 can be replaced 40% of the composition of this court as a result of forced retirement. And this is the body that evaluates the validity of the elections, so this is an existential problem of Polish democracy. Hence the dramatic calls for an action to be made to the European Court of Justice or even the suspension of this law, which, for example, saved the only Białowieża Forest in Europe from devastation. We talk about this in the centenary of Polish independence. Then, after an extraordinary victory that stopped the Bolshevik storm on the outskirts of Warsaw (we call it the "miracle on the Vistula River", 1920), Marshal Piłsudski, addressing the Polish youth, said: "We have fought for the independence of your homeland, and you will live, work and rule in it. Remember. If you turn to the East, you will go back to culture and economics by a minimum of one century. If you turn to the West, poland will grow at least one age faster." So he left us in his will a definition of betrayal of the Polish ration of the state. He betrays the Polish right of state, as Targowica once did, he who wants to withdraw Poland back to the East again, who wants to weaken ties with the West, who wants to weaken the European Union. Telling the truth cannot be a betrayal. I expect a wave of hejtu, which will only confirm that I am telling uncomfortable truths. Defending the Constitution is a duty. Poland today needs constitutional patriotism, which is why, today, standing up for the Constitution, defending the independence of the courts, we stand up and insist on the rights of Poles and Poles. (A flurry in the room)

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Mr. Lewandowski, forgive me for interrupting you, but as there are those who are committed this afternoon to interrupt you. I warn you seriously: respect the shifts of speech. Don't interrupt.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Standing today in defence of the judiciary and the constitution, we rebuke the rights of Poles and Poles and their good future in the European Union.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, what I will say is also directed at the people of Poland. Let me be clear. Our political Group appreciates the substantial contribution of the Polish people to restoring democracy in the east of Europe. We see the enormous progress the country has made since. We are also aware that not all aspirations have been met and that many people feel left behind. We understand that some people are angry. We have to be concerned. And if we don’t deliver, more and more people will turns their backs against democracy. The current discussion on and in Poland is about the state of democracy. It is worrying to see the signs from your country. Democracy, which your nation was so admirably fighting for, is in danger. All of us have the right to insist that a Member State is adherent to its constitution. We have to know that our partners are predictable. In Poland, the Constitution is at stake. We are concerned about the independence of the judiciary – a key element of every democracy. We share this concern with relevant authorities such as the Human Rights Committee or the Venice Commission, renowned scholars and friends of Poland around the world. Our Group was satisfied that the Commission has activated Article 7, and in March, Parliament explicitly welcomed this decision and urged the Council to take swift action. They acknowledged that this action put the Polish government in negotiation mode. But the results are poor and more or less cosmetic. The recommendations of the Commission have not been fulfilled. The Polish government continued its so-called reform of the judiciary. Almost 40 per cent of the judges will be forced into early retirement, and procedural rules are fundamentally changed. In less than three weeks there could be no independent judiciary in Poland any more. If the measures enter into force as planned, a large number of sitting judges of the Supreme Court will see their tenure unconstitutionally extinguished, including the First President of the Court. In combination with an increase in the number of seats, this means that the government-controlled National Council of the Judiciary will be in a position to appoint a majority of the judges. This could mean the end of checks and balances in your country. We must not accept this. It is against the Polish Constitution and against the Treaties, and it is against the people of Poland, who gave their approval in referendums for this. The situation is serious and urgent and we are obliged to act now – and not later, when democracy could be already severely damaged. This is not the moment for short-sighted political manoeuvres. After all the experiences with the Council (sorry), we must not expect that the summit at the end of June will deliver any clear results. Therefore, we appeal to the Members of the Commission to fully stand behind its Vice-President Timmermans. The Commission has to take strong action before July. It must refer this case to the Court of Justice. To make it clear, dear colleagues: if we give up Poland, we give up Europe.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwa I wanted to start with something else, but maybe I'll start with a polemic with my colleague Janusz Lewandowski. Well, it is not as you say – these are not uncomfortable truths, and no one will persecute you for these uncomfortable truths. Unfortunately, we do not control the hejt, hejt happens, meets each of us. These are not uncomfortable truths. The Lord, simply, from exaggerated and isolated facts builds a certain narrative that has nothing to do with the country in which we both live. As for Mr Weidenholzer, one thing I wanted to say. I have recently visited your beautiful country and I can only say one thing: I can assure you that the rule of law in Poland, the separation of powers and everything we are talking about are no worse than in your country. So, although I appreciate your concern, I assure you that Poland is not very different from Austria in this respect. However, I now turn to the President. In your speeches at the end of that year (I myself listened to you in the LIBE Committee), you repeatedly regretted that the Polish Government was refusing to dialogue with the European Commission, suggesting a lack of goodwill and arrogance on the Polish side. This was not, in my opinion, a fair assessment. But, as we all know, the Polish government, after its reconstruction and change of prime minister, has since the beginning of the year made another attempt at intensive dialogue, seeking to reach an agreement with the Commission and, in our opinion, an unfortunate and unnecessary procedure for verifying the rule of law in Poland. But not only – and the President has said this – because the Polish government has come out in front of many of the Commission's demands, even if it considered them not very well-being, for example, there have been such demands on the age gap between men and women. The Polish has made significant changes and adjustments to the adopted regulations in recent times, among other things, weakening the possibility of influencing the organisation of the judiciary, strengthening the role of the National Council for the Judiciary and the President and not the Minister, publishing outstanding, but only archival, constitutional court verdicts, amending the rules on assessors, imposing additional conditions on the possibility of an extraordinary action, equaling, as the Commission wanted, the retirement age of judges of both sexes, etc. We could have constructed your speech quite differently so that you can talk about these compromises, not the differences. Poland has therefore done a great deal to reach an agreement and to take account of the Commission's reservations. Unfortunately, goodwill and a willingness to understand from both sides are needed to reach an agreement. It is regretable that the Commission represented by you does not want to show this goodwill and understanding. You probably think that, when you contact some of the legal circles and the opposition in Poland, you also have the support of Polish society in your actions. Mr Weidenholzer also seems to think that he is speaking on behalf of Polish and not only on behalf of extremely ideologised forces in Poland and beyond, for example in this Parliament, as is heard in the speeches. Nothing more wrong. All the data shows that the reforms undertaken by Law and Justice have great public support. In August 2007, 81% of Poles said they supported judicial reform. So that please do not rely here on Polish society, on Poles, as you are criticising here. The details can be criticised, but the need for reforms cannot be rejected. Poles know that this is not a violation of the rule of law, but a restoration of the rule of law, they know how the courts have worked so far, what their efficiency has been and what the quality and independence of their judgments has been. And now I will quote a non-Pole. Günter Verheugen, once the Eu Commissioner for Enlargement, recently said in an interview on one of the Polish portals: "In my opinion, the European Commission does not have the appropriate powers to deal with this issue. (...) Of course, he has the tools to do this and can use them. However, I believe', sorry, Mr President, that is Mr Verheugen's sentence, 'that he is doing it ineptly. Commissioners do not know what to do. They also have no idea what will happen", and that is also what we should take into account: the consequences of our actions. "I have," says Verheugen, "for all the parties to the dispute, one simple piece of advice – settle this dispute ... I am not an expert on these matters," he continues, "but I know it's not just me" and Polish colleagues obviously didn't know that "the justice system needs Polish be reformed because it doesn't meet modern standards. The question is different – are we based on double standards or on the same rules? In Europe," says Verheugen, "there are double standards, because Polish government is not out of these so-called mainstream." End quote. And finally, he added, very characteristically, "Europe lives in an age of hypocrisy." Very aptly, in my opinion. Indeed, it is the secret of polystyrene that that there are many countries in the Union that deserve much more, Mr President, your concern and attention. I can tell you once privately about which countries would be. The solutions adopted in Poland are used in other countries, as you know. And as far as the political impact on judges or the tripartite power is concerned, I encourage my Colleagues in the European Parliament to look more closely at their countries, such as colleagues in Germany, I see that they are here, I would ask you to pay attention to that. Then maybe hypocrisy will be a little less. A little less hypocrisy in this House and a little less hypocrisy in this debate. Another prominent European politician, Bundestag President Wolfgang Schäuble, recently said: "Looking at some of the discussions between Brussels and countries such as Poland and Hungary, but also the Czech Republic and Slovakia, I would like to advise you: let us not give the impression of arrogance. I understand that eastern European countries may sometimes feel that their arguments do not count." Now, to conclude: we, for our part, have done everything possible to put an end to this dispute, which is damaging to the Union. And now the Poles, for the most part, believe that the time for our concessions is over. We are therefore waiting with all peace and firmness for the commission and the European Council to move, and are, of course, ready to continue to inform and explain our position.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let me make three general remarks before I go into the issue of the complaint before the European Court of Justice.  First of all – and this has been said here before – we have no fight with the Polish people, because they are Europeans like us. We are all one, and we are just standing up for the principles that we have all signed up to. The interesting thing is that you just said that the eastern countries may have a view. Countries don’t have a view. In a democracy, within a country there is pluralism, something that you have difficulty recognising. My second general remark is that my group fully supports Commissioner Timmermans’ efforts to redress the situation in Poland and bring it back into the fold.  My third general remark: you were all shouting when Commissioner Timmermans by accident or by mistake referred to Moscow rather than Warsaw. But isn’t there a degree of hypocrisy there? Aren’t you also working very closely, for example, with Mr Steve Bannon? This is all on the internet. It’s all public knowledge. Mr Steve Bannon is clearly out to undermine the European Union and is also working with Mr Orban, who is one of the biggest supporters of Mr Putin. So this is all one big network. You all have the same agenda. So stop the hypocrisy because this is not about, let’s say, the retirement age of judges. What this is about is your party creating an authoritarian regime in Poland, and the Polish people deserve better than that.  (Applause) Maybe you could have the decency to hear me out just for once. It would be nice. The Treaties allow the Commission to bring a complaint against the reform law before the European Court of Justice – it has already been raised – and we would really urge the Commission to do that soon, before the deadline of 3 July. You have the power and the means to act, and you have the support of the majority of this House. This is urgent. The new law on the Supreme Court will enter into force on 3 July, in less than three weeks’ time. Everybody has already mentioned what the consequences will be. We have to avoid that, because otherwise we get what we saw in Hungary: the situation may have been redressed by Luxembourg, but by then a lot of judges had already been dismissed, and they never came back. That means that, in the end, there is still undue political influence on the judiciary. Since there are only a few weeks left, we would also urge the Commission to ask the Court of Justice for an interim measure to suspend the law until the case is resolved. So time is almost up, and we would ask the Commission to act now. We would therefore join all the people in Poland – NGOs, political parties, civil society –who have been calling for the Commission to take this step before the European Court of Justice. Why is this important? I am going to quote the President of the European Court of Justice, who in a speech said, ‘Judicial independence is the bedrock of our democracies, be it at national or European level. I would go as far as to say that judicial independence is part of both our common heritage and of our very identity as Europeans’. The effective protection of EU rights requires that the competent national court is isolated from any political pressure, and if it’s not, it means that the whole European judicial fabric no longer works and that there are big holes in there. We have already seen the Celmer case, in which an Irish judge refused to extradite a Polish citizen and did not respond to a European arrest warrant, but this will go further. We are talking about more and more connection, for example, of databases; we are talking about e—evidence; and we are talking about the European evidence warrant. All those instruments will not work – not just in Poland, but in the whole European Union – because, if you remove one part of the chain, then the whole chain will fall. So this is essential. But I would still like to urge the Commission not to focus only on the judiciary, but also to look at the rights of women and freedom of the media. I am also very concerned about the attempts of the government to exert control over the media. The integrity and independence of the advertising and measurement markets are crucial in this context. Poland has actually dropped from number 18 to number 58 in the world press index out of 180 countries. That should tell you something. So, all in all – and to finally also respond to your accusation that we are applying double standards, that may or may not be the case – I think it is an argument, Commissioner Timmermans, to quickly come forward with this general mechanism for the rule of law that applies equally in all the Member States so that we can easily rebut the accusation that was just made.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is first and foremost a union of values, a community of values centred on the equal dignity of every human person. To best protect these values, we have chosen a political regime, democracy. A democracy that is now being called into question at the very heart of the Union. Democracy is not just about universal suffrage. However, the electoral system must allow a fair representation of society in all its diversity. Citizens must be freely informed by an independent press. However, the bulwark of the separation of powers must be held against all abuses. It is precisely on this front that the Polish government that came out of the 2015 elections openly defies our common values. He took political control of the judiciary and is now attacking the Supreme Court, the last of which remained independent. We welcome the action taken by the Commission, which has not hesitated to trigger the procedure to protect the rule of law against Poland. But we must recognize that, to date, the results are meagre and that most of the measures in question remain in place. The Polish government also knows that it can count on its allies in the Council, in particular Mr Orbon's Hungary. And Mrs Panayotova, Bulgaria's absolute timidity raises the question: is it an embarrassment or a tacit complicity? Still, time is running out. If nothing is done, on July 3, many of the Supreme Court's justices will be dismissed, paving the way for the government to appoint a majority of judges in its hand. Together with our Polish friends, Mr Timmermans, we have written to you asking you to use all means in your possession to prevent this fait accompli. On behalf of all Poles committed to our common values, on behalf of all democrats, I reiterate this call to you today: urgently refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the Union. Beyond the Polish case, the judiciary is threatened in its essence in several EU states. It is not only in Poland that it is the subject of attempts to submit to the executive, and a submissive justice opens the way to all abuses of power.  Elsewhere, budget cuts, brutal or lashed, paralyze the judiciary in its primary mission, to deliver justice. Is it still a question of justice when years elapse between a crime or a misdemeanour and its punishment? Is it still a question of justice when citizens no longer turn to justice for financial reasons? Finally, in the name of counter-terrorism, Mr Timmermans, it has become common to put the judiciary out of the way. While no attack has ever been committed because a judge would not have issued a warrant in time, again, the door is open to all abuses. I invite you, Mr President, to exercise your mission as guardian of the treaties and our fundamental values without weakness or favouritism. No government, and I stress this, is no government, which is suspect, and I conclude Mr President, but none can be spared from your surveillance. What is at stake here is a fundamental element of our democracies and, as you say yourself, democracy is never an irreversible achievement.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in March, Parliament approved the Commission's decision to activate Article 7(1). There are now persistent rumours that part of the Commission, concerned about concerns in the Council, is prepared to suspend the decision. The risk, in the event of a freeze, is that the Eu ropean Union will appear unarmed in the face of degeneration of the Rule of Law within it. In that case, it is better not to activate Article 7 at all, than to admit so openly a possible inability to act.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: On behalf of the EFDD Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I look forward to today's next debate on Poland. It bares hypocrisy, hypocrisy, repeatedly mentioned today, and hypocrisy. I hear that polish sovereignty is despised here and the Polish state and Poles are not respected. According to opinion polls, half of Poles misjudged the actions of the justice system. These were the days when judges at tusk's services tracked down internet users criticizing the then power. Then, Mr Timmermans, you remained silent when Poland was governed by a pro-EU agreement under the dictatorship of Brussels, which turned the leading role of Soviet Russia into the leading role of the European Union. You are worried about democracy and the rule of law, and it was in this House that a Member who pursued his right to freedom of expression was wrongfully punished. You may disagree with Mr Korwin-Mikke, but it turned out that you do not respect the right to freedom of expression. Right-wing journalist Tommy Robinson has been imprisoned in the UK for reporting on court hearings into mass rapes committed by immigrants. I will not prolong my speech by quoting examples. They are sufficiently familiar with everything that they have dealt with Polish in any way, but as soon as I hear demands from them to get rid of their sovereignty after the debates on Poland, I have to ask myself what exactly is going on. Is it about democracy and the rule of law, which in Poland is not under threat? Are you talking about prestigious matters? Or is it impossible to deprive Polish of the remains of freedom, which Poland cannot deprive?

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: On behalf of the ENF Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This debate, like several previous similar ones, says very little about the state of affairs in Poland. On the other hand, it speaks very eloquently and says a lot about the state of the European Parliament and the European Union. The Union remains focused on taking away further attributes of sovereignty from national states. Poles, like all other nations, do not have to have the best governments and the best courts at all. I would like that to be the case, but it doesn't have to be. Instead, they must be guaranteed that no one from the outside will impose something that they rejected in a democratic vote. How unequal, how unfair is the treatment of Polish recently showed the case of criticism of the Polish Constitutional Court. There has been a lot of criticism here. Yet for years no one has raised, for example, the issue of the functioning of the Constitutional Tribunal in The United Kingdom. And there is no Constitutional Court at all, and the United Kingdom can function to its liking, and Poles do not grant this right! Moreover, The United Kingdom does not have a constitution at all, and somehow the European Union does not mind it, and allows the British to function to their liking. And poles do not grant this right! Poles want to have the right to decide on the functioning of their homeland without external interference. And I defend this right of my own people. Criticising Polish in such a way that one party is supported against others is an unacceptable and scandalous interference in the internal affairs of Polish. That is why the Union is increasingly seen as an 'Anti-European Union'. Lessons have to be learned from this, because it is really a misfortune. This is the road in a very bad direction.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Of course the Lord is right. There is no debate here, only a series of pre-prepared readings. But here is not to be surprised. The ruling Left has a long tradition of disciplining defiant nations. As soon as an election in a country doesn't like it, as soon as the results of democratic elections don't like it, it always tries to kick it in the table and undermine it. You just lost the elections in Poland and agree with that. Finally, stop waiting, because what you are doing here is pathetic.  But of course that's not how we made the appointment, right? It is not for such democracy that we fought here to win not those who were to win, right? So the agreement is that every time a country deviates from the predetermined rate, the others will shake it until it returns to that course. Because those who are now demanding intervention in Poland are also afraid that they will lose the elections at home, and expect that then grateful colleagues from the Platform with them will destabilize the situation until they return to power. This is the mutual adoration system that is currently being used in our country. I am not a supporter of either party or the other. I think it's one putty for us, whether piS rules or platform rules, but I don't allow such interference in my country's affairs.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: (first Vice-President of the Commission). – Mr President, part of democracy is letting other people speak when they have the floor. The Polish people decided to join the European Union. The Polish Government signed the Treaty on European Union, it was ratified by the Polish Parliament, elected by the Polish people, and that Treaty comes with rights and obligations. (Applause)  One of the obligations in the Treaty on European Union, described in Article 2, is to respect the values of the European Union and fundamental rights. One of these elements is the rule of law, and the rule of law cannot exist if you do not have a separation of powers and an independent judiciary. (Applause) This is not an obligation that has been thrust from the outside on the Polish people and Polish nation. This is an obligation that the Polish nation went into with their eyes open after a popular vote – I think there was a referendum, if I’m not mistaken – and this obligation was taken upon the shoulders of the Polish people and Government and they execute that obligation. The fact of the matter is that the Commission is the guardian of the Treaties, and if we believe that there is a problem with Member States executing their obligations, we have to speak up. The world championships will start tomorrow – you cannot play a game of football without a referee to make sure that the rules are applied. If the referee is ignored or doesn’t apply the rules, you can no longer play football – the game will not happen – and that is the same with the European Union. We are a rule of law— and treaty-based organisation and we demand respect for the rule of law by all members of that organisation. That is not imposing – that is doing what was agreed and what was voted for, etc. (Applause)  In that context, the European Commission absolutely does not dispute the right of the Polish Government to reform the judiciary, and there might be very good arguments to reform the judiciary if it is slow, for instance, or if it is not delivering the results people expect from it. But in reforming the judiciary, you still need to respect the independence of the judiciary. If you believe that through putting the judiciary under political control, you can make it a better judiciary, you are wrong and you are violating your own obligations under the EU Treaties, and that is the core element of our discussion with the Polish Government.  Let me be clear: we do not dispute the right of the Polish Government to reform its judiciary, but in doing so, it should not infringe upon the independence of the courts, upon the independence of the judiciary. I put before you today our very concrete concerns. I’ve been very specific – that is why it took me some time, and that is probably also why I made that mistake. But when we do this, we do this in good faith. We want to have this dialogue – that is why I am travelling on Monday to Warsaw. That is, in my opinion, very important because I hope we can find a solution. It is true what you have said, sir, that with the new prime minister, a new era started – because this prime minister is willing to at least talk to us and discuss with us and look for ways out. But where I do not agree with you, sir – this is not horse trading. We are not talking about ‘you give a bit here’ and then ‘you give a bit there’ – we’re talking about the independence of the judiciary and the rule of law, and the Commission is just trying to maintain standards and wants to help Poland avoid a systemic risk to the rule of law. That is our duty, I am bound to that duty, I will do my utmost, and – frankly – I have been trying for two and half years. You can’t fault the Commission for not trying to find a way out through dialogue. I’ve listened very carefully to Parliament today, I’ve taken careful note of your remarks, I will also inform the Prime Minister when I seen him on Monday of your remarks, and I hope we can then find a solution together, but if we cannot find a solution, the Commission will have to stand firm on these issues.  Once again, it is not an imposition from the outside – it’s just holding a Member State to the agreement they entered into in freedom and ratified in freedom in their Parliament. Pacta sunt servanda – this applies to all of us. (Applause)

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me assure you once again that the Presidency and the Council as a whole attach great importance to upholding the rule of law and the separation of powers. They are at the heart of our principles and values. We believe that the dialogue should continue and we very much hope for a positive outcome. As I mentioned during my intervention, the issue will be on the agenda of the General Affairs Council on 26 June. I am not in a position to state more at this stage, because I speak as Presidency of the Council and therefore in the name of all its Member States. The Council will continue to follow this debate closely, and personally I can assure you that I paid particular attention to the views expressed here today during this debate.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Today's parliamentary speeches (Lewandowski, Verhofstadt) have been accused of alleged links between Law and Justice and Kremlin Russia. It's bizarre. In the first case, we are dealing with a former EU Commissioner who was actively involved in the 2011 campaign of a close power camp in Poland, in many respects closely related to Kremlin policy. In the early days of the Civic Platform government in 2007, there was a turn in policy towards Russia, the lifting of a legitimate Polish veto against the EU-Russia agreement, the conclusion of an unfavourable agreement with Gazprom, a further deepening of relations after the Smolensk disaster leading to the conclusion of an interstate agreement with the FSB, and a visit by the Polish State Electoral Commission to Moscow in May 2013 for consultations with the Russian electoral commission.  Mr Verhofstadt has a separate history of cooperation with the Kremlin, to which I will fully report at a different time. However, I would like to make it clear to both of you: My views on the Kremlin's actions are known, they do not meander, as in the case of both Lords. I am blacklisted by Putin. I am a co-worker of President Lech Kaczyński and President Jaroslaw Kaczynski, in whose government I was a minister. I do not wish to offend those who should remain silent, ashamed of their attitude towards Russia from the past. In this context, Timmermans' announcement to go to Moscow sounds particularly ironic.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – It had to become clear to the European Commission and the democratic governments of the Union that the 'Orban pattern' was contagious. This is reflected not only in the abusive use of power and in undemocratic reforms, but also at the level of communication. In Poland, the populist Law and Justice Party took over the Constitutional Court by legal administrative means when it came to power. They did so even without a constitutional majority. This was the key to the success of their further reforms. Then they began to systematically take over the media. And in 2017, with the retirement of judges and other legal means, they began to take over the judiciary. Let us not forget that in Hungary, it is yp'an example of how András Baka was removed from the head of the Supreme Court, without consequence. The initiation of the first EU Article 7 procedure has put a little stall on the Polish government, but it has not fundamentally deterred them: following Orban's pattern, they are trying to stall with communication tricks and a few false modifications. However, this is all a sham. While the EU digests and negotiates amendments with the government, a series of new judges are elected and fired. The European Commission and democratically functioning governments must realize that, together with the gradual attempts to undermine the rule of law and inaction, it is a lethal combination of democratic values, and that the Commission must as soon as possible go to the Court of Justice and ask for polish measures to be suspended before irreparable action is done.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Written. – Despite the European Commission's decision to trigger Article 7 against Poland, the situation with regard to the rule of law is still very worrying. If it is up to the Polish Government, a law will come into force in July allowing dozens of supreme court judges to be replaced. That's why there's not much time left to talk. The European Commission and European governments must now show decisive action to prevent such undemocratic measures from being taken by an EU Member State.  The European Commission should not make a political joust of it, but must stick to the facts and intervene legally through infringement proceedings before the European Court of Justice. In any case, all means must be used to stop the mass dismissal of the Polish Supreme Court, as it will be very difficult to reverse this measure in the future.  The judicial systems in Europe are so interconnected that one weak link can shake the whole system. That is why it is not only in the interests of the Poles that these measures be stopped, but of all Europeans who must be able to rely on a fair judiciary.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on humanitarian emergencies in the Mediterranean and solidarity within the European Union (2018/2768(SDR)). Ladies and gentlemen, this debate comes at a particularly complicated time. The immigration emergency requires an immediate reaction from the European Union. The problem cannot be solved at national level, nor can it be solved by disputes between Member States. Polemics, contrasts and confrontations only risk alienating the solution to the problem. If we look at what will happen in the next few years, we cannot fail to decide very quickly what to do. In 2050 there will be two and a half billion Africans. If we do not act on climate change, against terrorism, against poverty, against drought, against famine and against poverty in favour of peace, we will have biblical migrations. There will not be thousands of people moving from Africa, there will be millions of people moving from Africa. And we continue to waste time, the Member States continue to discuss with each other without finding a solution. The European Parliament, which represents half a billion European citizens, has approved a reform of the Dublin rules which can be an excellent basis for comparison between the Member States, because we have not made a weak choice, but we have combined firmness and solidarity. So it's a positive choice. We are prepared to compromise and to reach agreements, but the next European Council cannot be left without decisions, because the whole structure of the European Union is at the end of it. What is at stake here is not the question of 'immigration yes, immigration no, what kind of immigration', what is at stake is the survival of the entire European Union. Let us be very clear: the Member States alone cannot solve the problem. So we need a short-, medium- and long-term strategy. I believe that in the short term it is to stop migratory flows, in the medium term to create a Libyan state that can be a partner of Europe and, in the long term, a strategy that must also be an important part of the next multiannual budget of the European Union for more investment on the African continent. The European Parliament will not give up on playing a leading role. We have worked hard – I thank all the political groups – there are concrete proposals and we demand that these proposals be examined by the Member States.  On Monday of next week we will be in Vienna to meet the next Austrian Presidency. I intend to make the positions of the European Parliament stand up to Prime Minister Kurz and I will reiterate this position to the Council when I take the floor. It is my intention to go to Niger to send a positive message to that part of Africa about Europe's intentions. If I am authorised, I will also go to Libya to follow up the European Parliament's mission and the document approved by the European Parliament. No one can say that this Parliament has not been at the forefront of trying to solve the problem of immigration, but we cannot give up on solving the problem. That is why I strongly urge the Commission and the Council to act. The polemics between states – those who are tougher, those who are most responsible – are of no use. It is only small slats that do not help to solve a historical problem, which creates great social alarm and which really risks causing harmful effects on the whole of the European Union. That is why, Commissioner, Madam Representative of the Council, I would ask you to take this Parliament's request very seriously. We do not want to remain silent, we do not want to play the role of the handcarte, we want to be protagonists in solving a historic problem for the European Union. We are now listening to the words of Mrs Monika Panayotova on behalf of the Council.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, over the past few days we have watched with great concern the developments in the central Mediterranean Sea and yesterday I heard your concerns on the situation. From a humanitarian point of view, it is extremely disconcerting to see the same scene repeated again and again in which hundreds of persons risk their lives in flimsy rubber boats setting out from the Libyan shores. For many years Italy has received all migrants, regardless of where they were rescued, whether on the high seas or in the search-and-rescue zone of any neighbouring state. We should recognise the significant contribution by Italy, but Italy was not left alone. The EU has assisted Italy in terms of setting up the Frontex Joint Operation Triton, now Operation Themis, as well as Operation Sophia and a long list of measures to address the flow of migrants coming through North Africa. I refer here notably to the Malta Declaration of 3 February 2017, the implementation of which is ongoing and which was supplemented by the Commission Action Plan of 4 July last year. Italy has been very active in implementation on the ground, whilst Member State have contributed with funding for projects under the EU Trust Fund for Africa and by seconding experts to the EU agencies engaged in the maritime operational ‘hotspots’ and other migration-related activities in Italy. Our intensive efforts are reflected in the number of arrivals, which has decreased significantly. By 8 June this year the number of arrivals in Italy had gone down by 77% compared to the same period last year. However, the number of fatalities has not decreased to the same extent. This fact is a stark reminder of the desperation of migrants and the lack of opportunities they face in their countries of origin. Our strategy aims to address the root causes of migration by providing economic and social opportunities in the countries of transit and origin. I believe this is the right strategy. Apart from existing instruments to that effect – namely the European Union Trust Fund, the Partnership Framework, the Valletta Action Plan and EU Member States’ development assistance – more facilities have been developed such as the recently launched European Fund for Sustainable Development, which supports investment in Africa and in neighbourhood countries. The implementation of the European Investment Bank Economic Resilience Initiative is also very welcome. In the short to medium term, we should continue and intensify all the measures we have already undertaken in Libya and neighbouring countries. I can name some here but there is a whole range of initiatives: equipment and capacity building to enhance border management; the establishment of platforms to combat human smuggling networks; and support for international organisations to improve the horrific conditions in detention centres in Libya and promote voluntary return. We should also keep sustained pressure on the Libyan authorities and partners in the African Union to take a stance against the criminal activities that thrive in Libya and in the region, human smuggling and human trafficking of which migrants are so often victims. Our cooperation with the UN and the African Union has been very fruitful. Voluntary return of migrants from Libya was accelerated because of political engagement by African leaders and efficient groundwork by UN organisations. We need more of this kind of engagement from the region itself. The European Union cannot and should not do this alone. The fate of migrants in the Mediterranean Sea, even though we are fully engaged at our level, is not solely an EU responsibility. Coming back to the actual situation in the Mediterranean Sea, I believe that the different positions expressed by some Member States will need to be addressed in the Council. We need to find a solution that matches our common European values. We in the Council, in collaboration with all our partners, in particular Italy and the Commission, are pursuing this objective with vigilance.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: Membro della Commissione. – Signor Presidente, onorevoli deputati, volevo prima di tutto segnalare che sono d'accordo con Lei. Voglio anche ringraziare Lei e anche i gruppi politici di questo Parlamento per il loro sostegno. Il lavoro di questo Parlamento è importante per finire la riforma di Dublino in modo giusto ed efficiente per tutti gli Stati membri. La Commissione e il Parlamento lavorano insieme mano nella mano come sempre.   – Mr President, the events of the last few days concerning the Aquarius boat remind us of the gravity of the migratory challenge in the central Mediterranean and of its humanitarian implications.  We cannot turn our eyes away from what is happening, even after three years of progress in managing flows. We cannot afford to become complacent. What matters most is that people in a desperate situation were saved and helped. That is what counts – ultimately and always. I want to be clear on that. I will not enter into any blame game today. Everybody needs to take up their responsibilities and play their role in solidarity. In the case of the Aquarius boat, I welcome that a solution was found and I commend the decision of the Government of Spain. I would also like to commend Italy and many other Member States that are upholding our values and taking up their share of European responsibility for many years now. Just remember where we were three years ago and where are we today.  We should not lose sight of the efforts these Member States have made in the past and continue to make. Indeed, while the Aquarius will disembark in Spain, more than 900 people were embarked this morning in Catania, Italy. So Italy is continuing to take up its responsibilities. Our central objective is – and I think we all agree on this – to avoid people fleeing from poverty, persecution or violence in the first place, putting their lives at risk by embarking on perilous journeys. It puts people’s lives at risk. It creates tensions within our societies, as shown by the strong reactions on social media.  To this end, our action is much more effective if it starts before they embark on these journeys on the other side of the Mediterranean. On this we have already achieved results, and we have to continue strengthening our cooperation with countries of origin and transit in order to address root causes of migration and avoid people falling into the hands of smugglers’ networks.  Let me give you a few examples. Thanks to our good cooperation with the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), we have helped more than 25 000 migrants to leave Libya and voluntarily return to their countries of origin, and we have supported the evacuation of 1 474 migrants in need of international protection from Libya to other countries, including Niger, in view of their resettlement as refugees. Resettlement should be the normal way to Europe for those who need protection.  Finally, we continue to train the staff of the Libyan coast guard in order to enhance its capacity to carry out search—and—rescue operations at sea, which has so far resulted in 16 000 migrants rescued. We are strengthening our monitoring after training in order to ensure full respect of human rights. We also financially support Egypt, Morocco and Tunisia so that they can better control their borders and fight smugglers’ networks. Protecting the external borders is essential on both sides of the Mediterranean. Protecting our European external borders is and will remain among our top priorities. We have made significant progress since the establishment of the European Borders and Coast Guard, but we need to continue. We proposed yesterday to almost triple funding for migration and border management to EUR 34.9 billion for the period between 2021 and 2027, compared with EUR 13 billion in the previous period. This comprehensive approach delivers results.  The peak of arrivals over the past few days should not overshadow the progress that we have achieved in significantly reducing the migratory pressures in Italy. This year, arrivals to Italy have dropped by 78% compared with last year. So far, 13 000 have arrived this year, compared with 90 000 last year. But when migrants engage in dangerous, perilous journeys in the Mediterranean, our humanitarian imperative to help people in distress should come first. To truly prevent that situations such as what happened with the Aquarius, we cannot be satisfied with ad hoc solidarity. We need a comprehensive approach and rules to ensure that the responsibility of assisting migrants does not fall on the shoulders of just a few Member States. The Commission has used – and will continue to facilitate – an open and frank dialogue and it will continue to find durable solutions based on solidarity and responsibility. Migration is definitely not a challenge for one or a handful of Member States, but for the European Union as a whole and all its Member States. Our migration policy can only succeed if we work together in a spirit of solidarity and sincere cooperation and, most importantly, with trust. It will not succeed if each country proceeds with unilateral and uncoordinated initiatives or feels authorised to only look at its own national situation and interests. We are therefore looking forward to continuing to work closely with Italy and the new Italian Government so that we can continue to manage migration flows on the central Mediterranean route. But as I said before, this is not just an Italian issue – we expect all the Member States to join forces in sharing the solidarity and responsibility and addressing this truly common challenge. This is the essence of all our efforts, whether it is saving lives in the Mediterranean or better protecting our shared external borders or coming to an agreement on any formal common European asylum system as part of the comprehensive approach on managing migration better. Only united will we stand. It is very important for us to understand that it is part of the legacy of this Parliament and of this Commission for the years to come because migration will be with us for many, many decades ahead. We have to be better prepared, more united and resolved to provide solutions, always having as a priority how to save lives and protect those who are in genuine need of protection.  (Applause)

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it is difficult not to be angry when we find ourselves in another summer, facing a situation that we warned would come. It is difficult not to be angry when we know that we can introduce laws on plastics and on litter, we can end roaming, we can even reform agriculture, but when it comes to migration, prime ministers remain stuck. Our message to the Council must be clear: leave no space for more raised fists and banging on tables, no more victorious hashtags, no more children born on the high seas, no more lives used to prop up the wannabe strongmen of Europe. Things must change. Now, in the immediate term, we must reform our Dublin system to one that balances responsibility with solidarity. We need to ensure that our borders are secure and our coast guards have all the resources they need. We must break – as has just been said – traffickers’ models. We must draw distinctions between those in need of protection and those seeking work. Those who need protection must be given it, but equally, those who do not must be returned quickly. On migration and borders, the budget has been tripled. This is welcome, but in the medium term, we need to think outside the box and look seriously into having EU-run disembarkation locations in safe third countries, with EU standards, where anyone saved from the dark sea can be disembarked immediately, rescued, vetted, processed in full recognition of their rights – by  EASO, for example – and either returned or resettled. We have the money to do it and we must find the will to do it. In the longer term, we must move from aid for Africa to investment which creates jobs and creates hope and allows for education and entrepreneurship to flourish. Let’s create a Union where Italy, Malta, Spain and Greece do not feel left alone to manage this; a system where desperate people in need of protection have a real chance, where children grow up to a future without fear. That is the Europe I want to see and that is the world I want my children to find.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, you will remember well that before Mr Salvini used human suffering to win some votes, Mr Renzi's government has already called for help in managing migration. Italy asked for help and no one gave Italy help. That's the truth.  Greece is receiving a large number of migrants. Spain is receiving a large number of migrants. And Member States cannot abandon Italy, Spain, Malta and Greece in managing migration, which must be common. And it must be, first, because you can't let people suffer in this way and because, besides, letting them suffer only feeds the worst gasoline, ignites populism, xenophobia and racism. And because the solution is European and we know it. All the time the Council is wasting, we are all wasting it, all of us who sit here with a certain dose of responsibility.  The action of the Spanish Government, which is an intelligent, supportive, humane and, indeed, legal action, not like Mr Salvini's. This action must serve as a revulsive for the Council to react. You guys react! The president told you, my colleagues told you. Approve the Dublin package once and for all, listen to this Parliament, resolve a situation which is only giving benefits to those who are against the European project.  We're letting people suffer. We are not solving the problem of migration and we are feeding anti-Europeans, xenophobes and racists. That's the result, then something you have to move.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened very carefully to the report by the Representative of the Council and the Commissioner and I have to say that my conviction has increased in relation to three fundamental points that are highlighted after the events of these hours.  The first is the issue of the great inability to tackle this problem definitively and structurally. We have heard a list of many measures, we have also listened to the multiplication of resources, but we have not listened to and we still do not listen to a single word about the desire to redistribute the large mass of migratory flows that arrives in a few countries.  This is the crux of the matter before us and until the European countries come into the perspective of ideas that need to be addressed in this area and give a clear answer, the risk is that linked to the great hypocrisy, the polemic of these hours, which is frankly embarrassing. Listening to soldiers on their borders to prevent women and children from entering into a polemic against other countries is genuinely inappropriate and totally wrong. This brings us to the third consideration, which is a paradox. I listen to so many speeches against anti-system parties in this House and we do not realise that the European institutions have had and are having the capacity to create the conditions for the growth of anti-system parties in all countries, even though they have positions of total opposition to them. In fact, those who ask for and have a tough attitude towards immigrants are growing, in order to be able to have the solidarity of redistribution, and those who, paradoxically, at the same time close their borders, having the same similar attitude, are growing.  I believe that Europe is facing a clear risk today. The desirability of one state or another is no longer in question, there is a question of whether Europe will have a future. And the immigration game is worth much more than economic, social and institutional matches. I hope that this enormous gravity will be realised.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for your words, because they are entirely what I think too and what common sense and knowledge of the situation means. The tragedy of the Aquarius is not an Italian problem, neither a French critic nor a Spanish solution: it is a comprehensive problem of the European Union. Nor is it a false solution that has been established with Libya, and I would like us to think of something: our relationship with the ghostly Fayez al-Sarrach government results in all migrants leaving Libya leaving the shores dominated by Fayez al-Sarrach. Crete is much closer to Libya than Pantelleria. No one leaves the territory of the Tobruk government, led by Jalifa Haftar. It's worth thinking and going from ideality to reality. An African solution needs to be established with local, national, tribal, African religious authorities, because what happens in the Mediterranean is not a rescue problem either, it is the last link in a tragedy that begins in Africa. And, therefore, if we are not able to establish a solution at source — originally – in Africa, all we will do is a humanitarian task, I would say to alleviating our consciences— of our aesthetic consciences — when we are eating and meeting, at lunchtime, some dead on the beaches of Greece or in the waters of the western or central Mediterranean. And that simply seems to me to be a philanthropic approach, rather I would say aesthetic, but not profound, which is what we need. Collaboration in Africa is needed, comprehensive action is needed in Africa and true European responsibility is needed.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, nothing, nothing can justify a country closing its ports to a ship full of humans in distress. Mr. Salvini used human lives to engage in political blackmail and, incidentally, electoral gesticulation. This is unspeakable.  Yet we understand and share the anger of the citizens of Italy, Malta and Greece, these countries on the front line of welcoming migrants, too often left to their own devices by other Member States.  From Salvini's Italy to Kurz's Austria, De Wever's Belgium, Macron's France, Orban's Hungary and Kaczynski's Poland, fortress Europe seems to have become the alpha and omega of a majority of European leaders. Under the guise of firmness and humanity, it is a matter of pushing back and containing from a distance, even if it means paying dictators or armed gangs to turn their country into an open-air prison. But let us face reality, the challenge of migration - as you said, Commissioner - will not go away. Between wars and persecution, hunger, climate change and economic exploitation, the causes that drive human beings on the path to exile remain burning.  If the heads of state and government, who often scoff at being leaders, bow to costly, inhumane and doomed answers, the European Parliament has taken a different direction, and like you, Mr President, I am proud to belong to an assembly that has managed to find a large majority to end Dublin's iniquitous system and replace it with a collective, responsible and united approach.  However, the politicians who sit here come from the same countries and belong to the same parties as the heads of state and government and their ministers. So tell me why what is possible for us here is impossible for them behind the closed doors of the Council? If Mr Salvini really seeks the solidarity of Europeans, he knows what he has to do: support Parliament's position in the Council. One thing is certain: by dehumanizing migrants to justify fortress Europe, it is our fundamental values that we are treading on. No one, no one is asking the European Union to take in the 65 million people displaced inside or outside their country! But Europe is far from taking its fair share in hospitality today.  We can, we must do more, and better. It is a question of justice, solidarity and responsibility. It is even more a question of ethics and humanity.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since 2012 Italy has been condemned three times by the Strasbourg Court for collective rejections by pro-establishment governments. Let us remember this, evoking the unfair closure of its ports at Aquarius. Malta's sins are being discussed in Italy. That is understandable, but Malta unfortunately does not adhere to the reforms of the SAR and SOLAS conventions on rescues at sea and considers that it does not have the obligations of signatories such as Italy. Still, Macron accuses Rome of cynicism, but cynically closes its borders with Italy. In criticising Rome we take these things into account. Above all, we take account of the paralysis of the dublin IV negotiations. The sleep of solidarity generates monsters almost everywhere in the Union.  That is why I support Verhofstadt's proposal: an appeal by Parliament, under Article 265, in the council's inaction. That is why I welcome the Italian Government's 'no' vote to the Bulgarian Presidency's proposals on Dublin IV.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Italy has never failed in its duty to save lives at sea. Even today, an Italian Coast Guard boat was welcomed in Catania, which rescued more than 900 people who were rescued in the Mediterranean. Since 2014, some 640 000 landings have taken place in Italy. The Aquarius affair has laid bare what we have been denouncing for some time, we have been saying for years. Italy is left alone not only in managing immigration once migrants arrive on Italian soil, which is also European soil, but also in search and rescue operations.  I would like to address the representative of the European Council, who says that the European Union has supported Italy with Operation Triton. We are talking about Operation Triton, which provided that Italy was the only host country of all landings. So you understand that, if we are talking about Dublin, which still imposes the principle that responsibility remains with the countries of first arrival, if we take another step backwards and see the search and rescue operations that have to be carried out with landings only in Italy, then let us ask ourselves a question, which I have not heard from anyone so far. : because those who have the right to international protection, because those fleeing war and persecution, because those who are forced to leave their country of origin must arrive in Italy or Europe illegally?  The greatest contradiction and hypocrisy that reigns in the European Union is the fact that we want, on the one hand, to combat illegal immigration and, on the other, not to offer a legal alternative. The fact that those forced to leave their country for war and persecution have to pay the traffickers and have to pay the smugglers. So if we really want to talk about reforming the common European asylum system, if we really want to talk about cooperation, if we really want to respect the provisions of the Treaties and Article 80 on the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, then let us start talking about a genuine European right of asylum, let us start talking about legal ways of accessing the European Union, let us begin to give the opportunity for those fleeing war and persecution to arrive legally and safely. , without being forced to embark and cross the Mediterranean in inhumane conditions, without necessarily being forced to pass through Italy as a transit country. Then we would have concrete solidarity in this case and not in words.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on immigration you have been ripping Italy off for so many years, and it is your fault and the governments of Letta, Renzi and Gentiloni that Italy has become Europe's refugee camp. In the last five years, 700 000 immigrants have landed in Italy and 80 % are illegal immigrants. What has Europe done to help Italy? Nothing! What have Malta, Spain and France done? Zero! On the contrary, France has waged war in Libya over oil and left waves of migrants to Italy.  President Macron and the French bullets, who today accuse Minister Salvini and the Italians of being responsible and vomiting, must be ashamed and apologise. We do not accept lessons from anyone, let alone Macron's France, which in 2018 rejected 10 000 migrants on the border with Italy. The patience of the Italians is over, over! Minister Salvini and the new government will stop the business of illegal immigration. We will close the ports and defend the interests of the Italians, not those of some oil tankers French or some billionaire who funds NGO ships to bring illegal immigrants to Italy.  Europe has two options ahead of it: to lend a hand to Italy and defend its external borders or to continue with the usual hypocritical policy of Macron and of this European Parliament and of this Commission. Time is almost over. If Europe really exists, strike a blow now, immediately, otherwise it will be silent forever.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
