text: Mr President, the 'barbarism' of desperate refugees and migrants seeking port is an implementation of European Union policy and a great demonstration of its hypocrisy. The result of the stability which the European Union is leaning on all the falls, its so-called surgical wars and interventions, it and its allies, are these cries. The denials of docking are a consequence of the policy of concentration in the first host country, the 'Dublin Regulation', the entrapment of thousands in squalid conditions on the Greek islands as a result of the unacceptable Agreement between the European Union and Turkey. This policy nourishes and reproduces reactionary government measures, miserable quota competitions by urban governments, nationalist racist poison. In conflict with the policy of the European Union and governments we require human reception and hospitality areas, freeing from the Greek islands and other gateways, for refugees to travel to their final destination countries. Strengthen the struggle of the peoples against the imperialist wars and the capitalism that gives birth to them, along with exploitation and refugees!

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to begin by saying that under any circumstances it is unacceptable for us to have tragedies in the Mediterranean Sea or in another region of access to Europe. And so the European Union must be prepared as a whole to rescue the shipwrecked and to help those in need, absolutely necessary.  Then second point. I clearly criticise the way Minister Salvini has referred to this issue, but no one will see me condemn Italy, because there is no doubt that the European Union has responsibilities for leaving Greece, Italy, Malta, to a lesser extent Cyprus, Spain, which are countries that are at the forefront of the humanitarian crisis and which have been very alone , both from a logistical point of view and from a financial point of view, to tackle this problem. And then of course, we have medium and long-term solutions and, in medium and long-term solutions, we have, first of all, the coast guard that should be greatly strengthened, humanitarian aid that could be greatly strengthened and we must of course have a strategic vision for Africa, and here I must say - and I wanted this to be in the background my main call for the medium term - , Chancellor Merkel proposed last week a Marshall Plan for Africa that could create development in the Mediterranean Basin and sub-Saharan Africa for the next 20 or 30 years.  Let's take this plan forward. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – I have always voted for President Tajani. He is a humane and decent fellow and a lot of what he said made sense. What worries me is that, if we don’t keep people out of Europe in general, we look weak. What will then happen is that more and more people will take the risk of dying crossing the Mediterranean to reach the rich European Union and – probably more so – the United Kingdom. People are queuing up in Calais to come across to England. They are not queuing up ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: blue-card answer. – My dear colleague, I was totally convinced that you were one of the best supporters – the main supporters – of global Britain, a Britain open to receive people from all across the globe. No Europeans, but for people from the other continents the doors are open: that is global Britain. So I’m very surprised by your question.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Mr President, recently I was in Libya with one Spanish colleague and one Italian colleague. I am very proud of the Members here today who are not running away from the problem, but are facing the problem. The Commissioner said one thing which I think we should all keep at the forefront of our minds – and something which was said to me in Libya – which is that the number of sea arrivals in Italy is the lowest since 2013, but that migration will not stop. It is a simple equation. You can run away from the problem all you want – some of the arrivals will go down and they are going down, not up – and people will make a political football of migrants and people will play a game between Member States. But remember: migration will not stop. At the forefront of our minds, we must retain the understanding that, here in this Chamber, we must show leadership. That requires us, in this window of opportunity, to go for Dublin IV, for all of those asylum files, and then to implement them and make them happen. This is not some sort of dream: it is the obvious imperative for this Chamber. I would say this, colleagues: if we do not have Dublin, we cannot have this game playing in the Mediterranean and people dying in Niger and Libya, as we in our committee saw. We have a responsibility. Migrants cannot not become the footballs of the Mediterranean. Dublin IV has to work. We must pursue humanity and we must pursue the management of migration. If we do not do this, then what is actually the future of the European Union? (Applause)

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this week we saw Italy's new xenophobic government, popping international law, close its ports to the ship Aquarius and its 629 passengers saved from the sea. And, we have seen how the new Government of Spain offered to host them. It is a noble gesture, no doubt, but we all know that with gestures we will not solve the problem in the background. The burden of the migrant and refugee crisis rests with the countries of the South. We need a fair and generous European policy with refugees, effective in its mechanisms and equitable among countries, which demonstrates that the Union respects the values on which it is founded.  This House must press the Council to stop blocking the reform of the Dublin Regulation. Pressure him with all legal means at his fingertips. And I say with everyone, all of them, including those provided for in the Treaties, because thousands of lives are at stake and Europe's honour is at stake.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: "blue card" question. I believe that Rule 165 of the Rules of Procedure, first paragraph, states that you cannot offend in this House, you cannot offend the Italian Government with the words 'xenophobic' that our colleague used. I would therefore ask you to act immediately in accordance with Rule 165, first paragraph, of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: "blue card" response. – I have no intention of going against the Rules of Procedure. What I'm rating is the actions of the Italian government. That's what I mean. It is a government that has manifested itself on the mouth of its president, and the Minister of the Interior has expressed himself with clear xenophobic expressions. That's what I meant, under no circumstances do I want to break the House Rules of Procedure.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, words such as 'invasion' are heard in this debate, while the numbers tell us that there is no invasion going on, or as a 'migrant business', a formula that then those who use it should also explain what it means.  Meanwhile, Parliament's proposal to reform Dublin is there, it is very ambitious, but as usual it is the selfishness of the Member States that is blocking it. This is where the concept of Europe is at stake, and today it is completely betrayed. We are in the Europe of selfishness where, if everyone thinks for themselves, on taxes, on work, on immigration and on foreign policy, Europe itself ceases to exist. We need a change, but it is not done with other tests of strength, adding selfishness to selfishness, as those who today sing victory saying that making the big voice serves as a neighborhood bullet. But what victory? Every state in Europe today has lost and gone if it continues to do so every day and if it continues to address the issue of migrants as a necessary evil to be restarted throughout its body. It is not an emergency, but it is a changing world and will continue to change. If, on the other hand, we want to be protagonists in this irreversible process, if we want to guide it and not end up crushed, then we must change too. We need a cultural revolution – and I hope that these words remind my friends of the 5 Star Movement of something – we need to change the rules that are not carved into the rock, but we must also, and above all, change our ideas.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I will still return for a second to Mr Pedicini and his reference to Rule 165. I would say that I did not find the disruption to the session which is stipulated in the rule that you referred to. Having said that, colleagues, Ladies and Gentlemen, I know that this is a difficult topic and a sensitive one. It can be heated, but I think that we should refrain from unnecessary strong language. That is a general comment without reference to anyone that has so far spoken, but the Chair would appreciate it if we would keep in the margins of solid European Parliament culture.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the women, men and mayors, starting with the Mayor of Naples, who took to the streets in front of the ports to shout: 'open ports!' I would like to thank them because they have made me a little less ashamed to be Italian and to be European.  I ask my colleagues in the 5-Star Movement, with many of whom I have worked together so many times in this European Parliament: how do you define it if not xenophobic who talks about 'parceling' about refugees who come to Italy? How do you call it who is shouting victory over a ship with 600 people on board, which is forced to reach Spain? How do you define it? Other than the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament! I would like to say that Salvini is an icon, he is an icon of racism growing up in this European Union. But we must not forget Libya and Turkey, with which the European Union has an agreement. Let us not forget Bardonecchia and Ventimiglia, to whom Macron evidently does not pay much attention. Let's not forget Ceuta... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Ms Forenza, you ran out of time. I would appreciate it if you would show respect both to the Chair and to your colleagues – once again, I think that this is difficult and sensitive and I can understand that there might also be domestic political aspects referred to, but I would really appreciate it if we could stay in the margins of a debate which is respectful for this House.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the first question I would like to put to my fellow MEPs in this House is: how many times in recent years have we discussed exactly the same thing? I do not want Commissioner Avramopoulos to do that, but your speech seems to be exactly recycled in the same words as he said three to four years ago, and absolutely nothing has changed. Indeed, today there is the novelty that, to the same things that are always said, is added the trend topic of the moment that is to say "Italian populist government, xenophobic Italian government", as someone said in a really disrespectful way.  But what has the Italian Government done? The Italian Government has done much less than all the other governments in the European Union, and I am not aware that the French government, Macron's pro-European government, was referred to by yourselves as a Nazi, xenophobic government for what it did in Bardonecchia with blitzes on Italian territory, where there were pregnant women and children. I am not aware that Macron was considered xenophobic for closing his ports or for what he does in Ventimiglia. And I am not aware that the Spanish Government, which was hot-refoulement, which is not what Italy did, has been referred to as fascist, Nazi, xenophobic, contrary to human rights and genocidal!  It did not happen, and then we begin to adopt the same yardstick and the same measure. What has happened in recent years is that Italy has been left alone by all the other States of the European Union. She was left alone to deal with an epochal phenomenon, a global phenomenon of a moving continent. It was logical that sooner or later someone, who may not be doing business on the skin of migrants, should have said: just cannot go on like this! So let us be serious and demand that all European states take their responsibilities, starting with France, which was the first to cause what happened in Libya... (The President cut the speaker off)  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Corrao, you said that Italy was left alone by all the other countries of the European Union. Is it true that Germany has taken in significantly more refugees than Italy? And is it right that Germany takes in 50 refugees a month outside the contingent specifically from Italy to help you?

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Mr Schwab, I think we are making some terminological confusion, because what you call 'migrants' are actually called 'refugees' and are those who have already been granted international protection status.  Those arriving in Italy are migrants who, because of Dublin, remain in Italy. So I say: it is all well and good to redistribute, let us ensure that the ships of NGOs that do an extraordinary job of saving lives, flying the German flag, instead of taking them to Sicilian ports, which is my region, and leaving them there where they are stuck for years, waiting to know what their fate will be, take them to Germany and then you decide whether they are entitled to asylum or not. All right?

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, Matteo Salvini was right to turn back the Aquarius: Italy can no longer continue to receive boats from illegal migrants. Migration submersion must stop. This refoulement is a warning. The European Union must stop being the gravedigger of the identity of the peoples of Europe. Commissioner Avramopoulos said on 8 June 2015 that his target was to take in 50 million migrants by 2060. The peoples of Europe are opposed to it. It is time to fight against smuggling networks and NGOs that are objectively their accomplices. The solution is not to introduce mandatory quotas for the relocation of migrants, as the Dublin IV project would like to do. The solution is to make agreements with the countries of departure to persuade them to detain or recover migrants who are trying to leave. The future of European civilization is at stake. Africa will double its population to 2.5 billion by 2050. If we do not show firmness now, our model of society will disappear under the blows of immigration, communitarianism and radical Islam. Congratulations Matteo Salvini for being the lookout for the future of the European Union!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I was looking at the timetable. We are behind schedule. We also have an extensive list for the catch-the-eye procedure, so from now on I am not in a position to bring in any blue card requests. I do appreciate your understanding.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, I will not abuse your time. I want to protest and I will leave in protest at the traitorous attitude of the Union and the Tsipras government in granting the name of my homeland Macedonia to Skopje.

name: David CASA
text: – Din it-traġedja whether għandna fil-Mediterran Sur President qiegħda, iktar ma jgħaddi ż-żmien, iktar tħalli l-pajjiżi tal-Unjoni Ewropea mifrudin. Sfortunatament, anke alleati kbar, bħal ma kien, għandhom jibqgħu, Malta to l-Italja. Jien niddejjaq nisma xi deputati, mill-Italja, pajjiż li jien tant inħobb, jgħidu affarijiet illi flok iressquna lejn xulxin biex nagħmlu l-battalja tagħna fl-Unjoni Ewropea, iva kontra min mhux qiegħed jagħti dan il-kontribut biex insolvu darba għal déjj din il-problema.  Mhuwiex sew, għandkom raġun, illi xi pajjiżi fl-Unjoni Ewropea ma għamlu assolutament xejn biex jgħinu lill-Italja, b'mod partikolari, naturalment lil Malta illi illi ilna s-snin kbar niffaèèjaw wièèna ma' din il-problema. Għandna diversi soluzzjonijiet, jien ngħid lill-Membri tal-Kunsill, għandna r-Regolament ta' Dublin illi rridu naraw kif jitranġa. Ma jistax ikun illi nħallu r-regolamenti kif inhuma llum. Għandna bżonn li l-Istati Membri kollha jaqsmu din ir-responsabbiltà. Għandna bżonn li jkun hemm èentri ta' applikazzjoni f'pajjiżi sikuri fl-Afrika dawn jiddeèiedu jitħallew jitilqu biex jiġu fl-Ewropa. Imma ejja naħdmu din il-battalja flimkien għaliex jekk ma nagħmlux hekk ħa jerġa' jkollna d-diżastri illi kellna sfortunatament fil-passat.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, two quick remarks. I would like to say to President Macron that if we have a government today that he does not like at all, and that I do not like either, and I would like to say to the other members of the Council that if we have this government here, perhaps it is also because of the policies that many states have made against Italy, not helping our country in past years. I would remind President Macron that three months ago I invited him to come to Bardonecchia and Ventimiglia to see what the situation was and still is today.  While I would like to ask my colleagues in the 5 Star Movement: where did you end up? Where's your humanity? You were collecting money for NGOs and today you are allowing NGO ships to stand in the middle of the sea because you have abdicated Mr Salvini's fascist policies! Finally, I would like to ask Minister Salvini: why is he not here? Why is it not here to take the European Parliament's proposal on the reform of the Dublin Treaty and bring it to the Council? This should be our country, as it has done in past years!

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, no Member State is here to give lessons to any other, after the massive catastrophe that is this refugee crisis. None. But there are things to be said: a country in the European Union cannot infringe international law. And what the Italian Government has done is to infringe international law and maritime law. And yes, Mr Salvini's statements are xenophobia. I don't know if anyone's going to sanction us for telling the truth, but this is the truth.  That said, why is Salvini in power? Because, of course, and I agree, Italy has been left alone; because it has been the policy of the European Union that has fostered such characters. And not all of Italy is Salvini. Of course we do. I am proud of Mayor De Magistris, in Naples, who has raised his voice these days, saying, "Naples does want to welcome you." And, therefore, we know that not all of Italy is Salvini, of course we do.  And we know that there have been many governments that have been insolidary. The previous Spanish Government has been very, of which it has been so much, and that is why we are very pleased that the current Spanish Government has taken a totally correct and supportive action that we welcome, because, for many years in Spain, cities have also been alone calling for this issue. Barcelona, in three years: 11,000 refugees served, in the face of the complete indifference of the Spanish Government. Therefore, we also know in Spain what it is like to have a government totally indifferent and contrary to host policies.  But the question to be asked here is: do we have to condemn the things that the Italian Government does, in contravenation of international law? Of course. But more Aquarius is coming. And when more come, what are we going to do? Are we going to keep this up? It is therefore very important to tell the European Council at the end of June to unlock the Dublin reform, to launch secure routes of entry, to end border armour and, above all, to implement a rescue policy in the Mediterranean.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, 629 people fleeing misery and wars, to which the European Union contributes, will arrive in the port of Valencia for humanitarian reasons. But it doesn't end here. Reflect. How is it possible that for so many years thousands of people have been dying in the Mediterranean, we have not made progress on asylum? How long will the Council's deplorable action be allowed? How is it possible for the European Union to consent to constant violations of international law? Does anyone think these people will be the last to live this ordeal? Migration flows are and will continue to be a constant in our global world. If we allow international law to be violated with impunity, if our policy is to close borders, open CIES, the European Union will be again delegitimate and open the door for xenophobia and fascism , yes, fascism – to continue to spread. History, of course, is not going to forgive us.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: – Mr President, there has been an awful lot of gum-flapping both in this Chamber and other places about humanitarianism and solidarity. As far as I can see, the only humanitarianism and solidarity shown has been from the Italian Government. The policies of Angela Merkel and the EU are the issues that have precipitated this crisis, first by the unfair EU trade policies that are impoverishing Africa, and then by the ridiculous measures and windbag virtue-signalling that are failing to secure the borders of our respective nation states. Let us address the root causes of this problem. People are undertaking this hazardous journey and putting themselves in the hands of people-smuggling gangsters because of the policies I have mentioned that are both treating Africa as a dumping ground for European producers and refusing to allow true fair trade, to allow African nations to build working economies. If you were about to see a friend put his hand in the fire, what would you do: stop him, or take him to the hospital after he had burned it? The NGOs that are working in partnership with the people-smuggling gangsters are enabling them to carry on this cruel and dangerous trade. Britain stopped the slave trade in the world by stopping the people who transported the slaves. The world must now follow that example. Let us stop the people smugglers rather than making them richer. Have fair trading agreements with Africa and interdict the smugglers before they send all of those poor people off to die in the Mediterranean: that is solidarity, that is humanitarianism. Anything else is inviting tragedy and death.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Millions of migrants have arrived in Europe in recent years, and tens of thousands of those crossing the Mediterranean have died. Does the European Parliament have a responsibility in this tragedy? Some because it created false illusions. This parliament has adopted with its majority a report in which it talks about migration as a positive process that needs to be supported. The majority of this parliament declared that there was no distinction between those fleeing persecution and economic refugees coming here in the hope of a better life. This is an invitation letter, and the solution is not to distribute by mandatory quota. More and more countries are rejecting, seeing examples, not wanting a parallel society to be built in their own countries. The solution is to manage migration at its root in Africa, to devote energy to it, and since this is not a short process, borders must function as real borders, both on land and at sea.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, enough is enough to insult Italy, both inside and outside this House, italy that rescues and rescues hundreds of thousands of migrants! Too bad Tajani's not here. We must apologise to this Italy and yes, we must defend our Italian Government. I am Italian here and I defend this government, even if I am not a member of it.  The government has closed the ports. Of course, it is easy to talk from those european solidarity benches with the ports of others, because ports are not opened even in front of women, even in front of children, as has been done by France, by Spain.  So, we have a Dublin regulation – I had an intervention that I deleted, I no longer want to do it – but let us talk about a previous moment, let us also talk about the creation of hotspots in transit countries, in Libya, in Tunisia, let us talk about the coordination that must take place at European level of landings, and give Europe, which it does not yet have, an exact assessment of the means of seeing whether or not a country is under great pressure.  This must be done, because Dublin, if you like, is already falling at a later date. So let us not insult countries that have taken on the dirty work of Europe! Rinse your mouth when you talk about Italy.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I can only second that. If we would refrain from any insults, indeed – not just in this Chamber.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Italian Government's decision on aquarius is extremely serious and violates international law of the sea. Salvini, those who do the strong with the weak and the weak with the strong are cowardly. The battle for European solidarity is not on the skin of people at sea, but here at the tables where the wrong rules such as Dublin are changed, as we have done in this Parliament, obtaining an historic two-thirds vote, which deletes the criterion of the first country of access and establishes compulsory relocation and true European solidarity. Where was the League we didn't see you for 22 negotiating meetings? Go to the Council, at least now that you are in government, and ask your friend Mr Orban to play his part in the reception. And you European governments do not believe that you have been acquitted. NGOs that save lives at sea are only making up for the shameful lack of a European humanitarian search and rescue mission at sea, worthy of a civilised Europe. The only way to put an end to the deaths is to open up legal and safe access routes to all European countries, otherwise Italy and Greece will continue to be the only access points to an entire continent on very dangerous routes.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: Mr President, yes, the blackmail of the Italian government is inhumane and deeply offensive in addition to being illegal. But the Italian government did not break into power. The Salvini monster is not there by break and enter. It is the european Union's lack of solidarity in welcoming the 700,000 refugees! This is the cowardice of European leaders! It was the national selfishness that fed the beast! This is the cowardice of European leaders when they delegate our obligations to welcome the dictator Erdogan! It is the cowardice of European leaders with blood-slung hands when they deliver refugees to Libyan armed gangs by turning a blind eye to rape, murder and violence! It is the cynicism and irresponsibility of President Macron when he maintains an iron border against refugees at the Italian border! So the European Parliament has set an example: let's break Dublin, collectively welcome refugees and European leaders take their heads out of the sand to listen to us!

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, the first thing is to applaud the gesture of the cities of change and the Spanish Government. But if we do nothing, the illegal blockade by the ultra-right Italian interior minister to Aquarius can become a norm, a way of acting that violates international law and in passing criminalizes NGOs. Let's not be hypocrites. The case of the Aquarius shows that it is essential to open legal and safe routes of entry to Europe, and this also means removing fences with concertinas and preventing hot returns. The xenophobic policies of strong Europe must be turned around, urging new policies based on justice, solidarity and cooperation, which will in line with a new common migration policy; a policy that slows down the rise of the far right of the Salvini and the Le Pen, which breaks the trap that aims to force us to choose between neoliberalism and xenophobia. We cannot replace the rights...  (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have been hearing you from a long time ago condemning italy's sovereign decision not to take in 629 migrants. This decision would therefore not be humane; humanity, in your opinion, would be to encourage NGOs that play migrant taxis in the Mediterranean to the delight of smugglers, who have turned it into a business and turn the Mediterranean into a graveyard. Last year, an Italian policeman infiltrated by an NGO on the Juventa boat revealed the disgusting links between some NGOs and smugglers. When are we finally going to take an interest in the players in this sordid business?  Your condemnation of Italy is indecent, because finally who are you to give moral lessons to a country and a people that since 2013 have suffered the arrival of 700,000 illegal immigrants? In a country whose economy has stagnated since the adoption of the euro, where unemployment is endemic, how can we fail to realize the burden of these economic migrants?  With the arrival of these illegal immigrants with manners and lifestyles sometimes so different from ours, how can we not sympathize with the Italians who have experienced so much difficulty? Matteo Salvini and the Italian government are right to say "Stop," no matter what they think and whatever Mr Macron and his friends say. This situation cannot be sustainable. Thanks to Schengen, illegal immigrants welcomed to Spain will be able to cross the Pyrenees as before they crossed the Alps, and they will be able to choose to settle where it benefits them most once they have done their benchmarking of asylum conditions in Europe. It is time for each country to regain its sovereignty, for Spain to welcome all the migrants of the world if it wishes, but for France... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: – Mr President, I am proud that Spain yesterday and today continues to save lives. As an Andalusian, I know well the tragedy of immigrants who put their lives at risk to reach our shores. In 2017 alone our Navy, our Civil Guard and Maritime Rescue rescued thousands of immigrants at sea. That the refugees of the Aquarius come to fruition safely is always a relief. But a one-off measure is not the only solution that citizens expect, who know that, without a strategy for the future, that is bread for today and hunger for tomorrow. And the immigrants will be left again at the mercy of the traffickers. Europe's responsibility is: neither Spain nor any country should take on this challenge alone. That is why I demand that the Commission and the Council urgently adopt the new Dublin Regulation, with clear rules, but above all, that they be complied with. The borders of Italy, Greece and Spain are those throughout Europe, and countries that do not want to do so must be forced to look south. Because another failure in migration policy would sink the European project into the Mediterranean and give wings to populists. In this human drama no one can sing victory. It would be petty to use immigrants to achieve short-term political achievements. Let's leave the signs of victory by the time we get the migration policy ship, now on track, to sail again. And let us work with fewer spotlights, more effectiveness, for a freer and safer Europe and for relaunching the ...  (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Mr President, I just heard the Council saying that they are concerned to see the same scene over and over again of flimsy dinghies with people on board. So, with all due respect, Ms Panayotova, what are you waiting for? Because it is up to the governments in the Council to come together and act on this issue collectively, not letting certain members get away scot free – as they can do, as if nothing had happened. And I would like to refer to something else that was mentioned in this Chamber. Some mentioned Malta, as though Malta was doing nothing. Malta has always respected and adhered to its obligations. Malta’s resources are fully dedicated to saving lives at sea and Malta has the second highest number of refugees per capita, second only to Sweden. With all due respect, by pointing fingers at one Member State or another we are not going to solve this issue because we are in this together, and only if we act as one can we truly make a difference and solve the problem. So let this Parliament come together and stand up – stand up to the Council – because we have the solution for a centralised system and if the Council doesn’t want to hear that, then something needs to be done ASAP.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: For those of you who were not present when I made the announcement, we are well behind schedule and we have an extensive list for the catch-the-eye procedure, so a few minutes ago I said that I am not in a position to accept any blue cards.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: "Mr President, from this House I would first like to thank all the cities of refuge in Spain which are welcoming migrants and refugees, especially Valencia and its mayor, Joan Ribó, who will host the Aquarius. Of course, Valencia, Barcelona, Madrid, Basque Country, Navarra have been giving us an example for years. I also welcome the Spanish Government's decision to host the Aquarius.  In front of the far right, it is the awakening of solidarity Europe. But, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Council, we need much more.  All States, starting with Italy, have to comply with their European obligations, with European law, with international law. At the same time, no state can deal only with migration management. Spanish, Italian or Greek borders are European borders. In coordination with the Member States, the Union must take over the bailouts with more funds and more powers and, above all, already adopt a fair reform of the Dublin Regulation.  And I hope the Spanish government is on the right track. I ask you to remove hot returns and blades in Ceuta and Melilla. Solidarity with refugees and between European countries is essential to save lives and restore dignity to our continent.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, once again the Mediterranean has been in the news. The lives of almost seven hundred people were played, of which one hundred and twenty-three children alone, eleven babies and seven pregnant women. It's a terrible sign when we see political leaders react with indifference and even hostility.  For hours on end we have seen a sad hell because, once again, we have not been Europe, let alone union. We were 28 territories, each looking at his navel. We all got defeated. And because it's about lives, we should feel ashamed.  The wound has been exposed again: the Common European Asylum System does not work. But let us be clear, reforming this system, reforming Dublin, is a call for all Member States to do their fair share, so that there is genuine European solidarity. It does not mean open doors, but it cannot only mean more money from the Community budget.  Parliament did its part: we have agreed to strengthen our borders and just yesterday we reached an agreement with the Council to reform the Schengen Information System and increase security. But we have also presented our position to reform the asylum system. We are ready to co-decide, but the Member States do everything they can to delay. Yesterday a prime minister, regrettably, dared to talk about the willpower and how it would have returned to Italy. We would all be much better off if willpower had returned to the Council and all the Member States and we could finally reform the asylum system in Europe.  Solidarity is the cradle of Europe, but it is sunk in the Mediterranean. Have the courage to rescue her.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, are you not able to perceive the exasperation of this European Parliament, expressed in all the languages of the Union with this debate — and hundreds go — which strips away Europe's inoperability and failure in the face of migration? The Government of Spain has taken a humanitarian decision on the Aquarius and is a symbol that makes a difference, a symbol of political change, but also of how much political will can change things. And will in what is expected of the Council, of the forthcoming European Summit on Migration, to say, firstly, that the governments of the Member States which fail to comply with international humanitarian law and European law have no place in Europe, closing the doors to the desperate as the case with the Aquarius. Secondly, there is no solution that can be based on outsourcing and the sheer repression of the problem; that a holistic, comprehensive and preventive policy , as this European Parliament has demanded, must be adopted, increasing humanitarian aid and commitment to the desperate. But thirdly, we must change European legislation, unlock Dublin and this will ... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, this is not a debate about Italy or about this or that State. This is a debate about the European response to the humanitarian drama in the Mediterranean. But the problem is that there is no European answer. The problem is that States still do not recognize that, in order to meet the challenge of migrant management of refugees, responsibilities must be shared, solidarity must be taken, progress must be made in reforming the Dublin system and not facing this situation selfishly or on their own.  Let us not deceive ourselves, ladies and gentlemen, the Aquarius is just a symptom of a reality as harsh as it is unacceptable. The Mediterranean is the most unequal and deadliest border in the world. We can train the Coast Guard. Perhaps we will have a less deadly sea, but no less unequal, and this is why we will continue to have Aquarius.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent days we have witnessed the unscrupulousness of Mr Salvini and Mr Di Maio, who, with their unlikely alliances, alas on the skin of the weakest, to the detriment of human rights, make Europe believe that it can stop the landings by closing its ports.  The rules change at the negotiating tables and not in social networks. In Europe, and I ask all Member States to do so, work is being made to seek constructive alliances for a fair distribution of responsibilities. This Parliament has done so by amending Dublin, removing the criterion of the country of first entry and choosing compulsory relocation. Those who arrive in Italy, arrive in Europe. The search and rescue system remains our priority, italy's flagship thanks to the extraordinary work of the Navy, the Coast Guard and NGOs, increasingly scapegoats for failed European and national policies. At SOS Mediterranée, Medecins sans frontières, Sea Watch, Proactiva, Sea Eye, Mission Lifeline I say thank you for this test of great humanity. Solidarity with all the victims of the Mediterranean.

name: Stefano MAULLU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that aquarius has had the merit of breaking the veil of hypocrisy behind this real and great epochal problem of immigration. It has broken the veil of a policy that is not working, a European policy that has abandoned Italy and left it alone in relation to these demographic flows, and has made even more evident the neo-colonialist policy made by France, which has had the right to define our country in an improbable way, a policy made in Africa on the bayonets of the Foreign Legion , a policy that we are still suffering from today because of the disastrous action against the Libyan Government at the time.  An action that continues to this day, with the President of the Republic French who, in defiance of everything and in defiance of European foreign policy in particular, continues to make meetings with al-Sarraj and General Haftar almost as if he were a Foreign Minister of the European Union. We are paying for this: a damaging European policy made on the skin of migrants, giving six billion to a dictator like Erdogan and not doing the same for a great plan for the Mediterranean.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Mr President, my country Greece has shown solidarity and responsibility in managing migration despite economic problems. But we are facing a new humanitarian crisis: trafficking rings with turnovers of billions, which are also denounced for cooperation with NGOs, are continuing their criminal activity in the Mediterranean. The smooth functioning of the Schengen area has not been restored, and the revision of the 'Dublin Regulation' is contrary to the refusal of certain Member States to cooperate. We know that countries have long since closed their borders, one after the other. Where are so many people going to go? Colleagues, we're not here to blame each other. But in less than a year we have an election. If we do not demonstrate solidarity in practice and a coherent European immigration policy, we will not be able to defend our values, European values. We all have equal rights, but above all equal obligations.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. Chairman, migration poses a challenge for the European Union, but the problem should have been addressed at its point of origin, not in Europe. It was necessary to make a distinction between war and economic migrants and to provide assistance to those who save a naked life. It is tragic that in search of a better life people in the Mediterranean lose their lives.  I warned back in 2014 that the causes should be addressed first and foremost and that the European Union must start fighting more fiercely against smugglers and traffickers who have black-eyed thousands of families by promising them a better life. It was also necessary to help stabilise conditions in countries from which people have largely left their homes and to provide them with shelter in the first neighbouring country. On such activities, the European Union should have spent both its attention and its money. Over 1 million migrants arrived by boats, 35,000 by land, while 3,770 migrants died crossing the Mediterranean, terrifying.  We need to be more efficient and eradicate the causes of migration. Action should be taken before people board the ships.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I was proud of a President-in-Office of the Council who said 'better to lose a vote than a life in the Mediterranean', for which I am, of course, grateful. But, on the other hand, today we cannot blame Italy, Italy, which has made a great effort and set a great example of humanity in the Mediterranean. Today, Italy cannot be blamed for what has been done.  Italy has been left alone and today it is the Council that has this responsibility. The Council, which will be able to find a solution at the end of this month if it so wishes, will be able to find a solution. The Council cannot continue to postpone the solution, while Parliament has a definite position, probably not the best, but certainly a great step forward on the Dublin Regulation. Today my appeal is to the Council: examine your conscience, look at what is happening in Europe and in the Mediterranean, do not leave Italy alone, because Italy is not solely responsible for what is happening. Your hands are dirty with blood.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, Europe does not have a refugee crisis. We do have a crisis of solidarity, however. There is a refugee crisis in places like Jordan and Lebanon, where huge camps have been in existence for years, but here in Europe we’ve forgotten our fundamental values of solidarity and our moral responsibility to uphold human rights. In the absence of governmental action in some Member States to provide humanitarian assistance for refugees and migrants, ordinary citizens have stepped in and saved lives. I have visited Calais and Paris many times and talked to people working on the ground. Organisations like Care4Calais in France and the refugee support platform in Belgium are great examples of how citizens’ mobilisation can save lives. At sea, however, the difficulties are much greater. Although a few organisations like SOS Méditerranée provide invaluable sea rescue work they cannot meet demand, so the EU and its Member States must make humanitarian assistance a priority of migratory policy, with sea rescue as a focus.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, aquarius is a clear demonstration of the consequence of the absence of a European policy on immigration issues and refugee issues, but it is also, let us be careful, clear proof that a European policy is absolutely necessary, it must not be lacking. Unless, in the coming months, we see the Italian Government move Italy to the northern seas, Italy will have the problem of immigrants and refugees and will have to face it together with the others. We need a European policy. Unfortunately, by avoiding the problems, it was the problems that got us behind the wall. Today it is clear that policies are also needed to prevent Italian public opinion from sledging everything on an anti-European position. So far, the golden-egg hen has been the issue of immigration for the League and for Salvini, and I believe that public opinion must be given a voice by making sure that the European Council of 28-29 June ... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Giuseppe FERRANDINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Salvini's ill-considered decision to close ports to humanitarian ships must alarm us and encourage the next European Council to give serious consideration to the proposal voted by Parliament for the dublin crossing. Ladies and gentlemen, there is one fact that cannot be buried: Italy has been left alone to deal with the humanitarian emergency. This is a reality enshrined in the events and statements of the last few days, most finally those of Commissioner Avramopoulos.  Despite the efforts of recent years to stem and control the phenomenon with humanity, only 31 % of migrants arriving in Italy and Greece were then welcomed by another EU country. France and Germany have taken in only 25 % and 37 % of the quotas allocated, and we are well aware of the approach to migration policy in Austria and the countries of Eastern Europe. As long as there is a fragmented European Union on the subject of migration, there will really be no European project, because we are European only if we have the courage to build bridges and not walls.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, no one can remain indifferent to the difficult fate of migrants, including 120 children, who are waiting to be admitted by Italy or Malta, who do not want to. We are all very emotional about this and in such circumstances it is easiest to point the finger at those who have closed their doors to them. But we must not forget that the states that are now being demonized lightly have so far accepted a huge number of migrants and cannot be just accused of lack of humanity and solidarity. We must fight more decisively against smugglers who knowingly and for profit put people in danger of life. Illegal migration is completely unacceptable precisely because it puts people at risk. NGOs rescuing migrants in the Mediterranean should do so in better coordination with state authorities to avoid situations where the ship with the rescued has nowhere to dock. Accommodation in a safe harbour must be provided in advance for every rescued migrant.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the situation with the increased migratory flows has 'hit the ceiling'. Greece and Italy can't take any more refugees and illegal immigrants. Some are therefore safely criticising Italy for closing its ports, while France, Germany, Belgium, Denmark and Sweden have suspended the Schengen Agreement. At the same time, France and Germany have fulfilled only 30% of their obligations in relation to refugee relocations from Greece. It must finally be expressed in practice and the famous solidarity must be implemented and Dublin III, which has turned the host countries, namely Greece and Italy, into warehouses of souls, must be abolished.  The European Council must stand by its responsibilities, allocate funds for the refugee crisis, reactivate the system of relocation and responsibility-sharing. The inhabitants of the Aegean islands, which are still home to thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants, are sending a cry of anguish and protest.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, the 629 migrants who, instead of guaranteeing rescue, have found themselves drifting between Italy and Malta, are a thin expression of the hundreds of thousands of crossings in recent years. They are a faint reminder of the seven hundred and ninety-two killed this year or the sixteen thousand who died in the last four years of the Mediterranean, a common ditch of oblivion. They are an unequivocal demonstration of the total lack of solidarity of the EU and its powers with those who have nothing to lose and risk their lives for better days. Well can play the game of the pushes between the EU and Member States. The responsibilities of those who now close ports do not differ from those who before them did, criminalized rescue organizations, signed criminal agreements with third countries to repel and contain migration. They do not differ from the walls of Spain, Austria, Hungary or Greece, or from authentic concentration camps on European soil. All with the connivance of the EU and its xenophobic and racist policies that grossly violate human rights, international law.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, look at this ship. It is a paper ship, a paper ship in front of the ocean liner of the European fortress. How is it that the Council of Ministers has not been convened to what is happening? We're outraged. And our society, which we represent in this Parliament, which, by the way, is now empty; which, by the way, and I insist, is not even 10% of Parliament here today — in a debate like this, it is dehumanised. Don't throw the ball between each other. Do not argue between the Council and the Commission and Parliament, while the Mediterranean is a cemetery of the dead. Because this is going to keep happening. This has been a precedent for selfishness. This has been a precedent for fascist policies. Moreover, there is no need to shield borders with European coastguards, but it is necessary to put resources in place and put the European economy in place to avoid the causes that cause migrants to come here. We have to stand in solidarity because Europe has been an emigrant. And above all, the shipwreck of Europe, the shipwreck of the ocean liner, in the face of the dignity of these people who come to save their lives.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr President Tajani said earlier here that we need to find a solution, and quickly, and I agree with him on that. The solution is not for the EU to help more or less attract migrants to our Member States through generous subsidies and residence permits. We should be aware that those who come now are up to 99% economic migrants who believe that the EU is a large ATM.  We will not be able to resolve this through a reform of Dublin, and this compulsory distribution is being talked about. We have had that discussion for years without finding a solution, and we are seeing country after country distance themselves from this now. It is high time to redo and do the right thing instead. Instead of acting as a water taxi for people smugglers, it is better to look at other solutions. Sign an agreement with any African country where we can send the migrants back. In this way, we counter this with them going out in dangerous boats, and we save lives.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the problem of illegal immigration into the Mediterranean will not be solved, because the European Union does not have the will to carry out the actions needed to solve it.  Moreover, it does not show solidarity with the countries of entry. What solidarity has he shown towards Italy, Spain, Malta? The fact that it tolerates neighbouring countries closing their borders and abolishing the Schengen Agreement in practice? The fact that it distributes some funds which, as is the case in Greece, are essentially being abused by some corrupt NGOs? The fact that it blames Italy for deciding the obvious, that is, not to allow other illegal immigrants to come to its country? Things are even worse with Greece. Is the European Union showing solidarity when it tolerates Erdogan sending thousands of illegal immigrants to Greece every day, more than any other country in Europe? Or when it tolerates the European Union turning Greece into a vast camp of unhappy illegal immigrants? Does the European Union have the courage to build a hotspot in Turkey or to stop funding and accession talks with Turkey?

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, at last a European government, the Italian Government, is showing an exemplary attitude to the issue that has arisen with Aquarius. But too many questions remain unanswered. By what authority can members of any NGO transfer people, acting in practice as smugglers and slave traders? The ship's specific passengers were neither castaways nor were their lives in danger. With the support of some they have tried to exploit international law and move them to Europe. But no international law requires any state to break its laws. But the most important question is: why have the members of these NGOs not yet been arrested for human trafficking? Why have these criminal organisations not been banned? We must immediately stop the tolerance shown and implement the laws of the Member States, and the illegal traffickers of NGOs end up in prison wherever they belong.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank you for this very lively debate on the migratory situation in the Mediterranean. I take from this debate that we all share finally – or almost all of us – the same objectives, and that is very important for us. There cannot be one and only one answer. There is no single solution and we all know that. No Member State can do this alone. It is impossible. The only way is to adopt all the missing elements and to implement a comprehensive migration policy. This policy starts with cooperation with third countries. It continues with the protection of our common European borders – our external borders. It is in line with a future-proof European asylum system based on solidarity and responsibility. It is very much relying on effective return of people that have no right to stay in Europe. It is completed by the creation of legal pathways to come to Europe and by effective integration policies for those legally living among us. We need to continue our common work and our joint efforts in all aspects in parallel.  As regards some of the points you raised – Mr Corrao and many of his colleagues here referred to the support given to Italy – we have worked continuously and relentlessly over the past three years to ensure that much greater solidarity is shown to all Member States facing disproportionate migration pressures due to their geographical situation. I want to commend the Herculean efforts made by Italy over these past years. The Commission – and you all know that it has stood and continues to stand by Italy politically, operationally and financially – has granted more than EUR 653 million to Italy under the EU migration and home affairs funds to date. On top of that, we have offered EUR 193 million in emergency assistance. The European Borders and the Coastguard Agency Deployment is currently deploying 260 experts for Joint Operation Themis. Eighty asylum experts from Member States and interim staff have been deployed to support the operational activities. Europol guest officers are present in several hotspots and 12 963 persons in need of international protection have been relocated. We are also working closely with Italy to prevent departures from northern Africa. We have invested EUR 200 million in Libya to assist migrants, and EUR 46 million for border management. We will also grant Tunisia EUR 25 million for a border management project. As I said, this approach has brought results. Arrivals in Italy have decreased significantly. I look forward to working with the new Italian Government to ensure that arrivals decrease even further.  As I said during my introductory remarks, I am not here to play any blame games, and anyway it doesn’t help. The Aquarius incident shows that we need structural solutions and that solidarity cannot be an ad hoc or one-off thing. This is the essence of our discussions on Dublin, on stronger external borders, on cooperation with third countries and on our proposals today for more migration and borders funding.  These are European challenges which require genuine European solutions. This is not the responsibility of Italy alone or of Malta alone or of Spain alone. This is the responsibility of the European Union and its Member States as a whole.  Under these very pressing circumstances, and given the experience and the lessons we have learned over the last few years, we should reiterate our determination to safeguard the principles and unity of Europe in a spirit of responsibility. We should stand as one, guaranteeing a future-proof, balanced and fair European migration policy. All of us here have a great responsibility to show leadership and to ensure the unity and cohesion of our societies, avoiding divisive rhetoric. Migration has become a challenge for our unity. It is up to us to turn this into an opportunity, into a strong bond among EU institutions, among Member States and among our citizens.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, Commissioner, I have listened carefully to your views on the humanitarian situation in the Mediterranean Sea. The topic is of crucial importance, and it is my hope that we will be able to find a common solution quickly. The migrants certainly deserve that but so do our constituencies. We shouldn’t forget that most of the refugees and asylum seekers, particularly children and women, were affected by war and terror in their home countries. Migration is one of the major humanitarian challenges that the European Union is currently still facing and, as we discussed together yesterday and today, we need a holistic approach to migration management. The European Union response to this challenge has two main dimensions: strengthening the instruments for limiting irregular migration and addressing the root causes of migration. Many of you referred today to the reform of the Dublin Regulation system and – sharing the common understanding that the European Union needs a properly functioning common asylum system – the Council has not stopped working to enhance the security of our citizens, to strengthen border control and to manage the migratory process more efficiently. The Council has listened to you carefully and we welcome Parliament’s input in this debate. The Bulgarian Presidency fully shares your concerns and the sense of urgency around the need for asylum system reform which is both effective and protective. So we are doing our best to advance. We have proposed a qualitatively new approach to the Dublin Regulation. We are working not just on general principles but on the legal text of the regulation, article by article, and on concrete solutions. So we have built into the Dublin Regulation a new crisis mechanism for managing the migration and asylum systems in the Union when under pressure. The Presidency proposal provides clear criteria defining levels of pressure, and lays down measures aimed at establishing a proportionate response in each phase, allowing for timely mitigation, based on common action, of the challenges faced in addressing the root causes of the pressure at the very beginning, thus preventing escalation of the situation.  The Presidency is trying to strike a balance between responsibility and solidarity. As I have already mentioned in relation to the preparation for the European Council meeting yesterday, the process of seeking consensus is now being led by the President of the European Council. It is up to him and the leaders to look for compromises and propose a way ahead. Any solution that will be found should take account of the interests of all Member States – the frontline Member States and also the Member States that have been destination countries for asylum seekers. Any decision will need to provide sustainable solutions that will help the Union to cope with situations similar to the one we faced a couple days ago.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Thank you, Madam Minister. I would like to thank you, colleagues, Ladies and Gentlemen, for the discipline and mutual respect that you have shown. You made the chairing easier and it was a pleasure to chair this debate. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. – The case of the ship "Aquarius", which the governments of Italy and Malta refused to welcome, despite transporting 629 people rescued to the sea, has eloquently recalled how the tragedy of migrants in the Mediterranean is also the drama of Europe, by interspersing and calling into question the civilizational and humanist principles that are its most valuable heritage and its main legacy. Some progress made in managing external borders, in helping refugees and responding to the lasting causes of migration flows through development aid are not enough to hide the failure of the various attempts to distribute the refugee reception effort, distributing them in solidarity and proportionally across Member States. It is clear that the Italian and Maltese governments have made a reprehensible and shocking choice in the case of "Aquarius", turning their backs on human beings in danger, but it is still true that the effort required of these countries is unfair and that it is not enough to increase financial transfers to make it fair. It is regrettable that, three years later, the EU has not yet been able to reform the Dublin Regulation or impose consequences on member states for the relapsing reception of refugees.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – The odyssey of the Aquarius is more than a wake-up call. This case reminds us of the importance of clear European agreements. Let this be the ultimate argument for finally forcing the european breakthrough, which is blocking the reform of asylum policy, and signing for a quick, uniform processing of asylum applications and an agreement on the further development of an effective European border and coastguard, with 10 000 border guards (7 times more than today). Not a policy of pushbacks, but a policy that prevents people from getting into rickety boats, and effectively sends deported migrants back, but correctly. Without holding them on a leash or pushing them back on rickety boats. An agreement that allows migrants to apply in hotspots in Africa, but provides protection for war refugees, and certainly the most vulnerable among them. I sincerely hope that the Aquarius will also give the impetus for the launch of a major Marshall Plan for Africa. We have every interest in investing in the region, primarily in renewable energy and sustainable agriculture. The existing Trust Fund for Africa urgently needs to be developed into a comprehensive investment pact to generate opportunities and perspective in the region.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – In the face of the EU's cold indemlight, some 800 people have died this year crossing the Mediterranean. In the last four years there have been more than 16,000 who have perished, making the Mediterranean a gigantic mass grave. Official figures that conceal a reality most likely even darker. Pushed by hunger, misery and war - fleeing scenarios of devastation in which the EU has heavy responsibilities - they clash against a wall of indifference and inhumanity erected by the EU. The game of the push we are seeing, between the EU and the Member States and the Member States for each other, is deplorable. As deplorable are the attempts to criminalize rescue and rescue organizations that operate on the ground. Organisations whose action is necessary in the face of the omission and negligence of the EU and its governments in relation to humanitarian rescue and rescue actions. And deplorables are also agreements with third countries - especially the one signed with Turkey - to repel, contain or expel migrants. Eu agencies on the ground, instead of humanitarian action, focus on implementing these agreements. The 629 migrants adrift in Aquarius, including many children and pregnant women, are an eloquent expression of what the EU has become.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – In the Mediterranean, smuggling networks and routes must be eliminated as soon as possible, because in the system that is now in development, it is the smugglers who decide who can come to Europe. For them, no life matters, and unfortunately European NGOs are assisting in this when they are still "ringing" migrants from Libyan waters and then transporting them to Europe. According to the European Border and Coast Guard, crowded rubber dingboats are being released into the sea without water, food or life jackets, in anticipation of being quickly found by NGO lifeboats. If we really want to help, we must be able to prevent thousands of migrants from risking their own lives and that of their children by making it clear that it is not possible to enter Europe illegally. It is important that economic migrants are separated from those who are genuinely entitled to refugee status outside the EU's external borders, as less than 3% of illegal migrants arriving in Italy have proved to be genuine refugees. Today, we have finally reached the point where a growing number of EU national leaders recognise and voice what the Hungarian Prime Minister has consistently represented since 2015, that the protection of the external borders must be a priority. We must once again rule our own external borders on land and at sea. Effective measures are therefore finally needed, as today the EU is still managing situations that are being enforced by people smugglers, rather than amening its will at the external maritime borders.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. – Salvini lies: it is not true that Italy is left alone with migration: last Friday I and other members of the Special Committee on Terrorism passed by the Aquarius, docked at Catania, and went all the way to the Pozzalo ‘hotspot’, which would not be equipped and able to articulate with European Law Enforcement Command structures to identify, screen and assist people arriving, if it were not for European funding, manning and organisation.  Salvini lies: portraying migrants and refugees as threats and omitting that inflows into Italy have dramatically decreased. And yes, maybe inflows are managed by mafias trafficking human beings, but only because other liars and fearmongers in European governments are fuelling their sordid business by refusing to open legal, controlled ways for migrants and refugees.  Italy and Malta violated international and European law by refusing 629 people rescued by the Aquarius. The Socialists now in power in Spain saved European decency and humanity. But that will not always work: we need governments to approve at the next European Council the Dublin Regulation reform and the full migration/asylum package, proposed by Parliament to ensure that the EU, in solidarity, manages migration, not the human traffickers.

name: Dietmar KÖSTER
text: Writing. – Since 2000, more than 35,000 people have drowned in the Mediterranean. The inability of the European Union – and in particular the European Council – to put an end to this man-made disaster is intolerable. The European Parliament has long since put forward proposals to put an end to this disaster. But the Council is politically unwilling. Now this anti-human rights policy has reached a new climax: the Italian Minister of the Interior, Salvini, of the neo-fascist Lega, has forbidden the ship Aquarius of SOS Mediterranee and Doctors Without Borders to enter an Italian port. There were 629 people on the ship in need. Under international law, Salvini would have been obliged to include them. With his port blockade, he opposes human rights! As a socialist, I am pleased that the new Spanish Government has agreed to welcome the people. We must finally put an end to criminalising those who, through their practical actions, defend human rights. They deserve our solidarity. The Council must finally shoulder its responsibilities so that the death in the Mediterranean is brought to an end and a human rights-based refugee policy is implemented. The Council is called upon: the Dublin reform must now finally be launched!

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – Unless we make a clear distinction between genuine asylum seekers and economic emigrants, European citizens will not understand our purpose on migration issues. Unless we have functioning policies and rules that deal fairly, strictly and effectively with such issues, on a European basis, populists and extremists will win the political challenge. Asylum seekers should be given all the protection they need. Economic migrants, unless they are needed by European economies, must be sent back. For this we need a strong and effective frontier control system that reaches out to neighbouring territories, inclusive of a security capability. But Europe should also have a functioning common policy to allow open and legal economic migration, matching migrants to needs identified and declared by Member States. It also should strengthen and widen its development aid outreach to sub-Saharan Africa, while streamlining the investment and operating activities of its own corporations in that zone – so as to promote job creation there. We have been declaring these objectives for a long while. There has been a lack of agreement and limp implementation. Whether via ‘Dublin’ or otherwise, the time has come for like-minded Member States to jointly consolidate and put into full effect these agreed policy directions.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: Writing. – It is with relief that the Spanish Government has come to the aid of the African migrants rescued aboard the Aquarius vessel. Someone had to help people in trouble. With French Prime Minister Emmanuel Macron at the forefront, many are attacking Italian Interior Minister Matteo Salvini, who, in accordance with his new migration policy, intends to end the Mediterranean migrant crisis in his country for a reason and right. First and fore again, Chancellor Angela Merkel and her invitation-only "willkommenskultur", as well as Brussels' flawed immigration policy, putting the whole of Europe at risk. The humanitarian crisis of Aquarius's "castaways" is merely a consequence of these politicians, along with greedy people smugglers and irresponsible pro-migrant NGOs. You have to show solidarity — but not like this! Father Boulad is right, who, using the ship's metaphor, correctly stated that no one can be expected to overload the ship with the risk of sinking, for then they will all perish. And this ship, in the current situation, is Europe itself. I welcome the efforts of the Italian Interior Minister and his German counterpart Horst Seehofer to protect Europe's external borders. Hungary of the European Union and the Visegrad Four, the EU must radically change its immigration policy.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Written. Mr President, I would like to say that what we have seen in recent days is disgraceful, unseen and unworthy, but the reality is that there is nothing new under the sun. Since the dublin regulation has come into force, we have seen that migrants are the plaything of European governments and administrations. People are not registered and not taken care of, so they quietly disappear under the radar. When migrants apply for asylum, the uncertainty of the Dublin transfer hangs over their heads. And now the ports are closing to vulnerable people.  Dublin makes for a zero sum game, and the democrats are the losers. Because make no mistake, for Salvini the gain is not in the fact that Italy may or may not have to take in 600 migrants. The profit is that he can score on the hood of vulnerable people. That is why I am now addressing every democrat in the Council: you must act now. The game has to stop. Reform Dublin now, because with every ounce of dignity we take away from vulnerable people, we are taking away a little of our own dignity. You must act now because you bear the responsibility for what the EU will be in the forthcoming elections.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Writing. – The events surrounding the Aquarius refugee boat this week clearly show us how far Europe's right-wing parties are prepared to go. They are not in the least interested in a real solution, even worse: they accept dying in the Mediterranean in order to continue their policy of prejudice and fear-mongering. I didn't expect anything else from Orban, Kickl and Salvini. The fact that, with Seehofer and Kurz, Europe's Christian Democrats are now also tuning into the chorus of the far-right is dangerous for the EU. Proposals for the reform of the European asylum system have been around for a long time and are constantly being delayed. People expect solutions rather than rhetoric. The European Parliament is constantly renewing its clear position: we need legal entry, clearly defined distribution quotas and financial support for the countries of origin.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Andreas Schwab, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on a proportionality test before adoption of new regulation of professions (COM(2016)0822 – C8—0012/2017 – 2016/0404(COD))(A8—0395/2017).

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Fifty million people, or 22% of the workforce in Europe, work in regulated professions which are linked to the possession of certain qualifications or in which the holding of a particular title is protected, such as the profession of pharmacist or the profession of architect. For a whole range of professions, for example in the areas of health or safety, special regulation of occupational entry conditions is often justified. However, there are repeated cases at European level in the 28 Member States of the European Union in which excessive, cumbersome and outdated rules make it disproportionately difficult for qualified applicants to access professions. The Member States of the European Union have taken part in the regular legislative procedure to ensure that the principle of proportionality is recognised as a general legal principle in the European Union – not only in primary law, but also in the Professional Recognition Directive. The European Court of Justice has also repeatedly upheld the principle of proportionality in the area of the exercise of professional rights, which may be restricted by the Member States. Currently, Directive 2005/36, last amended in 2013, requires Member States to examine the proportionality of their own requirements restricting access to or exercise of regulated professions and to submit the results of that examination to the Commission. In that regard, Member States may still decide on these rules and provisions themselves, provided that they comply with the principles of primary law and the principle of proportionality. On the basis of this, however, the Commission has established that the exercise of the principle of proportionality by the Member States in recent years has unfortunately not been as successful as the Member States themselves and the Commission had actually promised, and has therefore put forward a new proposal on how the principle of proportionality from the Professional Qualifications Directive can be grasped even more precisely and even better in the future. And even if the European legislator had doubts as to whether the repetition of this principle and the clarification of this principle would really make sense in the end, the many examples presented by the Commission have convinced us. That is why, in the internal market committee, we in the Committee on the Internal Market finally persuaded ourselves by a large majority to work very hard and quickly to draft this legislative proposal. I am grateful to all my fellow Members, especially the shadow rapporteurs, for the fact that a very consensual solution has been reached here. The new directive therefore sets a Europe-wide benchmark for the criteria to be analysed and respected by the authorities of the Member States in the context of the proportionality test, and this will in future clearly regulate what proportionality means in terms of professional regulations and what effects, rules and opportunities will have to be adapted to the principle of proportionality in the future. In my view, the main progress that we have been able to make possible in this report in the end lies in the fact that, on the one hand, we have been able to create clarification for the health professions, but at the same time they must also be subject to the general principle of proportionality, because in the end it is necessary to decide by the courts what the requirements of the principle of proportionality must be. Secondly, it is important to me that this directive should also provide for the provision of cross-border services beyond the Professional Qualifications Recognition Directive only to include proportionate requirements, so that the practice of the profession is not in fact disproportionately restricted in the European internal market. Thirdly, it was clear to us from the outset that this directive does not serve deregulation, but rather a clarification of the principle of proportionality, and that in many places we have not obeyed the somewhat presumed impetus of deregulation, but have ensured that sensible regulation based on the legislation of the Member States will remain as possible in the future as before. Finally, it is important to me that we can also account for the craftsmanship, which in many places is an important achievement for our economy and society, not only by recognising compulsory membership in the Chamber, but also in other places, that we regard master-letter training as a particularly important contribution to the training of young people. And finally, it is, of course, important, including in the context of this legislative project, that subsidiarity, that is to say ensuring the legislative mandate on the basis of the Member States, is maintained and that we have all promised each other that we will not call into question the competence of the Member States at any point, provided they respect the principle of proportionality.
