I believe that, in the context of the proposal for notification to be discussed at a later date, which then leads the Member States to submit appropriate measures of professional regulation first to the European Commission for consideration, we will be able to improve the exercise framework of regulated professions in the European Union, in the European internal market, through this proposal. That is why I hope that, in the end, all the Member States will also take account of it. Finally, i would like to thank all the Members who have worked on it. I hope that this will enable us to take a small but hopefully effective step towards the European internal market.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I’m really happy to be here today for this debate on the Proportionality Test Directive ahead of tomorrow’s final vote. With this proposal, we have jointly delivered on the first part of our services package of January 2017. I really welcome your cooperation and your support. What do we want to achieve with this directive? You know that negotiations were thorough, they were intense, but we reached an agreement in just over a year, so relatively shortly. Let me briefly recall the goal of the directive. We want to improve the quality of the future regulation of professional services. As your rapporteur said, they are of utmost importance for our economies. Business services, including professional services such as accountants, lawyers, engineers and architects account for almost 13% of EU value added. Regulated professions all together make up nearly 22% of the European labour force, so almost 47 million people. And research shows that services inputs, including professional services, account for about 40% of the value added in manufacturing industries. So it’s extremely important for our economies. We also note that poorly-designed regulation creates obstacles, especially for young graduates trying to access these professions and for professionals when carrying out their professions. So we need to ensure that across the EU, the new regulation is really proportionate in order to protect public interests and that it does not create needless obstacles. This directive will help Member States with devising their regulations. It will mean that we can minimise any negative effects on the single market, on competitiveness or on the mobility of professionals. It does not prevent Member States from adopting new requirements, but it does prevent unjustified ones. We are not losing sight of existing requirements either. We adopted reform recommendations on the existing regulation of professional services as part of the services package. You discussed these recommendations recently – I’m really grateful for that, and I want to thank Mr Danti for a report that really encourages us to pursue this important work together with the Member States, and we are doing exactly that. The Proportionality Test Directive complements this by helping Member State authorities to fulfil their obligations under existing legislation, and of course, court judgments. It sets out very clear rules on how to determine whether planned legislation is really fit for purpose and makes sure that this is determined in advance of legislation being adopted. We have insisted many times that the Commission should make enforcement of existing rules a priority, and we are doing exactly that. But we have to recognise that ex-post enforcement actions are definitely not enough. The new directive will help us provide clarity on the general obligation of the principle of proportionality. As I said, I’m really grateful for the way that we have worked together on this proposal. The compromise, I think, strikes the right balance. The outcome of the negotiations maintains the overall objective of the proposed directive. It maintains legal certainty and coherence, while at the same time making sure that important public interests such as patient safety – which was raised many times – and our human health are really clearly acknowledged. There were many moments where some doubted that this directive should cover all of the professions, but clearly, the principle of proportionality applies to all professions, so I am grateful that this House – you, honourable Members – has managed to find a good compromise. I also welcome the enhanced transparency and additional focus on the principle of non-discrimination. Transparency has to be ensured before and after a new regulation is adopted in the Member States. Relevant stakeholders shall now be involved before Member States adopt the new regulation on professional services. The reason why the regulation was found to be necessary will be available to all after its adoption. You also have drawn attention to the obstacles that may hit professionals when they want to provide temporary or occasional services, so I welcome the addition that proportionality of requirements related specifically to this temporary or occasional provision of services must be assessed. The Qualifications Directive already says that professionals must be able to provide their services in other Member States without unnecessary administrative hurdles. But of course, too often Member States demand plenty of information from professionals instead of just using direct cooperation with other Member States via our well-established internal market information tool, IMI. Let me be clear that this does not affect the posting of workers or the application of local working conditions. I think that the adoption of this directive will not be the end of our work in this field; rather, it is the beginning. We will look closely into the implementation of this directive and will assist Member States. We will place special emphasis on the transparency that you introduced for the regulation and its rationale via our regulated professions database. This database has really become a reference tool for professional regulations in the EU. I would especially like to thank the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs, the competent ministers and, of course, the Presidency for your cooperation.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. More than 5500 professions are currently regulated in the EU. And there are still significant problems with the mutual recognition of professional qualifications between Member States. We continue to receive a great many complaints when, for example, in one Member State, nonsensical conditions are required to carry out its profession in another Member State. That must not be allowed to happen. That is why this proportionality test, as it is now being adopted here via this law, is an important step. It will help to simplify professional recognition across borders. This is particularly important for people who live on a border, as I represent them. Many people rightly do not understand why they should not be allowed to pursue their profession in another country, which they do well and in a qualified manner. Another part of the so-called service package was the so-called electronic service card, and I will come back to it very briefly. I was very clear in my opposition in committee and even contributed to their rejection with my vote. Why was that important? This service card would have re-emerged all the problems that we actually wanted to combat with the Posting of Workers Directive. It would have made effective controls more difficult and provided a new gateway for social dumping. However, we must combat social dumping more effectively, rather than simplifying it. Of course, it remains important for companies to be able to offer their services across borders. This is what our internal market thrives on. However, it remains important, in the same breath, to protect companies and workers from unfair competition.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Schwab, and the other fellow shadow rapporteurs for the long and demanding work we have done together. The goal we set ourselves was an ambitious goal. It was a question of changing the text that the Commission had given us in large parts. So finding balance and convergence on new formulations was no small feat, we succeeded and that is very important. Our aim was this and, at the same time, to seek solutions that would not restrict the autonomy of the Member States. It was supposed to be our work of supporting the Member States, maintaining their autonomy in regulating professional activities and in pursuing, through this regulation, objectives of public interest, as has already been said in the debate.  We have now amended that proposal and we are at a conclusion, some aspects of which I would like to highlight. We have ensured that the modalities of the test are flexible and proportionate to the changes under consideration. That wasn't the case at first. We have explicitly stressed the competence of the Member States to regulate the professions. The different approaches are not to be considered as wrong or negative, even before they are proposed, but they must come into synergy with the overall solution that we are evaluating here.  We rejected – yes, because there are not only the positive things that we have added, there are also those that we have deleted – the Commission's proposal to create independent supervisory bodies that could disrupt future work, ensuring that the list of criteria to be assessed is proportionate and less burdensome for the Member States, including through the elimination of the economic impact assessment that was in the initial text. We have strengthened the measures of transparency and consultation of stakeholders, starting with the social partners, and we have finally maintained the explicit recognition in the text of the directive of the specificity of the regulation of the health professions, which has caused so much debate but which has created so much sensitivity in all the countries of the Union.  We therefore have the autonomy of the Member States, which avoids deregulation, and at the same time we have increased the transparency and involvement of the social partners. It was a necessary balance but not a simple one. I'm very glad we did.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: for the ECR Group. – Madam President, the proportionality test seeks to remove the remaining barriers in the single market. Today, those who want to offer professional services or take up a job in another Member State face a significant number of regulatory obstacles. The situation is all the worse in professions where professional qualifications need to be demonstrated, and the 28 Member States have their own rules on what that qualification should look like. Those interested in these professions are then facing a slow and bureaucratic process of so-called mutual recognition of qualifications. For this reason, I consider the proportionality test to be correct, because it aims to prevent excessive professional regulations before they are adopted by the States. Proportionality has long been a well-known and sadly unbalanted principle, otherwise today we would not have states with more than 500 regulated professions, while another state is enough for the 1970s. The proportionality test should discourage unnecessary regulations for states, and the benefit of our negotiations with the Council has also been to maintain the principle of greater transparency in the adoption of national rules. I am pleased that we are trying to remove obstacles and not create them, and this directive is one of the few that really has the potential to reduce the number of regulations. However, the question arises as to why we cannot be consistent in this approach. Today, we are removing barriers, but two weeks ago we voted for a new regulation of the Posting of Workers Directive, which deliberately restricts service providers from other Member States. I would like to know how we can support two opposing initiatives at once and still pretend that we are a common objective.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the G7 Summit in Quebec brought many surprises. One of the biggest was the day after, when we realised that President Trump was not signing the final statement. The signal sent to the world was quite clear: the USA stands for protectionism, closeness and isolationism. The question is what the EU answer should be, and I do strongly believe that our answer should be to stand by our beliefs. We do believe in openness, we do believe in trade, we do believe in mobility. These are not just instruments to boost growth; these are also our values we should stand by. And this is exactly what we are doing tomorrow. The vote tomorrow is about 5 500 professions that would be able to move freely in Europe. Almost 47 million citizens will be affected by that. In most cases they can move from one country to another, but there are still significant barriers. In some countries, you have to live in that country in order to be able to exercise the profession; in other countries, you have to exercise this continuously. I do believe that tomorrow we are not just creating an instrument to boost growth and job mobility; we are actually defining our values. Thanks to the rapporteur and thank you to the co-rapporteurs for their very fruitful work. I hope that tomorrow we will have a clear vote on this subject.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, from the outset I have already expressed my rejection of this proposal for proportionality, and the reasons are very clear: the Member States are the only ones competent to regulate vocational and training systems, so giving the Commission any power to be part of this process implies a break with the principle of subsidiarity.  In addition, there are delicate professions, such as those related to health, that should not be included in this test. In addition, there is already a review of proportionality in regulations, and it is carried out ex post by the Court of Justice of the European Union, with the advantage that it does so for each individual case, for each rule which is believed to violate the principle of proportionality. More words, the criteria in Parliament's proposal are de extracted precisely from the Court's judgments.  The idea of a common test is therefore problematic in terms of competencies at all levels. That is why, of course, it was rejected in the Committee on Employment.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, no, national decisions on restricting access to regulated professions are not moral faults. National action is virtuous when it comes to limiting the effects of the European Union's action and its permanent deregulation, and far more legitimate in defending the interests of Europeans. National action is necessary through the imperatives of seeking the common good, it aims to protect strategic professions in the service of the citizen and for his protection. The unfair and savage competition generated by the destruction of these balances is the only horizon you offer our fellow citizens. This relationship forces the hand of the member countries by censoring unjustifiable and intolerable national action. The control of proportionality is a real guardianship, an assumed self-censorship and a new renunciation of France, since its authorities have just recommended the adoption of this procedure. This concept of limited democracy increasingly threatens the health, strength and strength of our nations. Be sure that the European Union's contempt for common sense and the ever-increasing interference will be the markers of the upcoming elections, and we trust the European voters who are showing common sense. We recently saw it in Italy.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: –  Madam President, thank you very much. I would like to congratulate my colleague Andreas Schwab for the work done on this dossier and for the compromise he reached in the negotiation. In the EU, qualification requirements can differ widely between Member States, resulting, among other things, in fragmentation of the single market. The proposed introduction of a proportionality test before adoption of a new regulation on professionals will on the one hand harmonise activities within the EU and on the other hand deepen the single market for services and foster growth.  I come from a country, Romania, and myself I studied medicine, where health professionals are very well trained but choose to leave the country for better jobs. Knowing the specificity of this profession, I think that the rapporteur is right to propose the creation of a specific status for healthcare professions. I fully agree that the Member States should take due account of the objective of ensuring a high level of requirements for healthcare professions, such as reserve activities, protected professional title, continuous professional development and rules relating to geographical distribution or the organisation of the profession, professional ethics and supervision, while respecting the minimal training conditions as laid down in Directive 2005/36/EC. In conclusion, with all the improvements from the work in the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) Committee and in other committees, this proposal will strengthen the internal market and will make our Union greater and stronger.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, very few thoughts. The freedom to practise professions, including health professions, and freedom of enterprise are fundamental prerequisites for enhancing human capital in a Europe that aims for growth, protecting the rights of both consumers, workers and professionals and also of the business system. In order to achieve this objective, it is necessary to prevent disproportionate and sometimes insurmountable obstacles from being put in place which limit their unreliability.  While it is true, as is true, that, in the absence of specific provisions aimed at harmonising the requirements for access to and pursuit of regulated professions, it is the Member States that take responsibility for their regulation, it cannot but be in line with the essential principles of non-discrimination and proportionality, thus tending towards homogenisation also with regard to the mechanism of mutual evaluation. And so the ex ante evaluation of regulations already in force or new regulations seems to us to be a fair and acceptable choice for the proper functioning of the market, which we want to be increasingly transparent and increasingly consumer protection.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: – Rules on regulated professions should be proportionate but also targeted. If they are not, this test will filter them out immediately. It is therefore a smart regulatory tool which gives us a strong push for the expansion of the European services market. I read in this legislation above all that the safety of the patient is important at all times and also that my own region, Flanders, deserves a wide freedom in the organization of its health professions. Compulsory Dutch language tests for doctors working in Flanders are therefore, in my view, perfectly in line with the principles that this new directive so emphatically emphasizes: qualitative, accessible and efficient healthcare.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are talking about a very important issue. This is evidenced by the figures quoted here: that there are 50 million people in regulated professions. But in every second speech I hear as if the justification appealing to the health service, to the doctors. And I don't know if it's a lack of knowledge or it's manipulation, because we have to remember that we're talking about thousands, thousands of different professions: locksmith, bricklayer, painter, not just doctor, lawyer or architect. And these thousands of professions, carried out by tens of millions of people, are terrible in the European Union, and especially in some Member States bureaucratic, overregulated. The effect is that it is to restrict access to these professions for young people, young apprentices, to restrict competition, and to restrict competition, of course, to increase prices, to reduce quality. I therefore like the direction of this directive, but together with it, in parallel, work should go in the European Union and the Member States towards deregulation, the reduction of bureaucracy related to regulated professions.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! It is good that we recognise professional competences across borders in the European Union. That is why, of course, the Member States must also comply with some common rules. It is perfectly fine for me that we update these rules in the new proportionality test and that we also strengthen transparency. But - and there is a but - because when it comes to health care and the rules for doctors and nurses and social and health assistants, etc., it is, in my opinion, the Member States themselves who should be able to decide how they regulate these professions. Health is something very special - it is a very special sector and the Member States organise this sector in very different ways. In addition, there is also the language barrier. That is why I am very annoyed that this proportionality test legislation did not exclude health. I don't think it should be part of the proportionality test. Health should face the market. I support the proposal in general because it is good that we are getting the rules updated.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am very critical of the Commission's proposal, as we know, for two reasons: firstly, I consider it unnecessary, unnecessary, and, secondly, I believe that it will not solve the problems that we certainly have in the European internal market. We already have proportionality criteria in Article 59(3) of the Professional Qualifications Directive, and there are a large number of decisions of the European Court of Justice which have reinterpreted these criteria in detail. We are not lacking in the legal framework, which already exists. I share the Commission's view that the Member States are indeed very inventive when it comes to foreclosing on their market, building market barriers – I fully share the analysis. But we will not solve the problem with ever new rules, but it must be done; it must then also be emphatic, it must be tackled vigorously by the Commission against known obstacles, and that is simply lacking. I do not believe that we are solving any problem with the recasting of this proportionality review directive. On the contrary, we are restricting some good regulation in the Member States. I would simply like the Commission, where it has become aware, that there are appropriate restrictions, obstacles and obstacles, to take a very strong approach against the Member States and to remove the obstacles. It would be ten times more sensible and efficient than creating new rules, as is now envisaged here.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteur for the quality of their work, which was all the more necessary because the Commission's initial proposal was of poor quality.  This criticism, moreover, applies to all the texts of the package on services, which all respond, in fact, to the same logic: under the guise of reviewing procedural aspects, whether on proportionality, but also on notifications or on the introduction of the professional card for services, we want to deprive Member States of the possibility of putting in place rules for regulated professions , rules which, it must be recalled, exist only because they correspond to compelling reasons of general interest as important as the health of Europeans, the safety of consumers or the protection of the environment. Fortunately, the work that has been carried out by Parliament limits or even eliminates the deregulatory aims of this text, in particular by recognising the specificity of the health professions or by recalling the primacy of sectoral rules and the principle of lex specialis, which must continue to apply. Once again, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the negotiating team here, in particular our shadow rapporteur, Sergio Cofferati.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! One of the fundamental freedoms in the European Union is the freedom to work and to do business. To make this possible, we should consistently remove all barriers to mobility and, above all, administrative barriers. Their existence is evidenced, for example, by the fact that only a small percentage of citizens still work outside their country of origin in the European Union. One of the barriers to mobility, not only between Member States, but also internal mobility, is the over-regulated rules on access to different professions. Very often they are a manifestation of protectionism, which in fact kills healthy competition and inhibits development. Such overregulation of professions, such as legal professions, also has negative effects on consumers, which is reflected in the high prices of legal or notarial services.  The assessment of regulated professions in European countries has shown that often national regulations are not based on sound and objective analysis. For this reason, the introduction of a mandatory proportionality analysis is extremely necessary. From here, I would like to express my deep support for this legislative initiative. The establishment of a common framework, the conduct of a proportionality test or the introduction of new rules governing professions will make greater use of the opportunities in the single market and facilitate access to professions. Unfortunately, this proposal has been criticised by many colleagues, including the Committee on Employment, which is why I would like to dispel a few myths about it. Member States will continue to decide for themselves how to regulate access to professions. The new directive will only introduce an obligation to carry out a test to show whether the new regulations are proportionate. The Directive fully respects the principle of subsidiarity and does not give the European Commission any additional instruments to block regulation at national level.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: – Mr President, thank you also to the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteur, Sergio Cofferati, for the great work they have done on this directive. It is true that we are receiving more and more complaints, especially from young workers who have trained themselves, who have learned languages to improve their employability, taking advantage of the advantages of the single market and the advantages of being in the European Union, and it is true that they often encounter, after this great training process, bureaucratic barriers to accessing these jobs in countries other than their own. Therefore, in this direction of improving employability and labour mobility, especially for young people, the progress of the proportionality test is well. But it is also true that there are certain professions, especially health professions, which already have, in the Professional Qualifications Directive, a special status which allows them to do so without losing a shred of the security they have to guarantee to citizens in the exercise of those professions. And it is true, therefore, that we are asking for the exclusion of health professions from the proportionality test, which we have not achieved, but we have also achieved in the context of the trilogous negotiations a compromise text which can improve that intermediate point in which, giving the greatest security to citizens, we also improve the employability of all workers in the European Union.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would also like to express my sincere thanks to Commissioner Bie kowska. We all know – as Angelika Niebler has already put it in a nutshell – that there is, of course, a risk here again, as with the General Data Protection Regulation, of creating an enormous bureaucracy, and that, of course, it is precisely this disproportionate application of bureaucracy in the Member States that poses a certain danger. We know gold plating is something that is very well received. I would therefore like to suggest that better regulation should be applied here in the sense that each Member State really carries out the SME test and, accordingly, makes it as simple and transparent as possible for member companies. I believe that the recognition of compulsory membership is a positive sign that, of course, the recognition of the master's examination – that is, this traditional dual system – is of the utmost importance to us and that subsidiarity can really be lived in this area. In this sense, I would like to see the Member States pay particular attention to ensuring that appropriate regulations are put in place in the health professions as well. We know that health tourism also plays an important role in Europe, and therefore the recognition of professional qualifications in proportionality is an important and right step in the right direction. With this in mind, I would like to thank all the colleagues involved. If implemented sensibly, it is a step in the right direction.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that the directive on the proportionality test, thanks to the work of my fellow Members, especially the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteur, should serve to help the national authorities to legislate better, not to prevent legitimate regulatory intervention by the Member States. Competent professionals fully integrated into the new digital dimension will in fact be crucial for Europe to remain competitive in the world and to protect our social model. In order to preserve a high quality of professional services, we therefore need policies to support, but above all a common, effective and proportionate regulatory framework. With this text, we have corrected a wrong approach by the Commission, which regarded any legislative intervention as an obstacle to economic growth. On the contrary, Madam President and Commissioner, I believe that we need to promote rules that, on the one hand, support healthy competition, young people's access to the world of work, growth and innovation, but at the same time protect the quality of the services provided, the objectives of the public interest and the final consumers.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, we should be happy that we have come to the end of these negotiations on a very important piece of legislation. The Directive on the proportionality test before adoption, a new regulation of professions, because this is legislation which improves the functioning of the internal market for services. There are a number of other obstacles on this market, and we should be happy that at least one of them will be reduced. I don’t share the concerns of some of the colleagues here that this is going to undermine the competences of national states. This is a good step forward which should be followed by other initiatives, but for at least for this one I would like to express my thanks to the Commission, and of course to our rapporteur, Andreas Schwab. We are talking about the obligation now imposed on Member States, before they introduce a new regulation on regulated professions, to check to what extent these new proposals are effective, and whether they do not go too far in simply imposing restrictive conditions for provision of services. This is a good day for the internal market for services, which has not been very lucky recently, and some of the initiatives have not been adopted by the Parliament. So for this reason, I express my joy and I would also like to express my thanks to all those who contributed to this final outcome.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I thank you for this proposal. I consider it a step in the right direction for an open internal market. In the EP, we have recently seen rather the opposite. Instead of breaking down administrative barriers, new obstacles are being created here, e.g. when approving the Posting of Workers Directive, this is indeed a demonstration. I personally believe that Europe needs, above all, protection against protectionist measures by the Member States and from social dumping from third countries. The IMCO Committee recently buried proposals on the e-card. It could have contributed at least a small step to a more functional market by easing administrative barriers. However, it has been shown that even the removal of these barriers can be seen by some states as an attack on their labour market.  I am therefore glad that, at least, we are giving this proposal from the package of services a chance, and I believe that a common framework for carrying out the proportionality test for all professions, including health services, will contribute to removing barriers to greater mobility of people, but will also contribute to strengthening the certainty and quality of professions carried out in the internal market. Thank you and I hope that this proposal will be approved.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, while an occupational regulation can be a means to safeguard consumer interest, it can often turn into a rent-seeking activity for powerful occupational groups, with harmful effects on labour markets. Indeed, in most cases, there are valid policy reasons to justify the regulation of professions, such as the need to ensure good performance or for security or safety reasons. However, data shows that this is not always the case. According to Business Europe, many activities are regulated in only a few Member States and more than 25% of them are regulated in just one Member State. From the perspective of the internal market, mobile workers represent a meagre 3.3% of the total workforce. Intra-European mobility is already made difficult by factors such as language, access to information, bureaucracy and social security provisions. Overregulation of some professions adds another layer of burden for mobile service providers. As a measure to prevent further fragmentation of the single market, the proposed proportionality test system is therefore very welcome.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs, colleagues who participated through amendments in improving the Commission's proposal. The report is very important and I hope it is voted on tomorrow. Of course there are professions - as was shown in today's debates - that had to be regulated.  With this regulation, I am convinced that cross-border work, recognition of qualifications will be made easier. States are free through this report to certify, but they must also report. At the same time, as the Schwab rapporteur said, there are trades, such as crafts, which should be regulated uniformly, as well as other trades. I believe that the report is balanced and can be voted on, and I hope that it will bring about an improvement for the internal market. We all want it developed and with very good professions and, of course, with a contribution to increasing competitiveness in the internal market.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the directive we are debating is particularly important, as it concerns at least 47 million people and 550 professions. The aim, of course, is to apply the principle of proportionality to the recognition of qualifications, at a stage particularly interesting for Greece, where now 500,000 Greek young scientists are abroad (400,000 young scientists from Portugal also abroad). All of them obviously want the opportunity to be recognised for their qualifications to work and have had to get away from the troika's policies. It is obvious that harmonisation is needed, and there is also a margin of appreciation that the Member States must have, especially in the health protection healthcare regime. Mrs Bieńkowska, I take note of the serious issue in Greece with the Qualifications Recognition Council, where in order to obtain equivalence in the professions it needs recognition. Unfortunately, the system is not working. We ask for your intervention in order to recognise the qualifications. Thousands of my fellow citizens are awaiting the decisions of this famous Agency.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I want to thank all the speakers who took the floor. Of course, I very much welcome the positive remarks. I listened carefully to the negative ones and to some concerns that honourable Members have. I would like once again to highlight the importance of this directive for the further improvement of the single market for services. This is one of the most important parts of our services package, and I am glad that, at least for now, we have this part of the package. I want to add that professional mobility is a right of EU citizens and I will echo some of you in saying that the vote tomorrow will be about values and freedoms, not just about professional services. So I hope that, with that vote tomorrow, you will support the compromise that has been reached in the proposal. I think it is a good compromise and I want to thank everyone involved and everyone who cooperated with us and with whom we reached this outcome.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 March 2008. Adopted on 16 June 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. Intelligent regulation of professions can strengthen economic growth in the Member States and in the EU as a whole, provided that this is not at the expense of the same professionalism, given that not all Member States have the same professional standards. The proportionality tests of the directive in question must therefore focus not only on the economic impact as a criterion in assessing the proportionality of the measures, but must ensure transparency, the high quality of the professional services provided and a high level of consumer protection, seeking to ensure a balance between the restrictions imposed on a fundamental freedom and the objective of public interest. Member States must be able to impose different requirements on access to certain professions, such as membership of professional organisations, continuing training and others, which may be important for achieving the objective of public interest. Service providers in regulated professions are already required to meet higher quality standards in terms of professional independence, education or lifelong learning. Consequently, these professions must be able to count on proportionate measures on the part of the Member States in which they provide services.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. – The European Union has managed to harmonise the requirements for various professions, such as brokers, auditors and others, in order to facilitate the free movement of workers across the EU and to unlock the full potential of the single market. Furthermore, the harmonisation of the professional services contributes to the higher protection of consumers. Although I support further unification, I believe a special status should apply to medical workers, due to the specificity of the healthcare system and a need to protect those services. The uniqueness of the public health system was confirmed by numerous rulings of the European Court of Justice, for example in the case Bressol and Others, dealing with the quotas for non-Belgian nationals in the francophone medical universities in Belgium. Therefore, such professions should be excluded from the scope of the proposal. Moreover, the directive sets the general obligations for Member States prior implementing additional restrictive measures. I welcome the addressing of this issue by the European Commission and an attempt to bring more clarity to the process. The Commission will be continuously assessing the national professional regulations and overview compliance with the existing EU legislation.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission (O-000044/2018 - B8-0026/2018) by Linda McAvan, on behalf of the Committee on Development, and the oral question to be answered to the Council by Linda McAvan on behalf of the Development Committee (O-000043/2018 - B8-0025/2018).

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: deputising for the author. – Madam President, I would like to speak on behalf of the Chair of the Committee on Development, Linda McAvan, because she cannot be here this evening. The Cotonou Agreement with the countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific concerns the Union’s cooperation with 78 countries. One in five of the world’s population lives in those countries, and the proportion is set to rise. No other EU partnership agreement has a similar geographic scope. The Cotonou Agreement covers trade, development, cooperation and the political dimension. It provides a detailed list of human rights and democratic principles that the parties must comply with. The agreement expires in February 2020 and negotiation must be launched by August this year. Many stakeholders have been consulted over the past two years and the partnership has been completely evaluated. Also, in the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly we have discussed the future of the cooperation beyond 2020. Also, our Parliament contributed to the reflection by a resolution prepared by my colleague Norbert Neuser, which was adopted in October 2016. This resolution stressed that the next agreement should maintain the acquis of the Cotonou Agreement, notably the legally-binding nature of the agreement, the political dialogue and the essential elements of respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms, democratic principles, the rule of law and good governance. Ahead of the adoption of the mandate, our Committee on Development thought it would be useful to present the EP priorities for the upcoming negotiations, taking into account the fact that Parliament needs to give its consent to the final agreement and that it should also be fully and regularly informed about the negotiations whilst they are ongoing. We understand that agreeing on the mandate within the Council is taking longer than expected and is proving difficult. Commissioner, Minister, as you have seen in the questions addressed to you, Parliament has a number of concerns, relating notably to the consequences of the shift towards regional compacts for the preservation of strong, overarching ACP cooperation. The question of the balance between the three regional components is also important in view of the enhanced partnership with Africa. Political dialogue is a fundamental part of the Cotonou Agreement and must remain a central and legal pillar of the overarching framework and at regional level. We believe that the effectiveness of the political dialogue should be improved, notably through better monitoring of the human rights situation in the partner countries. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular Sustainable Development Goal (STG) 17, stresses the need for true multi-stakeholder partnerships. There is a need for a reinforced role for parliaments, civil society and regional and local authorities, starting right from the phase of negotiating the new agreement. The new partnership is perceived as one going beyond aid, and going further than a recipient-donor relationship. This is very welcome. We insist on the need to put the 2030 Agenda, the SDGs and the European Consensus on Development at the heart of the future ACP-EU partnership. The eradication of poverty should remain a central element of this future agreement, and we should live up to the 2030 Agenda commitment ‘to leave no one behind’. With this debate, we would like to receive more information on the future institutional design and the future interplay between the Joint Council and the Joint Parliamentary Assembly (JPA). Let me take the opportunity to repeat the importance of strengthening the parliamentary dimension of the future agreement, guaranteeing real consultative power for the future overarching JPA and ensuring that it provides for open, democratic and comprehensive parliamentary dialogue. The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly is an innovative institution, and we should take the opportunity of the future agreement to consolidate its legitimacy. The European Parliament believes that the Assembly should be closely associated with the implementation of the agreement and that it should be regularly consulted on all matters of importance for the partnership. Last but not least, the ACP side has decided to widely disseminate the negotiating mandate of the ACP Group of States. Can the Presidency promise that the Council will publish the negotiating directives? Also, will the Commission publish textual proposals during the negotiations? I look forward to your answers, and thank you very much for your attention.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I am grateful for the question, which gives us the opportunity to discuss this very important topic. ACP-EU relations after 2020 have been high on the agenda of all the Presidencies in the past four years and the Bulgarian Presidency has had the privilege of taking the lead at this crucial moment. The Cotonou Agreement set a clear deadline for the start of the negotiations between the two parties and the Presidency spared no efforts to finalise the EU preparation process so that negotiations can open before the summer break. Our relations with the ACP countries are at an important juncture. We have all witnessed the significant changes since the signing of the Cotonou Agreement. The world, the European Union and the ACP themselves are no longer the same. Our own reality has become much more complex. The European Union has 13 Member States more than in 2000 and the ACP countries have also developed in various ways. Cooperation and interdependence at global level have gained even more importance in recent years, and relying on alliances is a key element of the European Union vision of multilateral values and principles on the international stage. The Council took the upcoming negotiations with the ACP as a clear opportunity to strive for a new framework that responds most effectively to these new challenges. I am happy to note that the European Parliament has shared this approach since the beginning. There was also a convergence of views from early on with the ACP side that the new framework needs to be adapted to the new reality so that we can address global challenges more efficiently. The 2030 sustainable development agenda will be the backbone of the new ACP-EU relationship. The EU position is therefore embedded in the European Consensus on Development and the new EU global strategy. The Council is in the very final stage of an extremely intense discussion process to agree the negotiating mandate. Its slant is commensurate with the importance we give to our future relations with the ACP states. With only one outstanding issue, by far the major part of the negotiating mandate is agreed. The Presidency is confident that the last outstanding issue can be resolved in the coming days so that the negotiations with the ACP side can be opened shortly. The vision of the European Union Member States is clear. We want to bring about a major change. Our aim is to leave behind the limitations of the donor-recipient relationship for good, and to open a new chapter with a bond between equal partners. Development, while an important part of our relations, should become one of the many areas of the complex, more political architecture. The ACP group has great aspirations and we are convinced that the two parties together can become a driving force on important global issues. Let me give you an example: in the area of climate change, our joint efforts have been exceptionally fruitful. The ACP-EU Council of Ministers adopted the ACP-EU Joint Declaration on Climate Change on 1 June, ahead of the upcoming conference in December. With Poland taking over the chairmanship of the Pre-COP from Fiji, this allows us to maintain joint ACP-EU efforts over two terms of office and to steer our common agenda further ahead. This successful example needs to be replicated in other areas of global importance. On the EU side, we are convinced that we can do it, and are putting all our energy into achieving this. The ACP-EU architecture is very complex and the different levels need to be readjusted to our new reality. The situation on the ground differs between the regions and countries, and regional and local players are gaining more and more importance. The EU intends to respond to this by shifting the centre of gravity and proposing tailor-made, action-orientated regional partnerships. We need to act at the most appropriate level, in line with the principle of subsidiarity, and to enhance the efficiency of the ACP-EU partnership. Our ambition is to agree on a more political framework with the ACP side. The new framework is intended to encompass all relevant matters of joint interest, such as human rights, fundamental freedoms, democracy, the rule of law and good governance, human development, sustainable and inclusive growth, peace, security and justice, as well as mobility and migration. It includes a strong commitment to the principle of leaving no one behind, which is not at all in contradiction with the objective of a modernised political partnership that goes beyond the traditional development-aid approach. It’s quite the opposite. Only a comprehensive political partnership will put us in a position to build peaceful, well-governed and prosperous states and societies by accelerating progress towards the attainment of the Sustainable Development Goals and thus to eradicate poverty and tackle discrimination and inequality. I would like to thank the honourable Members for Parliament’s valuable input and I count on your continued support as we pursue this important work.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Parliament and, in particular, Linda McAvan, Chair of the Committee on Development, and honourable Members Wenta and Neuser for their excellent work on this important matter. I welcome your resolution and the question on the upcoming negotiations of the partnership agreement between the European Union and the countries of the African, Caribbean and Pacific group of states. Your position on the way forward and that of the Commission are broadly aligned. We share the conviction that we need a legally binding agreement that is based on the essential elements of our existing partnership, namely respect for human rights, democratic principles, the rule of law and good governance. They are all part of the acquis and must be strengthened in the new agreement. I also agree with your call to preserve a strong ACP identity. Together, the European Union and ACP countries represent more than half of the UN membership. Such an alliance should be further exploited. Keeping the framework with 79 countries is fully compatible with having a tailored and strengthened approach to cooperation with the main regions. Africa will remain very much in focus in the years to come. The future EU-Africa pillar should build on the existing joint Africa-European strategy and use its institutional set-up. At the same time, the importance of our Caribbean and Pacific partners will also be confirmed. The institutional and political architecture of the new EU-ACP partnership agreement will be key to this. Each region should have a distinct governance and a focus on regionally relevant priorities for dialogue and cooperation. Political dialogue must be an integral part of the new partnership at all levels, including the ACP-wide level, the continental, regional and national levels, through the format most appropriate to the issues discussed. I also agree with your insistence that a core principle of the new partnership agreement should be a multi-stakeholder approach to dialogue and cooperation. Let me also reassure you that the new partnership will fully confirm the commitment to implement the UN 2030 agenda and its Sustainable Development Goals. Eradicating poverty and leaving no one behind will remain core aspects of our relationship with the ACP countries, which will cover all topics on which there are mutual interests. I also agree with you that the role of parliaments should be reinforced. Regional parliaments, in particular, should be stronger, matching the increased prominence of EU-Africa, EU-Caribbean and EU-Pacific regional councils in the future ACP-EU agreement. As regards the rhythm of meetings, the Commission has proposed that the ACP-EU Council should be convened on an ad hoc basis. The Joint Parliamentary Assembly should work closely with the ACP Council of Ministers, according to those same principles. Lastly, concerning publication of the negotiating directives, the Commission has suggested that the Council publish the final EU negotiating directive. It is ultimately up to Council itself to decide what it considers the most appropriate course to follow. Our counterparts in the ACP group adopted their negotiating mandate a few days ago at the ACP Ministerial Council in Lomé. Now it’s up to the Council of the European Union to adopt ours. I look forward to the debate on this important topic.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, since time is running out, I would like to say essentially three things. First of all, if there is a reason to maintain the EU/ACP framework that we are currently experiencing, it would be for strategic reasons, because between the two blocs, if I dare say so, we represent a majority of The Member States of the United Nations, and I find that at present and in view of the other factors involved, particularly in the countries benefiting from development cooperation, it might be worth reminding those countries which are our partners that the attitude towards Europe would logically be a privileged attitude. Secondly, I would like us not to get totally lost in the frills. The involvement of civil society and all that is fine, but at the end of the day, what is important is that, particularly in the African part of the partnership, we are in the presence of stable, functioning states with which a partnership for development makes sense. I cannot develop anything, for example, in the Central African Republic until the state exists, and it is not civil society alone that will help me; unfortunately, I would need troops, troops that we refused, weapons that we refused to the Central African government. Finally, as far as Africa is concerned, there is a dichotomy that we will have to resolve. The Pan-African Parliament covers the entire continent and we will need to determine how to integrate our special relationship with Africa into the overall relationship with the ACP region. The north of Africa is not necessarily a problem, but a hitherto absent element and must be somehow integrated, which leads me to believe that the focus in the future will have to be on a strategic relationship with the whole of Africa in any case.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, since the cotonou Agreement was adopted in 2000, and even since its revisions in 2005 and 2010, the world has changed quite a bit. New players have appeared in a certain global mess and I am sure that now, in reviewing our next stage, we must take into account three fundamental objectives. First, strengthen political dialogue. Many of the actors in the ACP group are now relevant in the multipolar world, and the European Union shares strategic objectives in this world management with them. Second, contributing to the economic development of many of these countries, most of which are in poverty and in need of investment, need the capacity to provide opportunities for their citizens.  Third, cooperate with them to meet sustainable development goals. Together we are more than half of the United Nations and together we can move forward, reducing poverty and, if we do, we will have made great progress in the whole world. Of course, we call for a greater presence of parliamentary scrtrolling in the implementation of the new Cotonou Agreement; we want to maintain the structure of the GPA, but at the same time highlight regional integration within its field; we want to increase accountability and there are two fundamental points I want to refer to.  The most important is that we cannot condition cooperation with these countries on meeting our demands on migration policies. We have to fight poverty, and that means not conditioning our help.  The second element, of course, is to respect human rights and make them the axis of our cooperation.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, Commissioner, the main objective of strong cooperation between the EU and the AKE countries is to eradicate poverty and promote the sustainable economic, cultural and social development of partner countries by progressively integrating their economy into the world economy. Both the EU and the ACP countries should benefit from this exchange of experience between them. The negotiating mandate for the future agreement between the EU and the ACP countries was adopted two weeks ago in Togo. In this context, the fundamental principles of the Cotton Partnership Agreement must be maintained and form part of our future treaty.  Supporting and promoting human rights and democratic principles, developing policies to build peace and enhance security in vulnerable areas, promote democracy, tackle migration and climate change, combat terrorism and, finally, address food insecurity are fundamental issues that need to be addressed. Political dialogue must remain a central pillar in the overall context of the new agreement, while the principles of effective development cooperation must be fully integrated into the new ACP-EU Partnership Agreement. Finally, on a practical level, I firmly believe that the EU must play a central role in educating and cultivating skills for the peoples of the ACP countries, while supporting them to stay in and work for their countries. Thank you, Madam President, for your patience. I would also like to thank the interpreters who have the patience to support us in our work despite the problems they face themselves.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, Cotonou has had the immense merit of combining development aid, trade and the political character of our relations. These elements of the spirit of this historic agreement must, of course, not only be preserved, but from my point of view, ambitiously amplified in a legally binding agreement. We have no right to miss this unique opportunity that should allow us to finally be genuine political partners. Partners whose destinies would be irretrievably and for the better linked economically, environmentally, industrially, ethically and politically. I am thinking of real gender equality policies, a human and legal migration policy, the consolidation of regal states whose authority and legitimacy could no longer be arbitrarily questioned. So Commissioner, I can of course understand the proposal for a pillar structure headed by a coordination dome. Basically, it is a little bit like continuing what exists today. But I cannot help but see the risk of maintaining our relations with Africa, especially in too narrow a straitjacket. We could very well ensure that the Pacific and the Caribbean are integrated into their natural geographical, cultural and historical reality. I am one of those who believe that the creation of a vast free trade area covering both continents and in accordance with the current bilateral association agreements would be an effective response to the uncertainties that disfigure the morale of Africans and Europeans. The resulting prosperity, Commissioner, would offer African and European youth an unprecedented prospect of economic and democratic development. In my view, this would be the real and only solution to the difficulties we have in managing migration phenomena. I see no better way to support the immigration pact initiated by UN Secretary-General Antonio Gutierrez. Beyond that, I totally agree with Mr Engel's argument that such an alliance would, of course, offer the world a much greater positive influence. This vision of the Cotonou accords would finally deprive the sordid populists of all stripes of their cynical arguments and their rhetoric...  (the speaker is interrupted by the President) ... so I finish, I finish, and I repeat what I have to say! This vision of the Cotonou Accords would finally deprive the sordid populists of all stripes of their cynical arguments and their deadly rhetoric.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the European Union is renewing the Cotonou Agreement. It is this agreement that regulates our relations with some eighty countries in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, including the most impoverished countries in the world. Cotonou is a very large agreement, but after almost twenty years it has not reversed the situation of extreme vulnerability of these countries to the globalized economy; rather, Africa is still condemned to be a mere provider of natural resources. Industry still does not develop despite its wealth in natural resources, inequality continues to increase, food security is a chimera and human rights and environmental violations by our European companies continue to occur with total impunity. Therefore, the new agreement must address some principles that ensure the necessary coherence between fair trade relations and the right to development. We must place the agreement within the framework of the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement on Climate Change. We must incorporate the gender perspective in a cross-cutting way, end the unsustainable exploitation of natural resources, develop the Transparency Directives for our companies, which must pay taxes where appropriate and be responsible for all their actions abroad. We must promote small industry and family farming, which feeds the world, and we must not condition our aid on our own interests. We have a precious challenge ahead of us— and I'm done— to make the European Union a true exporter of human rights, even more so in those regions where we have sheared for centuries. On that path, you will find the support of my group.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Madam President, Commissioner, in the Council, the differences between Member States are such that the Cotonou agreement could be null and void in 2020 without a new text being negotiated. The ongoing post-Cotonou negotiations are symptomatic of the impasse in the European Union. Article 218 of the TFUE is very clear on the procedure for negotiating agreements. I quote: 'the Council rules unanimously for association agreements'. That is why, in the Council, Hungary blocked the negotiating mandate on 22 May because of a disagreement on the migration issue. Then on 24 May, several Member States opposed the compromise text that would have lifted Hungary's opposition. Let us open our eyes, ladies and gentlemen, and understand that it is also because the European treaties are only unanimously amended, in accordance with Article 48 of the TUE, that we defend Frexit so that our country can act freely.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, our resolution is very positive on inter-parliamentary cooperation and is aimed at this cooperation. But we are saying only banalities about aid policies - involving civil society, good governance, fighting corruption - forgetting how to make African states actors in their development, as has been done in China, Singapore and once in our countries. By budgeting the EDF, we are removing the intergovernmental nature essential to efficiency and good cooperation according to the principle of subsidiarity. What is more serious is the spirit of Lomé focused on co-development, which called for privileged agreements for the purchase of raw materials, which demanded a certain protectionism to develop employment and activity on the spot, this spirit, already partly abandoned with the Cotonou agreements, we forget and even condition our aid to the opening of markets; we are destroying the local African economy.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, can I say to the Commissioner that what strikes me most about this issue is that it is certainly not an agreement between equals. This should be a policy towards a level playing field, but when you read the fine detail the ACP countries will be lucky to get the scraps from the EU’s table, whilst the EU ensures continued access to cheap raw materials whilst holding ACP states to difficult high standards of behaviour if they wish to continue receiving foreign aid from Brussels. Can you imagine what would happen to an ACP country for behaving like, say, Spain has done over the issue of Catalan independence? Substitute Catalonia for any other independence movement and suddenly the EU’s hypocrisy becomes embarrassingly obvious. This report is nothing more than a form of blatant neo-colonialism. We should be supporting initiatives to enable ACP countries to prosper, not to make them further dependent on aid regimes that have never worked, nor ever will, in their long-term best interests.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The Cotonou Agreement has put the relationship of the European Union and its Member States with the 79 African, Caribbean and Pacific countries on a comprehensive footing. This agreement expires in 18 months' time. I do not think there is much time left to negotiate the continuation of the current agreement or a recast. It is all the more regrettable that in May the Council did not give the Commission a negotiating mandate and that negotiations could not begin on 1 June as planned. The ACP's partners are already prepared. Since the beginning of the Cotonou Agreement in 2000, development has not stopped. China, for example, has long overtaken Europe in influence in many ACP countries. The Cotonou Agreement is not only intended to promote trade relations and development cooperation, but also to promote political dialogue and the treatment of human rights issues. The European Development Fund, as the main financial instrument for development cooperation with the ACP countries, is also limited to 2020. Parliament is calling for the Fund to be continued, albeit as a specific part of the EU budget. There are still many questions to be asked about the further development of the EU's relations with the ACP countries. We have set them out here in our oral question. They belong quickly answered. I would like to say a few words to my fellow Members: the next week will be the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. I hope that this time more colleagues from the European Parliament will take part than at the last meetings. We owe it to our colleagues from the ACP countries.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the opening of negotiations for the new partnership agreement between the European Union and the African, Caribbean and Pacific states represents a great opportunity to improve the characteristics of the Cotonou Agreement and contribute to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. The eradication of poverty, respect for human rights, economic and social development and the integration of the ACP States into the global economy must remain beacons in the new negotiation. At the same time, today's challenges embodied by the UN 2030 Agenda and the African Union's 2063 Agenda must also be highlighted in the new agreement: sustainable development, the fight against climate change, the definition of legal immigration routes and the promotion of peace. We have stressed, even today, the role that immigration plays in the European context. The new agreement between the ACP countries and Europe cannot deal with immigration only in terms of return. An ambitious holistic policy must be put in place to enable us to work towards eradicating poverty and the root causes of immigration.  On the future agreement, strengthening the parliamentary dimension is a necessity. We urge that the political dialogue be strengthened to guarantee the democratic importance of our activities. That is why we welcome the possibility of involving the opposition and civil society in regular ACP-EU meetings. We must work more and more with citizenship and towards citizenship. Implement and strengthen youth and gender policies, build a system that allows for monitoring of respect for human rights, taking into account the reports of civil society. Respect for and promotion of fundamental human rights have been the cornerstone of the Cotonou Agreement and must also be the basis on which to build the future agreement.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Thank you, Mrs Kyenge. Indeed, the intention was simply to emphasise that, for the sake of interpreters, we need to speak a little slower, and I hope that others will remember that too.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Have you ever been to Kiribati in the Pacific? Do you know the Caribbean island of Samana? Have you ever been to Bangui, capital of the Central African Republic? Commissioner Mimica, you know that development work in these three regions has about as much to do with each other as apples, rice and sweet potatoes. This also brings us to a core problem in our ACP policy, and Unfortunately I do not see any fundamental change in the post-Cotonou process either. We need a strong regionalisation of the ACP. Let us devote ourselves intensively to Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific – together, but still separately! Let us pursue our development policy pragmatically, not ideologically! Let us support projects on the ground instead of the budget of corrupt regimes in palaces, and let us create funds to finance development, to prevent flight! Let us dare the financial transaction tax! Do we have more courage than Macron and Scholz combined! Let us tax the actions of the super-rich to help the poorest! That is what I want for the future of the ACP.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Madam President, last week, on the occasion of the European Development Days, I had the opportunity to meet the Guinean Minister for Foreign Affairs, who told me that he will be the future chief negotiator for the ACP and that the ACP group has already adopted its mandate. Then we had a discussion with several people about why a mandate is being adopted in the European Union and I said that we could ask the Commission who it is. A response is rarely answered because the Commission is not a fan of blaming and shaming. That is why I ask you, the representative of the Commission, whether the following States agree with the mandate as proposed, including the United Kingdom, Ireland, Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, France, Spain, Malta, Cyprus, Greece, Italy, Bulgaria, Romania, , Croatia, Slovenia, Austria, Germany, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Portugal. You do not seem to contradict me, so I infer that Hungary is blocking these negotiations.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the future relationship with the countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific must be based, first of all, on respect for the independence and sovereignty of states, with respect for the will of each people. The ballast of centuries of oppression and colonial domination has not disappeared. He's alive in his current relationships. Asymmetric interdependence, unequal development are realities that must make us place at the center of this relationship, development cooperation, the fight against poverty, inequalities and social injustices. Instead of seeking to export models of state and economic organisation, the European Union must respect the legitimate options and priorities of the ACP countries. Instead of seeking to perpetuate the dominance relations, for which instruments such as the so-called Economic Partnership Agreements compete, the European Union must recognise the specific needs of the ACP countries and the negative impact on them on policies of liberalisation and deregulation of international trade. Instead of trying to divide to be united, the European Union must respect the unity and cohesion of the ACP countries.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, until now, the Cotonou Agreement has been based on three pillars: development cooperation, political and economic cooperation and trade cooperation. There has been total failure on trade policy. Some EU countries have set up neo-colonialist agreements, in which only sustainable measures on human rights, new social standards and environmental protection were put into words, but in fact trade liberalisation has been fuelled by imposing our products, such as new medicines, such as processed products or advanced technology products such as mobile phones, at great cost. While this was happening, these countries, particularly France, raided raw materials, from rare materials in congo to fishery products in Senegal, fuels in Nigeria, uranium in Niger, blood diamonds in Serra Leone and cocoa in Côte d'Ivoire. Political cooperation should have been one of the cornerstones of the Cotonou Agreement, but until now it has not led even remotely to the stability that we were all looking for. On the contrary, it seems to us that insecurity is being nurtured and even encouraged in such a way as to finance the business of arms sales and also that of migrants. In the negotiations, it must be stressed that political dialogue is a fundamental aspect of the Cotonou Agreement and that it must remain a central pillar in the general legal framework. If we want to do only trade policies without thinking about the situation of rights and without significant involvement of civil society in dialogue at all levels, the new agreement will also fail like the previous one. As far as cooperation and development are concerned, I am not afraid to say that they are in fact limited to the intergovernmental dimension alone, which is beyond the control of parliaments and civil society. The meetings of the ACP-EU joint institutions, and in particular of the Joint Council of Ministers, have produced very little concrete results and experienced unfortunately minimal and low-level participation. Development cooperation should have had the primary objective of erasing poverty. Unfortunately, none of this has happened. We hope that the new agreement will seriously affirm conditionality in respect for human rights and genuinely strengthen political dialogue, giving concrete instruments to defend the common values of the ACP-EU partnership.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support I will add three specific points to Parliament's position. Firstly, we are calling for a genuine multi-actor partnership in the future, but this time we are not referring to the different religious communities, even though without them there is clearly no social stability and fight against poverty in most ACP countries. Think specifically of the great mediation role of the Catholic Episcopal Conference in Congo, which is helping to create one of the worst humanitarian crises in the world. I would also like to send a message to the Council and the Commission: in the new agreement, we cannot leave churches out of the structure of EU-ACP cooperation. Secondly, the human rights situation needs to be improved. Yes, that's right, I can only agree. We must have zero tolerance for systems that trample on individual or collective freedom. In the future, it is out of the question to make business dealings with such regimes. Finally, I would like to argue with point 19 of the EP decision, which is very problematic for me. The ideological approach to migration, the planned immigration, simply deceiving people, instead of the absolute primacy of helping people in trouble locally, they send false messages. They are deceived by the promise of inclusion, employment opportunities, integration. It is a slap in the face to the extreme confusion between the situation of refugees and migrants. Why? Because this is a major impediment to solving the huge refugee crisis around the world.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the European Union's relationship with the Community of African, Caribbean and Pacific countries is surely the most strategic, veteran and experienced of those maintained by the European Union. Four Lomé Conventions and the 2000 Cotonou Agreement, as revised in 2005 and 2010, are more than enough experience to learn and extract the consequences.  I would like to emphasize strengthening political cooperation, institutional training for strengthening judicial powers, ensuring the separation of powers and guaranteeing human rights and also the fight against corruption and, of course, the parliamentary dimension, because that is what the European Union and Africa, Caribbean and Pacific Parliamentary Assembly is all about , exactly to strengthen accountability, accountability, and the responsibility of countries in their political practices. But I would also like to point out that it is not acceptable to link this strengthening of cooperation to the migration issue, let alone its conditionality to the return policy. This is simply out of the question.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Today we are working on renewing the Cotonou Agreement. After eighteen years of operation, today half of the ACP states are still among the least developed countries in the world. Their combined share of world trade is less than 5% and their share of global GDP is only 2%. Today, the most serious problem is uncontrolled migration, which is a huge threat to the development of the ACP states, as young, strong and courageous people leave their homelands, who could influence the development of their homelands. I agree with the call for more effective mechanisms for return and readmission strategies. The European Union should support the ACP States on the ground and stimulate their economies.
