The representatives of the ACP countries say this to us, the representatives of the European Union: Do you want to make the strongest, the youngest, the most courageous leave Africa, so that Africa really becomes an dying continent? Unfortunately, this ill-thought-out migration policy is bearing fruit.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: -Dear Chairman, Dear Commissioner, I expect today's debate to contribute to more effective negotiations on a new partnership agreement between the European Union and a group of African, Caribbean and Pacific countries. The European Union must seize the opportunity offered to it in these negotiations on a new partnership agreement after Cotonou and put development assistance as a major instrument of public diplomacy.  The development assistance provided by the European Union must have greater visibility and serve as a tool for a more effective foreign policy. This will prevent security threats resulting from ignorance of solidarity expressed from the European Union towards countries whose democracies are in search of consolidation and stability. Renewed cooperation between the European Union and a group of african, Caribbean and Pacific countries must contribute to achieving peace and stability globally. With these countries, the European Union fosters deep historical ties as well as a privileged partnership.  Work needs to be worked together to manage labour migration more efficiently, increase student flow and mobility, facilitate business investment programmes and act more intensively against a network of smugglers and traffickers. In order to prevent, it is necessary to improve the collection and exchange of information, as well as to strengthen the resilience of societies and economies in crisis countries.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by However, it seems that the European Union's policy towards the ACP states is a failure, fortunately one of the few failures of the European Union in foreign policy.  Almost twenty years of operation of the Agreement, about forty years of operation of the ACP Group, and what achievements do we have there? Room? No , these are very often places of bloody wars. Democracy? It would rarely be possible to sign the thesis that it reigns there. Human rights? They are often only on paper. Economic development? It is difficult to comment on this at all.  I may stress this too emphaticly, but it is precisely to make all those involved in this agreement aware that the mistakes of these almost twenty years cannot be duplicated. A new contract cannot be implemented in the same philosophy. In my opinion, one of the reasons for the failure of our policy towards the ACP countries is that it was, as some have argued here, based on the objective of aid. So as only aid is used, it is very often – I do not want to say only, but very often – only funds, capital, and therefore not only money, but also energy, time, etc. are squandered. In my opinion, the new agreement should be created on the basis of building partnerships to achieve certain objectives, it should not just be aid. Please note that, after all, the actions of the United States or, more recently, China are more effective, although in a shorter period of time. But these countries are not focused on aid, but on achieving certain objectives and, in my opinion, this is the pattern that we should adopt in this relationship.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the new agreement must be deeply rooted in the 2030 Agenda, with a mechanism to monitor the progress made by both sides in implementing the new Sustainable Development Goals. Particular attention must be paid to what were the essential elements of Cotonou: respect for human rights and democratic principles and the rule of law, which must remain the basis of cooperation. I would add the major issue of combating tax evasion and avoidance, of which developing countries are already paying the highest price. On immigration, we call on the Council and the Commission not to continue along the shameful path that has recently been taken to make aid conditional on greater border control. Unfortunately, the proposal seems to us to be too unbalanced towards returns and says little or nothing about the opening up of legal immigration channels. Let us work to ensure that the new partnership does not abandon its commitment to the fight against poverty and is an instrument for addressing needs and protecting rights and for sustainable development that really leaves no one behind.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, in a world marked by uncertainty and the fluidity of geopolitical relations, the negotiations of this EU-ACP partnership agreement are an opportunity to establish a matrix of cooperation based on respect for autonomy, human rights, civil society participation and sustainability, principles that are crucial for humanistic and just globalisation. It is also important to ensure that the blocs maintain a global position without prejudice to the specific approach to negotiation.  Eu-ACP cooperation must be a reference for the multiple partnerships the world needs, allocated resources that promote decent and sustainable development, helping to reduce forced migration and the phenomena of poverty and extreme inequality that are eroding 21st century cities. And the resolution we are discussing here today is a commitment by the European Parliament to this future agenda.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, as an active member of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, I have witnessed the importance of this framework. For post-Cotonou, I trust the Council will negotiate an EU-ACP relationship anchored in upholding the values of democracy, human rights, gender equality and the rule of law; one which will enable a vibrant and active civil society, including the work of human rights defenders. For instance, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, all Lucha and Filimbi members should be released, as should detained human rights defenders. The focus of our work with our partners at governmental and parliamentary level should be to ensure human dignity is respected everywhere. A strong focus on culture and education is also crucial. We need to make sure that intercultural dialogue becomes a key component of the ACP framework in order to use people-to-people contact as a means of achieving peace and prosperity. I also believe it is crucial to include a strong parliamentary dimension in order to strengthen the democratic foundation of our unique partnership.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the negotiations in the post-Cotonou partnership agreement represent an opportunity to renew EU and ACP relations in order to meet the common challenges we face. While welcoming the general architecture for future cooperation between the ACP Group and the European Union proposed by the Commission, I would like to stress that the 2030 sustainable development agenda, the sustainable development goals, and the European consensus for development must form the core of the future partnership. In addition, it is essential that the fight against poverty remains a central element of the new agreement, as well as conditions for respect for human rights, including explicit references to accountability, the monitoring and review mechanism in the event of non-compliance. Similarly, it is essential to involve civil society in the political dialogue and I reiterate that its full participation should be a binding element of the partnership. In conclusion, I stress the importance of strengthening the parliamentary dimension of the future agreement by ensuring that the future Joint Parliamentary Assembly (APP) ensures an open, democratic and comprehensive parliamentary dialogue.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, the partnership agreement between the European Union and Africa-Caribbean-Pacific is extremely important, and today we need to reposition ourselves within the framework of a European Africa-Caribbean-Pacific agreement. It is true that today, if we ask European citizens about Cotonou, post-Cotonou, I think there will be few citizens who know exactly what we are talking about. Ditto for the citizens of Africa or the Caribbean or the Pacific who, if questioned, will not know exactly what we are talking about. The first challenge that we Europeans and our partners face is to ensure that what is in these agreements is known to all; I agree with my predecessors who have said that civil society must be involved in these agreements, in the context of the discussion of these agreements, that there should be an appropriation of the process by civil society for the negotiation of these future agreements. I think it is important that the people of Europe and the people of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific are properly informed of what we are doing. Second, the work we have to do at the parliamentary level is also important; perhaps, perhaps, we have things to improve in this regard to ensure that between parliamentarians we can also set a number of priorities, because priorities and challenges for the European continent and the African continent, the Caribbean and the Pacific are important. Environmental challenges, demographic and population challenges, the challenges of the use of wealth, transparency and governance are challenges that we have in common with these different countries and with the countries of the European Union. I am a little sad today that when we address these countries, we only do so with the concern of migration, when that same migration is actually a wealth that we must share with these countries. So I think that the future of Cotonou is also the fact of being able to project ourselves in a common future with all these countries and I hope that we will all succeed together in this challenge.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the European Union's political and economic relations with the ACP countries must be built on the principles of mutual benefit. But, on the one hand, in Africa, European multinationals are grabbing the resources of wealth, grabbing the land, exploiting the cheap labour of millions of workers and competing with the Chinese to create food monopolies. On the other hand, the huge import of agricultural products from Africa into the European Union dissolves the European agricultural economy, dissolves all protection that exists in products of designation of origin, such as feta cheese, as well as in products with geographical designation and origin. The failed model of Industrial European exports and agricultural African imports is complemented by millions of illegal refugees and illegal immigrants entering the European Union. Concrete measures must be taken to protect human rights, child labour and the exploitation of women must be prohibited and at the same time the principles of the Cotton Agreement must be applied.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, if the objective of eradicating poverty in the ACP countries is sincere, a new framework of relations is needed to put an end to the current situation where the European Union imposes totally unequal agreements which allow it to continue to plunder its riches, natural resources and fisheries banks and allow us to continue land grabbing and also with its agricultural markets.  I believe that the agreements between the European Union and the ACP countries have not contributed to the development of these countries because they perpetuate the situation of poverty and misery, because they seek only cheap raw materials, low labour costs and lax environmental regulations and open the borders for multinational corporations to market these products with reduced tariffs or zero tariffs. A new relationship framework is urgently needed that truly seeks development, seeks an end to poverty and is based on the sovereignty and respect of these peoples.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am ingesting defence policy, security policy, and that is how I look at Africa: from the point of view of conflicts, threats, but also , unfortunately, those most drama-like events that are not lacking in Africa. And I must say that I also believe, like my colleague Joachim Zeller, that a legal framework, a political framework, is needed in order to be truly effective in responding to the events that are happening in Africa. And I also support the diagnosis expressed by Adam Sheikhfeld that, in fact, today we cannot be satisfied with what we are getting in Africa, either from a security point of view, from a social point of view, from an economic point of view, or from the point of view of stabilising the situation where we have achieved something. I would very much like the European Parliament, the European Union, when preparing the new framework for the agreement, to bear in mind the most important objectives to be achieved and to apply new techniques or new methods of stabilising and improving the situation in Africa. Otherwise, we will only spend money to reassure our conscience.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we are all aware of the crucial importance of the ACP-EU partnership, the great progress made in the fight against poverty that has been made and the great and enormous challenges that we still face. From this point of view, we are reflecting on the countless variants that may relate to the new partnership, all of which are important, but we must not forget what I believe is the most crucial aspect, namely funding. The budgetisation of the European Development Fund is to be welcomed, but as long as its destination remains preserved. What transpires about the new proposal for a neighbourhood, development and international cooperation instrument, however, does not reassure us at all, quite the contrary. It transpires that the binding allocation of development funds will be sacrificed on the altar of flexibility and that the fight against poverty will give way in the hierarchy of priorities to the defence of the interests of the European Union. We can design the best possible ACP-EU partnership, but if we do not ensure that the funds earmarked for its funding are not diverted, we will have lost the most important development game and the consequences will unfortunately still be felt for decades to come.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – The new negotiations offer an opportunity to modernise the partnership between the EU and the ACP countries. The Commission's proposal for three regional partnerships with the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries is therefore a very welcome and worth supporting basis and also strengthens the strategic objectives of both countries. For its part, the European Parliament has called for human rights as one of the cornerstones and has also emphasised the promotion of equality and the fight against climate change. I would like the future partnership agreement to see three things more strongly. Firstly, a clear reference to and measurement of the new Sustainable Development Goals and the partnership agreement. The second is a stronger grip on women's rights. The third is the promotion of the circular economy, starting above all in a waste-free society.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to underline that what is at stake in the upcoming negotiations for a new partnership agreement with the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries is ultimately the role of the European Union as a global actor. It is my hope that the Council will shortly adopt a decision to entrust the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy with the negotiation of objectives, strategic priorities and modalities whereby the EU can achieve such a global player’s role with its ACP partners. Let me conclude by assuring you that Parliament will be immediately and fully informed at all stages of the negotiation procedure. I am looking forward to continuing our fruitful collaboration, and I remain certain that Parliament will continue working to ensure that the European Union keeps on standing up for its values.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I am grateful for this interesting exchange. It shows a convergence of views on our side that the future ACP-EU partnership needs to be adapted to the new needs. This convergence is also due to the work of the European Parliament and the regular exchanges between all of us in the process of preparing the EU negotiating mandate. While we need to build on the achievements of the Cotonou framework, it is imperative that the future framework take better account of the interests, needs and challenges of the different regions on the ACP side. Concerning the questions from Mr Wenta and some other honourable Members, I would like to say that the Presidency will continue its efforts to allow the Council to adopt its mandate as soon as possible, in order for the negotiations to start as envisaged. The Council will make its decision on publication of the negotiating directives after we have agreed on the final text. The negotiation process will be crucial. The Council will contribute, within the limits of its role, to its successful progress and will continue its exchanges on this important topic with the European Parliament.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I have received one motion for a resolution pursuant to Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, June 14, 2018.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the implementation and follow-up of the EU framework for national Roma integration strategies (2018/2743(SDR)).

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for this opportunity to address the situation of Europe’s Roma, our largest ethnic minority. Many Roma still face deep poverty, social exclusion and racial discrimination. We have a common duty to ensure decent life chances for all our citizens and we must pay special heed to those who find themselves in the most vulnerable situations.  This is a topic that goes to the heart of our common European values. Equal treatment and equal opportunities should be enjoyed by all of us. Sadly, in Europe, in the 21st century, this is not yet the case. It has already been seven years since the Council, the Commission and Parliament joined their voices to call for action to improve the situation of the Roma. Back in 2011, we launched the EU Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies. Parliament and the Commission took the first steps and I’m glad to recall that the Council swiftly endorsed the framework and the European Council called for its rapid implementation. The Member States duly prepared their national strategies and began putting the framework into practice.  I’m also happy to note that, in its mid-term report published last year, the Commission was able to confirm the added value of the framework. It is particularly encouraging to read that the participation of Roma children in early childhood education is on the rise and that poverty is falling. There are definite signs that the implementation of the framework is bearing fruit.  But let us be honest, we have not yet managed to end the discrimination, the deep poverty and the long-term disadvantages that have weighed on Roma communities. There is no room for complacency. If anything, we must redouble the efforts to put things right and to offer the same life chances to all citizens, regardless of their ethnic origin.  This is why the Bulgarian Presidency has put an important emphasis on issues at the heart of advancing the agenda in this area. The Council is expected to adopt a set of conclusions on the early childhood development later this month. The focus has been put on promoting and protecting children’s rights, combating child poverty and social exclusion and providing all children with equal opportunities, irrespective of their social, cultural, ethnic or other backgrounds.  Member States should continue to provide multi-disciplinary support to children and families from disadvantaged backgrounds, such as Roma children. Investing in early childhood education and care is of high importance, not only for reducing inequalities at a young age, but also for preventing the risk of poverty and exclusion in adulthood by laying the foundations for successful lifelong learning, social integration and employability.  The European Parliament has worked tirelessly to keep this topic on the agenda. In matters where our common values are clearly spelt out in the Treaty yet Union competences are limited, strong political voices are needed to motivate us and to move us forward, so I thank you for helping us to keep the momentum.  The framework focuses on four main areas: education, housing, health and jobs. These are the matters we must address. No one in Europe should be denied the basic prerequisites for a decent life. The Council has also made the point that racial discrimination is unacceptable because it is also a root cause of the social exclusion of the Roma.  May I also highlight just three other key issues. The Council has repeatedly stressed the importance of the gender dimension in this context and the need for gender-sensitive approaches. The Council also strongly believes that the Roma themselves should be allowed to participate in planning and implementing policies that concern them. Finally, we need an emphasis on the local level. It is the people on the ground who can make the greatest differences.  None of this is controversial. I believe there is a broad agreement between our institutions on the approach we should take. The tools and the strategic insights are already here. A strong and sustained political commitment is needed, along with more forceful implementation. The EU institutions have been playing a leading role in the campaign for Roma inclusion for some years now. This is most welcome. It’s making a difference. Cooperation and funding at EU level can contribute significantly.  The framework we established in 2011 is due to expire in 2020. It is painful to admit that ten years have not been enough to significantly improve the situation of Europe’s Roma. To make greater strides, we need both a sense of urgency and a long-term vision. For this reason, in 2016, the Council called on the Commission to propose a post-2020 strategy on Roma integration and the Council stands ready to work further on these vital subjects. I know Parliament will be a faithful ally in this process.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the debate on this topic is a timely contribution to the Commission’s ongoing evaluation of the EU framework for national Roma integration strategies. We will publish the evaluation by the end of this year. It will analyse the achievements and challenges of the framework. These could then be the basis for reflections about possible policy suggestions for the post-2020 period. Without prejudging the outcome of this process, it is already clear that we have not undone centuries of discrimination in the few years since the launch of the framework in 2011. However, we can see the first signs of progress in some areas, like education. Fewer Roma youths leave school early, dropping from 87% in 2011 to 68% in 2016. More Roma children participate in early childhood education, rising from 47% in 2011 to 53% in 2016. Another important achievement is the development of necessary coordination and cooperation structures, such as national Roma contact points in all Member States and the annual European platform for Roma inclusion. The most important overarching challenge is the limited impact on improving the present situation of Roma. In several areas, there is still much to do. Less, although still way too many Roma are at risk of poverty: 86% in 2011 and 80% in 2016. Extreme forms of poverty such as hunger decreased slightly, but remain alarmingly high. Less, but still too many Roma have experienced discrimination when looking for work in the past five years. In some aspects, the situation of Roma even worsened in past years. Segregation in education has persisted and even deteriorated. The Roma employment stagnates at low levels – 25% – and the rate of Roma youths not in education or in employment or training grew from 56% to 63%. The housing situation of the Roma remains deplorable. Sadly, strong external factors such as the economic crisis, competing political priorities and the rise of anti-Gypsyism and nationalistic populist political movements have contributed to limit the progress. However, the Commission will strive to make the situation of Roma in Europe better, in concert with the Member States, which maintain the key competences in this area.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The current Roma strategy in Europe may not have delivered on its expectations. The main reason for this is that a very strong document has passed through the European Parliament, while the Commission has not been fully committed to taking forward to the Council the very important points without which this strategy cannot be successful: targets, legal basis, penalty opportunities, and the main problem is that, in fact, the Roma are not able to participate in these programmes. , neither in their design nor in their construction. That's why they're so inefficient. I feel that there is a great lack of financial control, financial control, because we are facing a much more complex situation than in 2011. Roma employment is still below the majority national average, while we see that 30 million people will be missing in the labour market by 2060. It is an impermissible luxury for Europe to leave europe's poor untapped. Active job creation is perhaps the most important thing right now. We have achieved a lot of results, and I thank Mrs Panayotova for reporting on it in such detail. I agree, both in early child development and on other issues. Thank you for the Commission's attitude, but we still need to move on. One of the big problems, I see, is that the lying news about the Roma or the Roma policy of the Member States is increasingly ingenable in the parliamentary material itself. This is very, very hindering the objective picture, we are not learning enough from good practices, and I see that this strategy needs to be magned up to one hundred and ten million of the poorest people in Europe, of which only 100 million are Roma.

name: Soraya POST
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I want to start by thanking the Commission for launching the EU framework for national Roma integration strategies in 2011. Due to this, the Member States now have their national strategies and there are programmes and funds aimed at fighting anti-Gypsyism in its various forms. Although we are far from seeing the much-needed improvement in the lives of Roma in Europe, there has been some progress. Now we need to up-scale the efforts following the clear and strong position of the European Parliament. This position was based on the concrete demands and proposals in the report entitled ‘Fundamental rights aspects in Roma integration in the EU: fighting anti-Gypsyism’ adopted by a threefold majority last year. In addition to addressing social inclusion, we need to situate anti-Gypsyism in the focus of the post-2020 EU framework and to introduce anti-discrimination indicators in all fields. We need to set specific deadlines for measurable goals. There should be consultations with Roma representatives to avoid the creation of discriminatory programmes, or programmes that do not reach out to the Roma. We need close monitoring in order to identify quickly which actions can improve the situation on the ground and which do not. I therefore ask the Commission and the upcoming Presidencies to keep the fight against anti-Gypsyism on their agenda and support the continuation of the EU framework. The 10 million Roma in Europe must be equally entitled to enjoy the rights and opportunities established by our Treaties. Their situation depends on the continuation of the framework. Last year we heard some hate speech, so let me just finish by expressing my hope that, during this debate, our colleagues will refrain from using hate speech.

name: Marek JUREK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am pleased to be able to appear in this debate. In my hometown, in Gorzów Wielkopolski, we have a monument to the great Polish Poet of the Roma language Bronisława Wajs (Papuszy), we have her street, this is what children in schools learn about. I hope that in your cities you can also boast about it. If there are such examples, well, you can raise your hand, I will gladly see.  Because it is not good – we have problems in Europe. Only in the last decade from France, from Italy, from Denmark roma were expelled. Martin Schulz, Guy Verhofstadt protested... And what? And they protested, because no vigorous action was taken on this issue. I think we should follow the path that Lívia Járóka and a colleague who followed: we should just work together with this community. Work the way Hungary works, and never use it instrumentally for political battles. People just need help.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We sometimes forget that europe was actually built on values such as tolerance and equality. Even today, all European citizens must have the same opportunities for schooling, free movement, health care, social rights and everything else, but unfortunately the situation in far too many Member States is unacceptable.  Minorities are victims of discrimination and hate crimes, and roma in particular face systematic discrimination, prejudice, marginalisation and exclusion across the EU. Indeed, there are places in europe where Roma do not even have access to clean water and where 80% of roma are reported to be living in poverty. Where children don't get vaccination against diseases we thought we had eradicated a long time ago.  Roma have actually lived in the EU for over 700 years. Then it was called Europe, now it is called the EU. Their culture and history are an important part of our historical heritage. Despite steps in the right direction, such as the 2020 strategy, there needs to be faster action and greater efforts from all Member States to put an end to systematic widespread and unacceptable discrimination. I would like to highlight the Soraya Post own-initiative report of last autumn, which emphasises the importance of education on the history and culture of the Roma and greater efforts to end social exclusion.  All people have the right to a dignified life and the right to choose their lives and shape their future. That is why we must now demand that the Member States step up efforts to integrate Roma, thus putting an end to prejudice, discrimination and marginalisation. Only in this way can we build Europe strongly to face the future.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It is clear that, despite roma inclusion strategies, there is a very long way to go to reach an acceptable level across the EU. It would probably take a substantial Marshall Plan to go all the way, because centuries of discrimination do not disappear in just a few years of active work.  We Greens have suggested in the past that a more specific EU strategy for Roma inclusion would be needed, to speed up the implementation of national strategies and to address cross-border issues. It says a great deal about the pace of national strategies when many Roma make a living and their families more easily by travelling to other EU countries, where they often live in tent camps and beg in front of the supermarkets despite 20 degrees below zero, than are given the opportunity to find jobs at home. Freedom of movement obviously applies to all European citizens and yet some voices are being raised, for example in my own country, to ban begging. We do not solve the problems that way. An EU strategy would be needed to address countries that do not implement their national strategies and other regulatory frameworks and to ensure that the rights of EU migrants are guaranteed when they make use of their right to free movement.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the If you look at the public consultation on the implementation of the Roma Framework Strategy, you can see that there have really been only marginal improvements since 2011, and almost a third of respondents find that the situation has actually deteriorated. In particular, health, work, housing, education and the fight against discrimination are absolute flaws in the Member States - one could also say: everything. There is not a single relevant measure – and this was our concern in 2011 – to combat discrimination against Roma communities and to combat racism. What we really need urgently before any action can even take effect are binding measures to do so. The next strategy must therefore focus on discrimination and racism and ensure effective mainstreaming in policy areas, at EU level and in the Member States, and bindingly. Finally, we do not want the forthcoming Roma strategy to somehow be part of a poverty strategy. We need a separate strategy if we are really serious about it.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I hear so many fine words here in the Chamber. We talk about social inclusion, equality, integration, caring, sharing, peace and love, etc. The Commission knows that it is wrong to finance this project because the results of integration do not exist to date. They do not exist because you claim to integrate those who do not want to be integrated. Just think of how much money is wasted in Italy. One hundred million a year to manage the Roma camps in Milan, Rome and Naples. Twenty-seven million thrown away by the City of Rome for a project with poor results for the schooling of nomadic children.  The EU makes around EUR 26.5 billion available to European taxpayers to finance these failed projects, which also require huge national direct appropriations, in other words, italians' money. The Commission's statement makes me think that it does not know what it is talking about, because in Italy, as witnessed by the umpteenth news story of yesterday, there are bellicose feuds between families of nomads who contain the property, ladies and gentlemen, of a minor segregated in slavery and forced into prostitution. Giving money to those who habitually commit these crimes means being complicit, indeed no, you are worse off, because today you want to continue with this disgusting lace.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, despite the wishes of the European Union and the governments for the Roma, the state and European funds wasted to no avail for their social integration, in a system that not only produces, but lives off, imbalances and exploitation, it is next for vulnerable groups, such as the Roma and especially women, to become victims of even greater discrimination. , exclusions and gedification. They fall victim to racist and Nazi gangs or because of their poverty and marginalisation they are exposed to criminal networks, they are totally incriminated, that is, unjustly, as pockets of crime, while at the same time hiding that the peaks of criminal circuits are not within the Roma camps. Substantial social integration of the Roma means permanent stable work with rights, protection of the unemployed, public health services, simplification of procedures for legitimising their commercial activities, kindergartens, auxiliary teaching departments, uprooting illiteracy, humanisation in their homes with roads, sanitation, electricity, water, schools, dispensaries, public transport and, finally, not discrimination and racism, but respect for their culture and way of life.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I think it is right that the EU monitors the situation of ethnic minorities and, if there are problems, demands that they be remedied and, of course, encourages the Member States to address their situation.  Let me mention specifically the situation in the Czech Republic. The Czech Republic has its own roma integration strategy until 2020. Its purpose is to reverse negative trends in roma development in the fields of education, employment, housing and social issues. There are 245,000 Roma living in the Czech Republic, half of whom are integrated and half still live in ghettos. Let me mention here that if we want to help and prevent ghettos, exclusion, poverty, we must help the Roma, but the Roma themselves must and must be active.  The Czech Government, especially the schools themselves, strive to integrate them into education, because this is an essential condition for their further successful life. Here, too, the EU is helping, because EU funds are able to prepare a number of programmes to integrate Roma children and improve their education.  I am proud that finally in the Czech Republic it was possible to correct the injustice and reverently modify the land on the site of the former Roma concentration camp in Let u Písek. It was the Minister of Culture of my political party who completed this activity, and this is a condition for the Roma to feel safe, to be actively involved in improving their lives. We're going to help them do it.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the fight for equality is never completed, because neither is the fight against discrimination, even if that is a permanent pillar of the European Union and, of course, crucial for this European Parliament. That is why we are doing the right thing by debating the functioning of national strategies for roma inclusion, because that is exactly what this Parliament's resolutions order. But I think this debate loses focus if you look at country by country those where there is a greater history of Roma integration, where it is most ingrained, such as Spain, or those countries where the balance sheet is most deficient. Because the really important thing is to target the most vulnerable population—women, children—: schooling, employment, housing, access to health care, access to education, and equal opportunities. But one thing we can and must do is exclude from this European Parliament the language of hatred and discrimination against Roma which we have so often heard, full of energum hatred in this European Parliament, because that is absolutely intolerable. That is a mandate that we can fulfil: to be vigilant and absolutely intransigent with the language of hatred and discrimination against the Roma in this European Parliament. (He agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: blue-card question. – My dear colleague, you have helped me so much from the Socialist side to push this dossier and we have talked so many times about what sort of financial background there should be behind it. Would you be reconsidering your Socialist view on whether the multiannual financial framework (MFF) should have a bigger budget for the many more poor people in Europe, because when we started this dossier we had 43 million poor people in Europe and about six million were non-integrated Roma. Now if we grow the document because poverty has doubled, would you be considering mentioning this dossier in the MFF? With a loan budget line of course.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for your question, my respected colleague, Ms Járóka. Ever since the great recession got started, we Socialists have fought all along the way against the recessive austerity and in favour of a European budget in order to fight social exclusion. Inequality is on the rise and of course that goes precisely to those segments of the European social fabric which have been the victims of a long, protracted discrimination in history – the Roma community, of course, but not only them.  Let me say that making up the budget is not only a matter in this House for a single European political group and that of course I do favour an increase in those particular chapters of the social European budget. The second thing I wanted to say to you is that, in the current dispensation of the European budget, there is 20% for social inclusion, including in the European Social Fund. And that is an absolute must when it comes to the integration of the Roma population in Europe.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: – Mr President, despite the efforts of the European Union and the Member States, there is still strong discrimination against the Roma community which makes it difficult to integrate and participate in society, especially in the case of Roma women.  The Commission has taken a step forward by recognising as one of the specific objectives of the European Social Fund Plus the social and economic integration of excluded communities such as Roma, with their subsequent financial support. That is why, from Parliament, we must recognise the fight against anti-Itanism as a European priority and support, without any means, the Member States in the development, implementation and supervision of policies aimed at eradicating them.  It is true – and it has been said here – that they can be improved in many areas, in particular in education, employment, health and housing. However, I think we have to give it to education and training. Firstly, ensuring schooling and, secondly, avoiding school drop-out, thus improving their job prospects and their integration and participation in society. Finally, I would like to stress that it is important that the measures are not generic but that they have to be addressed specifically to the Roma community, with the active participation of specialized NGOs, as well as with the Roma organizations themselves. In Spain it works very well, and I think we have to stay on this line.

name: Anna HEDH
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Although we have an EU framework for national strategies on Roma rights, and despite the fact that the Member States have had their own national roma integration strategies since 2012, so far few things have changed for the better. Europe's Roma are still extremely marginalised. They are prejudiced and discriminated against and do not always have access to fundamental rights.  Anti-Gypsyism is scattered and more socially accepted than other racism. This is devastating both for the living conditions of the Roma and for their confidence in society. We cannot allow this to continue; we need to do more. It goes without saying that the Commission alone cannot bear responsibility; it is in our Member States that changes must take place, but the Commission has an extremely important responsibility to monitor and scrutinise the effective implementation of member states' strategies. Unfortunately, there are shortcomings here that need to be corrected.  The best thing we can do now is to continue working on the European framework for national roma integration strategies. Without pressure from you, Commissioner and the others in the Commission, I do not believe that national governments will prioritise the issue or do what is necessary, so we demand that you continue to press the Member States on Roma rights, preferably with a Roma strategy.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – Mr President, I would like to say that I feel that we are a little unfair to the Member States. I will speak for my country, for the Slovak Republic. The Slovak Republic has its strategy to help solve the Roma problem. We have a Roma plenipotentiary. And I know that this is the case in several countries, because I have been a member of the fact-finding mission on several occasions, visiting several countries where there is a larger roma community that we consider excluded or groups that are struggling to integrate. But I will tie to what Lívia Járóka said: without cooperation with the Roma community itself, we will not be successful in these strategies. The fact that we have excellent strategies is one thing, but the fact that we cannot implement them also because a large proportion of Roma communities do not cooperate in these strategies is another matter. And when we talked about education, I just want to say for my country that my country has created all the conditions for Roma children to be educated from pre-school to school. Unfortunately, in the environment of their families, they do not feel any support in educating themselves, so they then end up schooling rather and find it difficult to place themselves in the labour market. Moreover, the majority of Roma in Slovakia are more likely to carry out manual activities because they will close such schools, and we know very well that technological progress does not make it possible to create as many jobs as they can do. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Soraya POST
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, I am happy that Member States are doing their best, but do you really mean, Monika, that the Slovak Government is doing their best when they are creating walls and when they are creating segregated schools for Roma children? Is that the way to do integration? You have to ask that. You also had a sanction from the Commission because of the segregated schools.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – It is not true that special segregated schools for Roma children are created in Slovakia. On the contrary, the Slovak governments, whether present or past, have tried to create space for Roma children to be integrated into the proper teaching system in full schools. The problem is that we have Roma settlements regionally located in some areas, and unfortunately, as there is a higher incidence of children from Roma settlements, not all of them meet their own abilities to be part of other schools, and therefore it is not only for Roma children that special schools are created.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: There is a blue card per speaker, not two, three or four, otherwise it no longer becomes a question, it becomes another thing. Catch the eye procedure

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, Roma across Europe face countless problems, such as unemployment, poor housing, poor access to public services, multiple forms of discrimination and social, cultural and economic exclusion. Too little progress is being made, not to mention the anti-Roma prejudices that are still being promulgated, including at the highest political level in some Member States. The Commission’s recent public consultation showed that only in the field of education has there been any progress, and I am grateful for the work of the Committee on Culture and Education in that regard. In almost all the other areas – employment, healthcare, housing and discrimination – a large number of respondents declared that they saw little or no improvement. I wish particularly to mention the issues faced by Roma women, who find themselves at the intersection between anti-Gypsyism and sexism. Problems in relation to discrimination against Roma need to be addressed through a rights-based approach and the EU has a responsibility to lead the way.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the Roma are a minority of 10 to 12 million, who for centuries have been living in social marginalisation, facing discrimination and stereotypes that exist against them. Let us not forget that millions of Roma were executed, murdered in Nazi concentration camps.  In the meantime, the years have passed and yet poverty and social marginalisation continue for the Roma. Of course this cannot be an alibi for anti-social behaviour on their part. They need financial support and social inclusion. Funds must be made available and the obstacles to bureaucracy must be overcome. I would like to tell you in this regard, Commissioner, that we must support the effort being made for the Roma in the Kamelovrysis region of Fthiotida outside Lamia. There the children go to school in containers, they face water and lighting problems. Bureaucracy must be overcome and funds given for relocation projects in this area of Kamilovrysis where there are too many Roma.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Together with Vice-President Lívia Járóka, the reporter of the case, I am proud that in 2011 the EP adopted the European Roma strategy under the auspices of the Hungarian Presidency. Contrary to the accusations made in the Sargentini report, Hungary has been at the forefront of the implementation of the strategy ever since. However, I am ashamed of how little of their strategic commitments have been achieved by the EU and some of the Member States concerned. The EU takes many times more care and spends money on illegal immigrants than on its own Gypsy citizens in Europe and on their integration. Drawing conclusions from what we have learned so far, we must not get thres about polkorrekt verbalism, but we must finally act to integrate millions of Roma living in extreme poverty into social, economic, educational and health integration. Our post-1920 strategy obliges us to do so.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner and Minister, before I begin, I would like to say to Mrs Beňová, nothing you have said is true and you know that well. Roma communities, the largest ethnic minority in the European Union, are an integral part of European society and economy, but remain deprived of their fundamental rights. Persecuted for centuries, Roma citizens continue to be victims of prejudice and discrimination in Europe today in education, employment, access to housing and social benefits, thus making them especially vulnerable to poverty, social exclusion and trafficking in human beings. They are also often victims of forced evictions, racist attacks and police mistreatment and, in some Member States, prevented from obtaining the citizenship and documents necessary for health and social security services. This shows that, despite some improvements in the field of education, Member States are lacking in their fight against discrimination and makes it urgent to ensure that the Union framework for national roma integration strategies in the post-2020 period is more ambitious and more integrated, in a logic of empowerment and fostering the participation of roma communities themselves - i close , Mr President - so that they finally cease to exist in the Union romai stateless or treated as second-rate citizens.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, with this strategy, the position of the Roma has not improved much in the Member States. It has improved somewhat in concrete terms in the area of education, but exclusion and also the relatively worse position in the labour market, public decision-making, access to services or influencing one's own life have continued more or more as before. At the same time, public attitudes – racist and anti-Roma – have not been much corrected in Europe either. All this speaks in favour of the need for a new EU framework programme with stricter monitoring and also corrective measures for each Member State when the objectives are not achieved. This means that a specific section is needed that directly addresses public attitudes, racism and discrimination, which is unfortunately widespread in different Member States. As such, this is a good reminder of why we also need an anti-discrimination directive. We also need stronger Roma involvement in decision-making, both on the public and private sides, and finally we need training that strengthens the position of the Roma in the labour market in relative terms, that is, not cheap labour, but in those areas where there is a demand for future working life.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The creation of Roma integration strategies was in itself an acknowledgement of the specific situation of Roma communities and the EU's willingness to participate actively with Member States in solving problems. I think it is extremely important that the EU tries to monitor the work of the national authorities, but at the same time we need to see that governments can do the most to implement the strategies. The issue is extremely complex, but I feel that the social and educational dimension is most important, because the catching up of Roma communities can be successful if its members feel that there is an opportunity to break out of poverty and that education can make their situation better. If we look at the labour market processes in the Central and Eastern European region, we need to realise that there is a huge need for Roma who are currently unable to enter the labour market because of their low level of education. Roma integration is therefore important not only for the Roma, but can also benefit many times in all Member States and local communities.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In the Committee on Culture, I am in some sense taking care of such financial support for Erasmus+ programmes. For this reason, I follow the fate of the various minorities – including national minorities – in this programme. And I have to say that the Roma community is not functioning there. This is on the verge of statistical error. On the other hand, the situation of the youngest generation of Roma, in short, children, has been slightly improved, but I stress. A year later, they leave school, but most often at the basic level. I would like to draw attention to this, because we must unfortunately take note of the fact that the Opinion of the Council and the Commission is wrong, but that it is accepting, in terms of the reality of the assessment, but not accepting in terms of prospects. We need a much more effective, much better addressed and much better coordinated programme, also at national level. Here are the biggest troubles.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for your clear and strong contributions, engagement and guidance on this important matter. It is obvious that, together, we need to continue an EU-level commitment. Roma strategies must be part of a broader narrative of inclusive structural reform that benefits all groups suffering discrimination and exclusion. In addition, hand-in-hand with socioeconomic inclusion, we will need an increased focus on fighting racism, in particular anti-Gypsyism, as well as clearer, measurable Roma integration goals, backed by robust transparent and inclusive monitoring. The results of the EU framework evaluation will feed into reflection on the needs and directions of the post-2020 EU approach. I count on your strong support along the way.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you once again for the opportunity to address this important subject in Parliament. The Council welcomes your determination to keep Roma inclusion on the agenda and to provide continuity.  Let me repeat that the Council has already called on the Commission to propose the post-2020 strategy. It has not yet been decided how exactly the work on this subject will be continued after 2020, but we are quite confident that – with the proposal for the Multiannual Financial Framework and the 25% guarantee financing under the European Social Fund+ for social inclusion – the national Roma strategies will have the financing needed to implement them after 2020. We believe the EU framework for National Roma integration strategies is a major achievement, a manifestation of our common commitment to social justice, so let us overcome our divisions and affirm our common humanity.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We would like to thank the Minister, who will also be with us for the next debate, while we greet and thank Commissioner Mimica for being here. The debate is closed.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on: - the question with request for an oral reply to the Council on improving language learning and mutual recognition of language skills in the European Union by Cecilia Wikström, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions (O-000055/2018 - B8-0029/2018) (2018/2707(RSP)) and - the question with request for an oral reply to the Commission on improving language learning and mutual recognition of language skills in the European Union by Cecilia Wikström, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions (O-000056/2018 - B8-0030/2018) (2018/2707(RSP)).

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: author. – Mr President, in the name of my committee, the Committee on Petitions, I have the pleasure of presenting the oral question to both the Council and the Commission on improving language learning and the mutual recognition of language competences in the European Union. In my Committee, we have received a number of petitions asking to improve language learning and the mutual recognition of language competences in the European Union. The petitioners claim that the existing differences in the teaching, evaluation and recognition of language skills in different Member States undermine the freedom of movement, which is very serious. They also claim that it discriminates against children in school whose mother tongue is one of the smaller languages of the 24 official languages of the European Union. My Committee decided therefore to table this oral question to both the Council and the Commission on this issue, and both these questions were unanimously – and I underline, unanimously – adopted by the Committee on Petitions. According to Article 165 of the Treaty, Member States are exclusively competent for the content and the organisation of education and training systems. So in this sense, the offer of languages for secondary school exams is the decision of the Member State’s Ministry of Education on the organisation of their educational system. However, proficiency in very much more than only one language is considered essential to strengthen employability within the European Union. It is also a critical key competence for active citizenship. The EU therefore supports and supplements the actions of the Member States, with the aim to improve the efficiency of language teaching and learning. The oral questions to the institutions therefore tabled by my Committee are in line with the Commission’s initiative on the creation of the European education agenda. I’m proud of that. We are completely (inaudible) within that scope, and in particular the concerned package of measures presented by the Commission in May this year suggesting, among other things, a Council recommendation for improving language learning. The Committee on Petitions wanted to have a debate on these oral questions in this plenary, taking into account the adoption by plenary of the own initiative report by the Cultural Committee on modernisation of education in the European Union. The EU has long promoted language learning with an aim to increase mutual understanding and mobility, this by supporting supplementing actions and cooperation between national educational systems. Parliament is taking serious note of these petitions that we have received, in which EU citizens do raise their severe concerns about the lack of teaching and recognition of language skills in their mother tongue. Every EU citizen should be able to take advantage of their freedom to live in a Member State other than his or her own, and unfortunately this problem is today making it difficult to do so. Therefore, we ask and call upon the Council and the Commission to elaborate on the following issues – and I have them, there are four: Firstly, what actions have you taken to support Member States in order to improve the mutual recognition of language competences in all the official EU languages, based on the levels existing under the common European framework of reference for languages? Secondly, how does the Council and the Commission assess the added value of teaching official EU languages and particularly the recommendation for ‘mother tongue plus two’ in the context of modernisation of education in the EU, and more particularly for stimulating entrepreneurship, job opportunities and preservation of cultural diversities within the European Union? Thirdly, does the Council and the Commission have recent and accurate data available concerning language assessment opportunities and the recognition of language exams, diplomas or certificates in the official EU languages other than English, French, German, Spanish and Italian – the big five? How can the European Union further support educational institutions that do provide classes in the official EU languages for EU citizens living in a Member State other than their own? And lastly, what measures does the Council and the Commission intend to put in place in the European education area to develop an online system for the cross-border recognition and validation of EU language certificates for the purposes of school-leaving diplomas in order to facilitate accessibility to higher education across the EU? Those are our four questions. They conclude my Committee’s oral question to the two institutions.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, at the Gothenburg summit in November 2017 the EU Heads of State and Government chose education and culture as the first subject to be addressed under the new Leaders’ Agenda, underlining their willingness to do more in these areas. The results of the Gothenburg discussions were formalised in the conclusions of the European Council meeting on 14 December last year, which emphasised that education and culture are key to building inclusive and cohesive societies. But the European Council didn’t limit itself to such general statements: it also set out a number of specific areas for work to be taken forward. I would like to mention two such areas, which are specifically relevant to the question posed today. The first is language learning, where the Heads of State and Government called for action so that more young people will speak at least two European languages in addition to their mother tongue. The second area is the mutual recognition of higher education and school leaving diplomas, and here Member States’ cooperation is key. The benefits of multilingual competences impact upon all aspects of life. They contribute to mutual understanding and mobility within the Union. They increase our productivity, competitiveness and economic resilience. The lack of multilingual competences hampers the mobility of our citizens within the European Union and beyond and limits access to education, training and the labour market. At a time when Europe is looking to the future and seeking to re—engage, especially with young people, around an agenda of shared values, we believe multilingual and multicultural competences are crucial to creating a sense of belonging among Europeans.  Here, I would like to remind you that multilingualism was one of the core elements of the modernised Key Competence Framework adopted by the Council in May and the Council recommendation on promoting common values. The Council recommendation on key competences for lifelong learning is particularly relevant because multilingual competence is identified as one of the eight key competences which should be developed by the Member States’ education systems. This update was not just a single act by the Council to address the common challenge in the European Union of the modernisation of educational institutions, but also part of the Member States’ overall ambition to keep working on the New Skills Agenda for Europe. The Council’s recent extensive work on that matter, including the provision of a quality framework for language learning and recognition, started with the revision of the European Qualifications Framework. The revised European Qualifications Framework recommendation provided better understanding of qualifications and enabled better use of the skills available on the European labour market. The new Europass Framework, agreed recently, builds on the successful formula with easy—to—use tools to help people identify and communicate their skills and qualifications in all EU languages, which is a major boost for the recognition of all EU languages. In addition, many other initiatives in Europe have supported the definition and development of language competences. The Council supports in a sustainable manner the use of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages and recognises the impact of the European Language Label Award for excellence and innovation in language teaching. Allow me to remind you that the Council held an education ministerial debate in February this year, when it called for a stronger Erasmus+ programme building on current successful instruments and further boosting participation. The call for an inclusive Erasmus+ programme, providing more and new participants with mobility opportunities, will increase the opportunities for young people both to learn more languages and to promote their own mother tongue with the European Union and beyond. In May the Council adopted important strategic conclusions on moving towards the vision a European Education Area, which recognised multilingual competence as an important building block of such an area. In the meantime, the Commission has issued a package of three further proposals for Council recommendations, including a proposal on the mutual recognition of higher education and school leaving diplomas and the proposal on improving language learning. The two proposed recommendations are particularly relevant to today’s discussion. The recommendation on improving language learning focuses on language teaching and learning in compulsory education, covering both general and vocational schools, as well as multilingual competences in a lifelong perspective. Both recommendations will be examined in detail by the Council. This process has only just begun and it is therefore too early at this point to comment on the substance. However, there is already broad consensus that these are the key areas to be addressed in seeking to build a European education area and it is my understanding that the ambition of the forthcoming Austrian Presidency is to seek agreement at least on the first proposal, on mutual recognition of diplomas, before the end of this year. Therefore, on the issue of language learning, as well as mutual recognition of diplomas, it is clear that the work is progressing quite quickly. These issues are a priority for the Council, and Parliament can expect quality results during the upcoming Presidencies.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I would like to thank the Minister and welcome Commissioner Navracsics, who will be remembering this evening because today is her birthday, and I wish him a happy birthday.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this oral question which reflects Parliament’s strong commitment to multilingualism. Just three weeks ago, the Commission adopted a proposal for a Council recommendation on the teaching and learning of languages. In fact, this proposal’s recommendation is a response to the European Council which last December called on us, I quote, ‘to enhance the learning of languages so that more young people will speak at least two European languages in addition to their mother tongue’. Language learning and multilingualism have never been higher on the political agenda. We should use this momentum. Let me now answer your questions. First, the mutual recognition of language competence is based on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages. The Commission supports and encourages Member States to use this Council of Europe framework. It facilitates the assessment of language competences and helps to create mutual understanding and transparency for the recognition of such competences. In recent years, the Commission has reinforced its cooperation with the Council of Europe and its European Centre for Modern Languages, situated in Graz, Austria. We have supported several joint projects, including on the assessment of language competences. Two practical tools have also been developed. First, the European language Portfolio, a document that helps language learners, at and beyond school, to record and reflect on their language learning and cultural experiences. The second instrument is the Europass Language Passport, which is part of the Europass online tool. These two instruments help validate language competences in a transparent and comparable manner. Countries can use them to move towards the recognition of different language competences. On your second question, on teaching languages in the context of the modernisation of education in the EU: language competences are at the heart of our ambitious vision to create a European Education Area. Being able to speak foreign languages is a key condition for studying and working abroad. It provides valuable and much-demanded skills on the labour market, strengthens a sense of European identity and enable learners fully to discover Europe’s cultural diversity. The Commission proposal for a Council recommendation on a comprehensive approach to the teaching and learning of languages stresses that young people need to be able to express themselves in three languages. First is the language of schooling, which is generally the national language; second is a language of international communication; and also a third language, which is most often relevant to their personal context. It is a priority for the Commission to support Member States in making language teaching and learning more effective. Now, on your third question on language assessment and the recognition of language certificates, as well as support to educational institutions: in the 2014 Council conclusions on multilingualism the Commission was invited to explore the feasibility of assessing language competences across all Member States by using existing national language tests. In 2015, two studies were launched. The aim was to map national tests and compare the tests used across Europe to assess the language competences of secondary school pupils. However, these studies concluded that the data available at national level were not comparable. The Erasmus+ programme supports language learning. In fact, this is one of its specific objectives. Opportunities for pupils to learn abroad, which we intend to boost in the future Erasmus programme, will also support the learning of languages. Moreover, teachers will benefit from continuous professional development and mobility schemes. We want to ensure that by 2025 every newly graduated language teacher will have spent at least six months learning or teaching abroad. Online training projects are also valuable for developing language competences. Finally, to your fourth question on the recognition of language competencies in school-leaving diplomas: in May the Commission proposed the Council recommendation on a comprehensive approach to the teaching and learning of languages. It stresses the importance of acquiring and developing adequate language competences in one’s mother tongue plus two additional languages. To help people reach adequate competence levels, the recommendation promotes the concept of language-aware schools that embed language learning – the learning of both of foreign languages and the language of schooling – across curricula. This enables a focus on pupils’ respective needs, circumstances, abilities and interests. Language-aware schools value linguistic diversity and enable students to maintain their entire linguistic repertoire, including their home language or mother tongue when this is not the language of schooling. As a consequence, the prior learning and knowledge of languages which are not part of the curriculum can be formally recognised and can be added to school-leaving certificates. Currently it is not possible to acquire recognised qualifications in all European languages. Therefore, the Commission encourages Member States to step up their efforts to make language certificates more widely available.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – I would like to see today's debate as a wonderful victory for the cause of the small official languages. Indeed, the small official languages were worth a debate in the Great Hall in Strasbourg.  Among the petitions that were at the heart of today's debate was a Bulgarian petition, a particularly impressive petition of the Association of Bulgarian Schools Abroad. And although the question and the debate started under a petition of Bulgarian teachers, very quickly the topic was recognized as a large pan-European topic, namely the protection of small official languages and especially their most vulnerable carriers – children, students.  Because it is about protecting those young people whose parents have benefited from the fundamental right to free movement or whose parent, in the case of mixed marriages, and whose natural proficiency in the mother tongue is not appreciated in dignity, especially in the case of a mother tongue official in the European Union.  This debate, started by the Committee on Petitions, shows that when you have a cause, when you have arguments, your voice will be heard by the European Parliament, and as evidenced by Commissioner Evracsics' response, it will be heard even by the European Commission. Because it is a principle – the principle of equality in all official languages. There's no going back. Moreover, from what I have heard so far, I think that the Commission and the European Parliament will overtake the Member States in this direction.

name: Peter KOUROUMBASHEV
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– The main objective of this petition, which Mr. Malinov is referring to and for which the Association of Bulgarian Schools deserves congratulation, is to offer end-of-secondary exams in all official languages of the European Union in certain schools in all Member States. It does not make sense to resolve this issue at the level of bilateral relations between two separate Member States. This is precisely the point of the European Union and European law – to address this issue in all official languages in all Member States. Every person would like their children, regardless of where they live or how many languages they know, to speak their own language, in the official language of their country. Every language is a gateway to a culture. Your own language is a gateway to your own culture. We are very proud that as Bulgarians we gave the third alphabet in the European Union after the Latin and Greek alphabet, and I very much hope that Bulgarian children will be able to read and write in Cyrillic anywhere in every Member State of the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the Committee on Petitions is the committee to which citizens are addressed and has the opportunity to raise the issues that concern them. The issue we are dealing with today in the form of a question is really crucial, because the ability of citizens to have language skills, to be able to speak two additional languages in addition to their mother tongue, is something very important and decisive, especially at a time when thousands of young people from the European South and the European region, precisely because of the austerity and poverty policies that exist in these regions. , they are forced to come to the hard core countries. It is therefore essential to enable young people, through Erasmus and European funds, to have these language skills, but of course there must also be procedures for recognising the language skills acquired by our young people. We consider both these initiatives and the support of language teachers to be important.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – I would like to thank everyone who worked on the topic, but above all I would like to thank the Association of Bulgarian Schools Abroad, whose petition laid the groundwork for this oral issue, which we are discussing tonight. I know that the European Commission in such cases says: "The question is within the competence of the Member States." Specific language policies are implemented in the Member States. In this case, however, it is not just about education, it is about mobility. For mobility and free movement of our most valuable capital – knowledge. Indeed, what more valuable capital does it have than the skills and knowledge of adolescent generations? Language competence is part of that capital. Its acquisition is promoted as a key competence.  It turns out that mobility can devalue and lose language competence already. I'm setting an example for you. A student from Bulgaria with two foreign languages, English and French, arrives in France and remains with only one foreign language. His Bulgarian no longer counts, does not fit anywhere, is not recognized, is not appreciated. This devaluation leads to its non-maintenance and loss. The local system actually says, "This language is superfluous to you." Don't they need Member States with this rare knowledge to make it more closely integrating markets and cultures? We are not talking about harmonisation here, we are not talking about education systems, we are not talking about exam systems, we are not talking about language policies. A mechanism is needed to convey the value of the language knowledge acquired, regardless of which language, how and where they were acquired. It is not harmonisation, but a mechanism of choice of countries – whether with national examinations, whether with recognition of certificates or otherwise. Such a mechanism will appear as an administrative measure, not an educational one. In conclusion, I would say that the issue is not just in front of Bulgarian students and parents, but in front of hundreds of thousands of European citizens. Mobility means open doors, and the loss of language closes its doors.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, cuirim fáilte gan dabht roimh an díospóireacht seo mar ceapaim gur maith an rud é aitheantas a thabhairt dár n-éagsúlacht teanga. Is díospóireacht bheo leanúnach í cearta teanga san Eoraip agus sa bhaile in Éirinn. Mar shampla, tá ár rialtas féin ag déanamh faillí ar ár bpobal Gaeilge le heaspa seirbhísí agus easpa aitheantais, easpa múinteoirí agus easpa tacaíochta, go háirithe dúinne atá inár gcónaí sa Ghaeltacht.  Tá dearcadh rialtas na Breataine scannalach i dtaobh ár dteanga dhúchasach agus nílid toilteanach comhaontú Chill Rímhinn a chomhlíonadh maidir le hAcht na Gaeilge.
