Tá sé tábhachtach mar sin go seasfaimid mar Fheisirí go láidir ar son cearta teanga agus son cearta daonna i ngach gné dár saol. Tá ár dteangacha tábhachtach, ní hamháin dár bhféiniúlacht ach dár bhféinmhuinín, dár n-éiceolaiocht, dár gcultúr agus níos mó ná san.  Ach mar fhocal scoir, agus samhlaím go bhfuil sé tábhachtach é seo a ardú agus sinn ag caint ar chúrsaí teanga ar ndóigh: tá deacrachtaí ag na hateangairí le riarachán sa Pharlaimint seo agus táim ag labhairt go díreach leis na hateangairí atá anseo trathnóna chun a rá libh go bhfuilimidne in éineacht libh, táimid ag éisteacht libh, táimid in éineacht in bhur dtroid ar son cearta agus ar son bhur gcearta oibriúcháin. Beirigí bua, seasfaimid an fód libh.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, recently there have been voices in the Netherlands, which is the champion of happy globalisation, against the supremacy of English in higher education. A late awakening at a time when for the average international student, the days are punctuated by courses in English and conversations on Skype in the native language. Barcelona's objectives of mastering two foreign languages as a guarantee of diversity have long been a long time, from Bologna to Maastricht, globish reigns undivided. It is surprising when the European institutions themselves maintain a double permanent discourse between praise for multilingualism and a hegemony of English that is disproportionate to its demographic weight in the aftermath of Brexit. Behind the question of principle looms that of the consideration given to nations such as France, founding state and net contributor, while the renewal of patriotism swarms the ferments of a spring of the European peoples. The answer to this question depends on the legitimacy of Europe but also on its survival.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. The Committee on Petitions has been approached by a number of European citizens on the use of language, on this basis we are asking the Commission and the Council today about the issues raised. I think it is a prescient idea on the issue addressed to the two institutions, because if we want an open Europe capable of understanding and understanding each other, we must start by educating young people. Without language skills, learning about our cultures is more difficult, travel is more complicated and studying abroad is more complicated. This is why it is important to receive strong EU support for as many initiatives as possible to strengthen linguistic diversity. The European Union can help learners a lot, for example by adopting language exams and certificates from other Member States more quickly and flexibly, or by better supporting institutions specialising in teaching other languages in other Member States. I would like to stop here for a moment, because I think that similar, or perhaps even greater, support is needed for pupils and students who speak minority or regional languages. That is why I am asking the Commission and the Council not to forget young people who speak European minority languages in their future measures.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, I think this debate on this oral question from the Committee on Petitions seems to me to be of great opportunity. I believe that improving language learning is an obligation and, although other colleagues have referred to the fact that it is indeed the competence of the States, I believe that more can be done from the European Union, from the Council and the Commission. We are the largest common political space with the largest number of languages. We have countries like Russia or the United States with a single language, practically. That is, therefore, we are a great political space with a large number of languages, and that is a shared value. Therefore, initiatives must be taken. I found those of the Council interesting, also those announced by the Commission. I am from a country – Spain – with an official language but with three more official languages in its territory, and I think that is a wealth. These initiatives must be pursued and the competences of States to be generous with the fact that the European Union favours the language and learning of these languages.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I also thank the Commissioner for his report and the attention he pays to the issue of language learning. I think it is in the EU's interest for people to come to an agreement with each other. To do this, they undoubtedly need a lingua franca, that is English today, and if they are well-off, they will certainly be able to master another foreign language. The EU must also promote mother tongue education. Of course, it is in the interest of the Member States to be active, to promote the linguistic literacy of their citizens, but, given mobility, it is also up to the EU to help them coordinate language education, which is why we are proposing a mechanism for regular transparent evaluation of language competences across Member States. The EU should support educational institutions that provide teaching in official EU languages for citizens living outside their own Member State.  Last but not least, we should also help to make university education available through an online system of cross-border recognition and validation of language certificates for the purposes of school leaving certificates. We should also use the competence, the capacities that the OECD has, for example. At this point, I would like to thank my colleague Malinov for his initiative and the Commissioner for his cooperation.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Going beyond the framework set by our mother tongue and learning foreign languages bring many cultural, social and, last but not least, economic benefits. At the same time, knowledge of foreign languages and, as a result, quality language teaching are becoming an increasingly necessary necessity in today's multicultural world. Nowhere is this as obvious as in the European Union. This gives them the opportunity to learn about each other's cultures and deepen relations between nations, but also to develop one of the EU's fundamental principles: the free movement of labour, which would not be possible effectively without the practice of a foreign language. It is therefore important that the EU supports the ideas of modernising language teaching with all its measures in order to ensure the conditions for modern language teaching. I also think it is important to place greater emphasis, in addition to the basic languages, on the need to strengthen relations between neighbouring countries through language teaching. It may be useful if the basic foreign language taught outside a foreign language in a given country is the language of a neighbouring country in that country. This will also make communication between neighbouring countries and mobility with mutual economic benefits more effective.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – There are a number of families living, working and studying in another Member State within the Union. The choice to live, work or study elsewhere should not come at the expense of the connection with the native language and culture, but on the contrary, quite the opposite. Unfortunately, children in these families often lose their connection to the native language. This is partly due to the fact that most Member States of the European Union do not provide for the possibility of taking a maturity exam in so-called small European languages such as Bulgarian, which is a pure sample of discrimination. The cultural and linguistic identity of every citizen of the European Union, whether born in Bulgaria or England, is something we must defend, and the European Union must play a key role in this process. Access to equal opportunities is something we cannot compromise on. Since we have mutual recognition of diplomas, I believe that we should also have mutual recognition of language competences.

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: – One of the Policies of the European Union is to stimulate the learning and dissemination of official languages in the Union. In this sense, any language outside the mainstream, such as English, French, German and Spanish, deserves to be recognised in the education systems of the Member States of the Union. But most member states do not recognize exams, diplomas and certificates for languages other than those listed, which is discrimination against students who are fluent in the so-called "no-fly zone". small languages. More and more families with children are already settling in another Member State of the Union, and it is important for them that children remain in touch with their native language. An incentive for them will be if their knowledge of the native language is evaluated and the grades or the certificate is recognized when applying to a higher education institution. Students who speak so-called "yes" should be given the opportunity to speak out. whose parents are outside their home country to learn their mother tongue. According to statistics, there are over 200 thousand students abroad from Bulgaria alone, but only 15 thousand of them are covered by Bulgarian schools. It is necessary to provide for a legal possibility of taking a math or other examination in any of the official languages of the European Union. Including in the Bulgarian language and the result of such an examination to be entered in the diploma of completed stage of study of the respective education system of the Member State of the European Union. This, for example, is already done in the United States of America. It is also normal to do so in the Member States of the Union. This problem affects not only Bulgarian students, but also students of all Member States. Mastering another language will be a plus for personality development to make it competitive in the labour market.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – Mr President, the European Union contributes to the development of quality education by promoting cooperation between Member States. Where necessary, it shall support and complement the activities of the Member States. In so doing, it should fully respect their responsibility for the content of teaching, the organisation of education systems and cultural and linguistic diversity. Programmes such as Erasmus are a good example of the spread of this diversity and understanding across the Union. However, I am concerned that language examinations are not recognised on an equal footing by all the Countries of the Union. It is common practice that if a student obtains a state examination or other equivalent english language certificate, for example in Slovakia, he or she has a subsequent problem with its recognition within other EU countries. This week we talked about an education strategy in the European Union. This strategy imply the need for a blending of higher education, provided that language certificates are mutually recognisable. It is precisely the mobility of students in the EU that helps to increase the training of young people and, ultimately, their employment in the labour market. Each Member State has a unique cultural and linguistic identity, which we should respect. All states are equal under Union law and therefore the practice of recognising language competences should also be harmonised in this respect.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, languages and language skills are of particular importance as part of the formation of a European identity and also in improving human interaction and developing European policies and dialogue, and, of course, also as a condition for moving to other Member States in the labour market. Therefore, as part of this European education area, particular efforts should be made to increase language teaching at all levels of education. When I speak languages, I mean two or three different languages. At the same time, it would also be necessary to promote the spread of these standardised European language tests to the various Member States and to the various forms of education so that we can demonstrate the level of language skills in a common way in the various Member States. These are the wishes of the Commission with regard to the strengthening of the language area and the strengthening of language skills.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I welcome the initiative for further promoting language learning, including ‘the mother tongue plus two’ ambition. Being able to speak several languages improves one’s employability and increases the likelihood of getting a qualified job. It is also a way to internationalise one’s career, which is very useful in a globalised world. Learning another language is also an incredibly enriching cultural experience which provides learners with social skills – in particular intercultural skills – and the ability to adapt to different social and cultural environments. When you learn a language, you do not only learn about grammar and vocabulary, you begin to understand someone else’s vision of the world. Learning openness to other perspectives and being willing to learn a language yourself are amongst the most transferable skills that young people will need in a fast-changing globalised and diverse world. Finally, as a disability rights champion and as a qualified BSL signer, I also want to mention the need to promote sign-language learning for a true and inclusive language diversity.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – A language cannot be large or small. In this regard, it cannot, is not right and should not be divided into large and small languages in the European Union, because the language is not measured by the size of the territory. The territory has changed and changed. If a language has poetry on it, if a language can make art, then it's big. My language has 1,300 years of history only in the Balkans in Europe. That's the Bulgarian language. And the alphabet we have created and preserved has created, preserved and carried thousands of cultural heritage. We are part of the European Union, each one of us is different, each of us brings part of our culture, from our memory. Languages must therefore be preserved and therefore identity, self-consciousness and self-esteem must be preserved through the preservation of the language, which is what happens when we enable every single citizen of a European Union country to take their maturing exams and to keep their language. This is what we need to do in the European Union.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, as we speak languages I would like to support the interpreters of the 24 booths of this European Chamber to claim their right to strike and as we speak languages to explain that there are no large languages or small languages, there are living languages or dead languages. Multilingualism, the recognition of language skills is of great importance. We have just approved a European citizens' initiative on minority languages. And I would like to draw attention to the support of minority languages, mother tongues, languages such as mine, the Ghastly language, which loses speakers, especially in children. Do not forget, European Commission and Council, of the co-official, co-official languages of many European peoples.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I would still be admonished for such languages so-called dead as Latin.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In the Committee on Culture, we all agree: the recognition of language competences is an objective, it is a challenge, and that is a good that we should pursue. We also agree with the Commissioner. Notabene if I knew what the Commissioner would say, maybe I would not speak. But one element escapes us all the time: we speak as if there is no addressee of this demand. Since we know that this falls within the competence of individual countries, it is worth mentioning those countries with which we have the greatest problem, where diplomas are not recognised, where the recognition of all that falls within the area of competence is also not categorised. We should talk about it.  I have been minister of culture for seven years and I know that this is extremely mobilising – pointing out flaws, mistakes, showing exactly the address that should reform or implement a certain project is effective. That is why I have a request to the Commissioner: let us say where we have the greatest problems.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for having this debate here in the Parliament, because it’s reinforced our fundamental message that education is really probably the most powerful vehicle of social integration and social inclusion, and the language aspect of this vehicle is even more important in the European Union, which is a multi-lingual community. So it has its own social role, and the education of languages, both majority official languages and also the minority languages for the minority communities, is of utmost importance from the point of view of the future of Europe. But it is also the economic aspects of the education of languages. The more languages we know, the more competitive we are, and it can be one of the most important underpinning of the single market and the economic aspects of the European Union and also the future competitiveness of the European Union. So thank you for this very fruitful debate. I rely on you in the future when we encourage the Member States for closer cooperation to have the mutual recognition of diplomas and school papers and language certificates and working towards a European education area.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this important and enriching debate. I believe that there is a very wide consensus regarding the importance not only of learning foreign languages, but also of preserving the so—called smaller languages. This is not only key to the ambition of creating a European education area, but even more crucial to the task of building Europe for the future, based on common values and mutual understanding of our diverse traditions. Parliament can be sure that the Council will advance quickly on this agenda. Now please allow me to say a few words in my mother tongue.   – I would like to address all of you in Bulgarian, as this is my last participation in plenary, the last debate in my capacity as Minister for the Bulgarian Presidency, taking part on behalf of the Council.  I would like to thank you warmly over the past six months for the extremely good spirit and dialogue of cooperation we have had; for the privilege and honour of participating in really important debates on the European agenda, important both for the future of European policies, which are important especially for the future of European citizens. So it was a real honour to speak for the Council and to be with you in plenary and we will be happy to pass on the June relay to my Colleagues in Austria. It is a pleasure that I had the opportunity, precisely the last debate in which I take part, to be dedicated to young people, to education, to cultural and linguistic diversity, which are the basis for actually building a common European identity for all of us. And we show that, in fact, when the three institutions work together in the same direction, indeed the unification makes the power, which is also the motto of the Bulgarian Presidency. Thank you, it's really been a pleasure. I hope it's mutual.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: It is always nice to feel the language community of Slavic languages. I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Malinov for his support for this initiative. As Vice-President of the European Parliament's Committee on Culture and Education, I think it is very important to talk about languages, language learning and the recognition of languages and diplomas at European Union level. Language is the basis of the child's cognitive and social development, so learning in the mother tongue is important in the first right. In addition, the competence of multilingualism has advantages in all areas of life. Minority and majority languages and cultures alike contribute to Europe's diversity, and there is a consensus on this. The protection of minorities contributes to europe's ethnic, cultural and linguistic diversity. In democratic societies, the teaching of the mother tongue and the learning in the mother tongue are the fundamental rights of all people, including indigenous national minorities. This right must be granted by the State. All the more so that the mother tongue is the best tool for education, since students are best able to meet school requirements in their own language. Unfortunately, minority and regional languages have not received sufficient attention in the recent proposal on an approach to language teaching and language learning published by the European Commission. In line with the principle of subsidiarity, I call on the European Commission and the Council to come up with proposals for the mutual recognition of language examinations and diplomas, thereby supporting not only the spread of major European languages, but also languages spoken by smaller, regional or indigenous minorities in Europe.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In the context of the debate on improving language teaching and mutual recognition of language competences in the European Union, I stress the importance of language skills for increased mobility in the EU. In this respect, I ask the Commission, within the framework of the Erasmus programme, to allow all beneficiaries of the programmes access to language tests and courses. This could contribute both to increasing the mobility of scientific and administrative staff under this programme and to improving the language competences of all participants. Enabling everyone to learn languages under Erasmus would represent an important Union contribution to promoting multilingualism and language learning.  Furthermore, with regard to my report on the modernisation of education in the Union, I stress the need to include language learning more in vocational education and training programmes.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the closure of the EU ivory market to combat poaching (2018/2750(RSP)).

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for putting this important matter on the agenda. It is a very timely debate, given the developments in relevant international forums, in particular the CITES Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, and also in some of the EU Member States and, of course, at EU level. A number of measures have been taken since we learned about the latest increase in elephant poaching in several African countries. We have seen some encouraging signs since then, but many elephant populations are still at risk. The greatest danger certainly comes from the trafficking of ivory from source countries in Africa to consumer markets in East Asia. Some EU Member States are unfortunately used as transit hubs by the traffickers. Of all the ivory that is being seized by national customs authorities, by far the biggest share concerns such transit shipments from Africa to Asia. Under the EU Action Plan against Wildlife Trafficking, we have worked with Member States since 2016 towards the tightening of controls and increasing of relevant capacities. We are also working with third countries at both ends of the trade flow: to help them fight poaching on the ground in Africa and to reduce demand for ivory in Asia. In addition, we have increased the development cooperation budget to fight elephant poaching and with contributions to the African Elephant Fund. The current discussion about domestic ivory markets in the EU and elsewhere must be set against this broader global background. The Conference of the Parties to the CITES Convention adopted a resolution on this at its last meeting in 2016. The resolution calls on countries to close their domestic markets for commercial ivory trade if there is a legal market that is contributing to poaching or illegal trade. Already we have in place strict rules on ivory trade in the European Union: imports of ivory into the EU and exports from the EU have been banned since 1975 in respect of Asian elephants, and since 1990 in respect of African elephants. For ivory items that have been in Europe for a long time, domestic trade is strictly regulated with a system of certificates and demonstration of legal origin by traders. The rules were tightened further in May 2017 with the adoption of a specific Commission guidance document. Since then, the export of old raw ivory from the EU has no longer been possible. EU Member States have unanimously supported this additional tightening of the rules and are following the guidance very closely, thereby ensuring uniform application of the rules. With this measure, the risk that ivory exported from Europe could fuel the demand in destination markets, and indirectly also the poaching in Africa, has been significantly reduced. But we did not stop there. Towards the end of last year the Commission organised a public consultation to gather relevant data and to consult widely on possible additional measures regarding exports and sales of ‘Old World’ ivory items. The consultation attracted many responses and a clear majority of respondents called for far-reaching measures against domestic ivory trade. Those calls are often based on the precautionary principle, rather than on any specific evidence for systematic links between the legal ivory trade in the EU and elephant poaching in Africa. On the other hand, EU stakeholders, such as makers of musical instruments or antique dealers, used the consultation to highlight the impact of any additional restrictive measures on their sources of livelihood. The Commission is currently reflecting on the way forward and it will report to Parliament and the Council in the context of its progress report on the Wildlife Trafficking Action Plan.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Africa’s elephant population is drastically declining and, at the same time, globally the legal ivory trade is – and remains – at the same level that it was at six years ago, even though different kinds of attempts have been made globally. The record for seizures of illegal ivory was, actually, in 2016. We have fewer than 440 000 elephants today and poachers kill an estimated 55 elephants per day. So we need drastic and good actions. I would like to thank the EU Member States and the Commission for taking these steps forward, but this is not yet adequate. Illegal poaching and the illegal ivory trade will not stop as long as legal trade in any form is open. We need to close the domestic markets. The EU is still the largest domestic market for ivory in the world and, by the way, we are also a major transit point for illegal trading in wildlife goods.  China has banned the ivory trade domestically, the UK has one of the most stringent bans and the same goes for the USA and Hong Kong. What is actually needed now is for the EU to close its domestic markets totally. Exclusion through special permits would be allowed for some antique instruments or issues like that, but normal domestic trade should not continue anymore.

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I echo the remarks made by our former speaker, well done. In April 2015, I sponsored an exhibition in the Brussels Parliament for the Born Free Foundation. The actress Virginia McKenna spoke passionately for an end to wildlife trafficking and a ban on the ivory trade. Prince William’s speech in China endorsed our position, and last week in the British House of Commons, they voted for what will soon be one of the toughest bans on the trade of ivory in the world. This UK ban will be tougher than America’s and China’s, but nations acting alone cannot succeed in closing the market. Only global action can stamp out the trade in ivory and turn back the tide towards elephant extinction, and not forgetting the rhinoceros. We in the UK have consistently taken the lead; we were the first country to ban cosmetics testing on animals in 1998, but it took the European Union six years. With 20 000 animals slaughtered annually, waiting six years is not an option, Commissioner. As long as Europe has a large market for ivory, the poaching of elephants will continue. I want future generations to be able to enjoy our world’s diverse wildlife, not just read about it in history books. So if we act together now and close down this European ivory market, we can make a huge contribution towards saving these magnificent animals and stop the criminals who currently profit from the trade. I therefore implore you Commissioner, to do something and act now and follow Britain’s lead in abolishing this abhorrent practice.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the slaughter of elephants for their ivory continues, and it’s abhorrent. We all know that, the public knows it, and it has to stop. But the EU is sitting still while others are taking real action. China and Hong Kong have closed their ivory markets, and even the UK, as we have just heard, is now coming forward with a total ban on all ivory. Yet the EU is still the largest exporter of so-called ‘legal ivory’ in the world. That’s the problem. We all assume the ivory we are exporting is legal. We assume that if an ivory carving, a knife handle or a snooker ball has paperwork saying it is pre-1947, it is legal and can be sold as antique – but that’s not always the case. An Oxford University study to be released later this month shows that over two thirds of ivory sold legally on the EU market is in fact not pre-1947. It’s clear that illegally-poached ivory is getting into the legal markets, and it’s the marketplace that’s driving demand, and that is driving the killing. Criminal gangs control this profitable trade. They forge paperwork and they get their new or reworked ivory onto the market. The only place where ivory belongs or should have any value is on the front of a live elephant. So Commissioner, no half measures. All ivory trade is driving slaughter. Thousands of tonnes of ivory representing thousands of elephants – for what? Trinkets and criminality. We need a full and comprehensive EU-wide ban on ivory, with appropriate exemptions, now. I will not stand by while elephants die. The Members of this House support this position, as do the citizens of Europe. The Commission and its Member States must send this clear message to the rangers who protect and to the customers who buy: ivory has no monetary value any longer. Ivory in Europe is not for sale.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, elephants are under huge pressure, and poaching is the leading cause for that. While we are having this discussion here in the European Parliament, two elephants are being killed out there in Africa. They may be extinct within ten years in the wild.  Poaching is fuelled by the illegal ivory trade, which has increased dramatically recently, and the illegal trade in ivory is also closely connected to legal trade. Our current regulation is not sufficient and not effective. There are the problems of documentation, the green zone, on-line trade, and so on and so forth. As a sign, in 2016 two tonnes of illegal ivory was seized in the EU. Organised crime networks are closely related to wildlife crimes and the illegal trade in ivory.  Drastic steps are needed, and Parliament called on the Commission to make them. This is a popular cause; almost 70 % of European citizens support a complete ban on the ivory trade in the EU. We must listen to them; we must act.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Thank you, Mr President. Ivory poachers are violent criminals who have decimated elephant populations over the past century. The ivory trade has brought the elephants to the brink. It's almost unimaginable, but still 55 elephants are killed every day. Europe plays a dubious role in this. Trade in ivory has been banned for almost 30 years. Yet Brussels still allows exceptions for so-called old ivory. As a result, for example, jewellery, chess pieces and billiard balls can still be marketed here and the demand for ivory remains. Europe is a real linchpin in the illegal ivory trade. The poachers operate in an organised manner and do not shiede back to exterminate the elephants. Commissioner, be clear. Let there be no doubt and forbid all trade in ivory. If you don't, we can watch together as elephants are brutally massacred. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished. Thank you very much.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the number of elephants victims of poaching is abhorrent. It is estimated that around 30 000 African elephants are killed a year in order to meet the world's demand for ivory. This makes certain african territorial groups a real elephant cemetery.  Of course, poaching is not just about elephants, it is about a whole range of animals. In the face of such a disaster, we recognise the fact that the European Union's action plan against wildlife trafficking, which came into force last year, is a first step towards curbing the scourge of ivory trafficking. However, the more restrictive measures taken by the United States, China and Hong Kong are much more effective. The European Union should raise the level of watch by taking equally stringent measures. We must stop the cycle of death, which involves not only elephants but also foresters who dedicate their lives to their protection. From Africa and the citizens of Europe, we have come to an appeal to which we must respond. The fight to safeguard biodiversity and wildlife conservation also depends on firmness in combating the illegal ivory market.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – In 2016, as shadow rapporteur, I participated in the resolution on combating illegal wildlife trafficking. At the time, I was calling for a European ban on the ivory trade, without loopholes. Because illegal ivory always finds its way to the legal circuit. I repeat my plea today. Ivory trade is deadly to biodiversity and threatens to turn elephants and rhinos into 'living dinosaurs'. But the ivory trade has other disastrous and often deadly consequences. Every year, the trade puts billions of euros in the hands of criminals, militias and terrorist organisations, creating insecurity and instability. Moreover, the trade in ivory is increasing spectacularly and we as the European Union are involved as a market and a hub. A major fight against these criminal activities and the closure of our ivory market are needed to ensure the protection of the species and our security. The European Union can and must make a difference.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Every twenty minutes an elephant is murdered by poachers. The EU is the largest exporter of ivory products, although we all know that any trade will contribute massively to the cruel slaughter that continues. Only an UNcommitted EU ban on the trade of ivory could save elephants from extinction. No exceptions, I say! Or do you want to tell your children and grandchildren at some point that there are no more elephants because our decisions have not been consistent enough? Do you have the courage to tell your children and grandchildren the whole truth, namely that the political establishment has turned into accomplices of these heinous crimes for economic reasons? Elephants have lived on this planet for ten million years. We simply cannot allow this wonderful species to be eradicated for profit. It is high time to stop the planetary extermination campaign of our species. We have only one earth. Preserving them is our first duty not to serve the economy! Now the citizens expect a clear political response. There is nothing left, but there is nothing left to negotiate, because we are running out of time. Finally make nails with heads! Let me tell you: no exceptions!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the ivory market is a huge market. Millions are being played around this case. As mentioned, 55 elephants a day are killed, essentially murdered, in order to support the illegal ivory trade. This huge poaching has important consequences for the ecosystem, for development, and at the same time it does not lead to corruption and supports organised crime. And, while the United States, China, the United Kingdom have taken tough measures, here in Europe we let things run. First of all, very tough measures must be taken and the intra-UNION ivory trade must be stopped. Secondly, we need to check for the species that exist here in the European Union. So we need determination, we need measures that need to be taken here and now.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, despite the international ban on ivory exports in force, illegal elephant hunting and ivory trade have reached record levels. It is estimated that between 20,000 and 30,000 African elephants are killed each year by poachers.  One of the main causes of this rise in illicit trade is the growing demand for ivory products in Asia. However, we must also admit that the demand for ivory in the EU is also growing. During my work on the palm oil report, I was able to find out for myself how the EU all too often takes into account how we are involved in the destruction of nature and biodiversity. Here, however, it does not pay to look the other way when it can cause the extinction of species. The EU has its obligations and must respect them. There is no other way, if we value natural wealth, there is no other way if we want to value ourselves.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the illegal trade in ivory threatens the existence of elephants and wild rhinos and inevitably fuels the demand for ivory products obtained by illegal means that undermines any attempt to control and reduce trade.  We have already approached the Commission on this issue, most notably in a letter on 3 May, and we come back here to ask you – and I am doing so with my fellow Members too – how you are assessing this problem and this aspect in particular of the problem, that is to say legal trade and how much it has an impact on illegal trade. The scientific community is unanimous in recognising that the illegal culling of elephants at the hands of ivory-hunting poachers is the main cause of their decline and in Africa they are killed at an appalling rate of 30 000 specimens per year. Commissioner, the sad reality is that as long as there is an ivory market, there will also be poaching and illicit trafficking. For this reason, I agree with what my fellow Members have asked for: imports into the Eu ropean Union must be totally banned. There is no more time to waste, the time is ripe and we must act.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I did not expect Commissioner Navracsics to be present at this point. This is a different portfolio. I will therefore ask the Commissioner one problem, but so that there is no misunderstanding, I will start with the most important element for me. I cannot accept the current situation where the world is losing between EUR 8 billion and EUR 20 billion per year to trade in illegal animal elements. I cannot accept a situation where rhino hunting has increased by 7,000% and up to 30,000 elephants are killed every year in Africa – that's incredible. Here we are not effective. But I must say that we are effective elsewhere: in prosecuting or hindering artists from moving between continents, when they use historical instruments that are made of Brazilian rosewood, rosewood from Madagascar, or contain other elements of animal origin. I draw attention to this gap between the fight against pathology and the obstruction – in this case of artists – of movement between continents.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for those valuable contributions to the debate. We have taken good note of your views and Mr Zdrojewski’s remarks as well. We are very much aware that the EU is expected to continue playing a leading international role in the fight against ivory trafficking. We are, of course, also aware of the measures taken by the United States, China and by some of the EU Member States. We are looking closely at those measures in our reflection on the EU regime on the ivory trade.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. – I strongly support the foreclosing of the EU ivory market. The US, China, Hong Kong and the UK have already taken measures to close their domestic markets, which are much stricter than those currently in force in the EU. Both the African Elephant Loxodonta africana and the Indian elephant Elephas maximus are listed in the Annexes to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). Although international trade in ivory is prohibited under the current CITES regime, domestic trade in ivory is not regulated by CITES. That is why the European Parliament is once again calling for the EU's ivory market to be closed. It should be remembered that the illegal trade in ivory has more than doubled since 2007. Illegal hunting has reached a high level in recent years. Poachers are said to kill 55 elephants a day. Between 20,000 and 30,000 African elephants have been killed each year since 2011. Although trade in ivory in the EU is strictly regulated through the EU Regulation on trade in wild and wild species and the import and trade of ivory into and trade within the EU and its exports from the EU are generally not authorised for commercial purposes, the EU has a major role to play in the whole situation. If the EU ivory market is not closed, we cannot expect any improvement.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the report by Bogdan Zdrojewski, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on structural and financial barriers to access to culture (2017/2255(INI)) (A8-0169/2018).

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by For the first time in the European Parliament, there is a report covering the whole issue of participation in culture, precisely the barriers to access to it.  The title of the report itself may be somewhat confused, as research leading up to this document shows that the biggest barrier is not infrastructure shortages or the price of accessibility, but educational shortages. Of course, for the world of culture, the possibilities for creating new goods are the most important: talent, work, but also, of course, financial opportunities. Nevertheless, many educational neglects are a key barrier to cultural acceptance.  Of course, responsibility for the development of culture falls on state governments and local governments at all levels. It should include three elements at the same time: the training of artists, the education of the public and the construction of infrastructure for the first and second meetings. What is particularly worth highlighting in the report? Firstly, the catalogue of human rights to culture (we have 47 existing legal bases in this document), recognising culture as a key area of activity, recognising the importance of creative industries, also for Europe's economic prosperity, recognising the role of cultural dialogue, rejecting cultural exclusions, recognising the importance of cultural heritage, the need to protect and promote, and the need to take into account technological and civilisational changes for cultural participation. It is worth mentioning here Article 27 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights on the right of every person to participate freely in culture. What does culture give us? A chance to better understand the world. It helps build a knowledge-based society. It is the most important source of inclusive processes, a source of wealth, creates an area of special values, including positive emotions.  Which provisions of the report should be considered as key? There are 70 of them, not counting the preamble and the points of justification. Rather, I will cite those that are illustrative in order to show the scale of the references. Firstly, the need to build cultural strategies for children and young people. This is also a recommendation to the Member States. Recognising access to culture as one of the priorities of the European Union's political agenda. The need to simplify rules, rigours and tax systems that primarily include artists. Linking participation more closely to culture with accessibility – it is all about the richness of infrastructure. The need to provide financial guarantees, public funds for culture (here we have a call for financial protection even in times of crisis). To draw attention to the fact that financing cultural activities is not only an expense is also an investment. The quality of access to culture is a source of strengthening the creative economy. The need to reduce the tax burden across borders. Making tax policy more difficult in the Area of the European Union, especially with regard to VAT. In addition to exclusions due to age, health, lack of infrastructure, especially in the place of residence, there is a new exclusion – digital exclusion.  I would like to thank the data-acquisition staff (Eurostat and Eurobarometer) very warmly. These are the main key years 2011-2016. Let me remind you: the cultural sector is more than 8 million employees, that is, 3.7% of those working. As many as 36% of Europeans did not attend any cultural event in 2015, but as many as 83% of young people in turn took part in such an artistic event, which I would also like to draw attention to.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the Committee on Culture and Education (CULT) and in particular the rapporteur, Bogdan Zdrojewski, for his work on this report. It raises the crucial issue of structural and financial barriers preventing access to culture. Culture is not a side issue or an added extra. On the contrary, it is at the heart of the European project. This was confirmed by the Heads of State and Government in their conclusions last December. Culture is part of our identity. It gives meaning to historical events and feelings, and it helps us to communicate across languages and nationalities. Culture and creativity are also important engines for economic growth, yet figures show that more than one third of Europeans do not participate in cultural activities at all. I share your analysis regarding the obstacles preventing wider cultural participation, both on the demand and supply sides. More efforts are needed to promote interest in culture, starting with children at a young age. At the same time, we need to ensure a market for cultural and creative professionals that is less fragmented, and where they have sufficient access to finance and enjoy viable contractual conditions. Your valuable recommendations fed into the preparation of the proposal for a new European Agenda for Culture that the Commission presented in May. The new agenda intends to exploit synergies between culture and education, to strengthen links with other policy areas, and to help the cultural and creative sectors to grasp the opportunities of the digital shift. The Commission will play its part to help Member States achieve these goals. Let me give you a few concrete examples. First, under the Creative Europe programme, the Commission will launch a project on cultural and creative spaces and cities to promote cultural participation and social and urban regeneration. Second, we will support regions in focusing their smart specialisation and macro—regional strategies on culture. Here the Commission is already promoting sustainable cultural tourism through a dedicated European initiative as part of the European Year of Cultural Heritage. Third, we will organise regular dialogue with the cultural and creative sectors in the context of the renewed industrial policy strategy. This will identify policy needs and support a comprehensive policy framework at EU level. Finally, the Commission will propose a mobility scheme for professionals in the cultural and creative sectors under Creative Europe. We cannot have this discussion without mentioning the important role of the European Year of Cultural Heritage. One of the objectives of the year is to make cultural heritage accessible to all by removing social, cultural and physical barriers. I am grateful for the continued enthusiasm of the Parliament for the European Year, and I would like to use this opportunity to warmly thank President Antonio Tajani for organising a high-level event dedicated to the year in the European Parliament on 26 June. I hope that many of you will be able to take part. Let us keep up the momentum of the year and work together to ensure its legacy. Turning again to Mr Zdrojewski’s report: you stress the importance of proper financing and public support. This is indeed critical. The current Creative Europe programme already helps by promoting the circulation of cultural and creative works and of artists across borders – but we have to do more. This is why, in our proposal for the future Creative Europe programme published two weeks ago, we propose a funding increase of around 34%. This will enable us to reinforce support across the board, to add specific sectoral activities, to support the mobility of cultural and creative people and to encourage the activities of the European cultural and creative sectors on the world scene. I would ask you to support our proposal for the future Creative Europe in the tough negotiations ahead. We have a great opportunity to create an ambitious framework for culture: a framework that will enable more Europeans from all backgrounds to take part in cultural activities, and a framework that will boost the circulation of European artworks and help cultural professionals and artists perform or work in other countries. Let’s use this opportunity.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I, too, congratulate Colleague Zdrojewski on a very good report on the issue of access to culture. This is the underlying theme of cultural policy, considered from both a national and a Community perspective, but above all crucial from a citizens' perspective. I draw attention to the use of new technologies for cultural purposes, which is particularly important because it allows us to reach new, hard-to-reach or non-traditional audiences. We are talking about digital tools. Properly applied and implemented and supported by digital skills at an appropriate level, they can overcome barriers to access to culture conditioned by factors such as geographical disadvantage, disability, social origin, language, lack of time or financial resources. I believe that digital tools can be a means of overcoming social barriers and, in this context, digital education should be part of the learning process from an early age in order to develop the right competences and knowledge. Public support remains the main means of financing cultural activities. I, too, point out that fiscal policy can play an important role in financing the cultural and creative sectors by introducing reduced VAT rates. In this context, better coordination of national cultural and fiscal policies as a tool to stimulate cultural participation is important. Minister, congratulations once again.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group, Mr President, Commissioner, first of all thank the rapporteur for the constructive way we work and indeed we have reached good compromises. The first commitment, to ensure greater investment and differentiated cultural mobility for the outermost, mountainous and remote regions. We also ask for funding so that schools can visit cultural institutions, as well as we ask for internship scholarships in cultural institutions. In this report, we also advocate the generalisation of the European Student Card and free access to the cultural institutions of the European Union, precisely through that card. On the other hand, not least, in need, already said, of tax justice in the area of culture so that there is no double taxation and that there is a reduction in taxes particularly for the private part that finances the culture. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said artists and creators were the jewels of the crown. More recently, the President of this Parliament has said, and I quote, "that culture more than the economy unites us". Now, if culture has to be a gamble, then why do we have only 0.15% of the current European Union budget for the Creative Europe programme? Why don't we see a greater focus in funding for culture in the future, too?  I would like, Commissioner, to see this Union as concerned with the tenths of culture as it cares about the tenths of the banking and financial system. I would like to see what this other Europe would look like that would choose to invest more in culture. Investing in culture is investing in democracy, investing in human dignity and memory, our memory.  This implies, I insist, the political courage to geographically decentralise the investment made in culture and to invest in cultural mobility. The mobility of European and third-country artists is a way of promoting peace, sharing and divisions that involve the deconstruction, forgiveness, of stereotyped social and cultural representations. And those who do not invest in culture is because they do not know what this world is made of.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Indeed, I also congratulate my colleague, Mr Zdrojewski, who has produced a really good report, and I want to say that, although the statement that we live in a digital age where everything is available on the Internet has already become, life is more complex than one phrase. The availability of cultural heritage is an example of this. Often, cultural heritage is physically difficult to achieve, for example, when it is located in remote regions. Or when poor people are simply too busy with survival issues and have little interest in culture. Or when cultural heritage is created in rarely used languages. Even more often, cultural heritage remains unknown due to its poor advertising. It is therefore necessary to welcome the report by my colleague, Mr Zdrojewski, and it really well discusses the structural barriers to the accessibility of culture and seeks solutions for them.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has In cultural dialogue, we shape our values and our understanding of history, negotiate how we deal with global problems humanly – whether this happens in a film or in a comic book, literary or musical, it doesn't matter. Cultural dialogue is a food stuff. Access for all is crucial. More intercultural education inside and outside schools is crucial. A public cultural infrastructure with reliable support from European support policy for innovation and cultural heritage is also crucial. The rapporteur has done a good job and has complemented it in a cooperative manner. The report therefore clearly mentions the needs of the cultural and creative industries. This growing industry must not be a model for a world of work in which social security is unknown. In addition, artists who work across borders are charged multiple taxes. This must change as quickly as possible. What is not yet specifically stated in the report are more moderate copyright regulations and, therefore, extended exceptions for our cultural memory institutions such as museums, archives and libraries. I will continue to drill and conclude by saying that we should all heed one thing: culture costs everyone, but unculture costs us all more.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, let me start by thanking my colleague Zdrojewsky for this report. It is so great that it was very difficult to prepare an amendment to it.  Culture, these are monuments, that's theatre, it's film, but it's also how we treat each other, what environment we create around each other. Cultural policy is often underestimated, undervalued, even financially, while culture is Europe's greatest wealth compared to the world. Europe's creative industries, cultural heritage are the largest in the world and have huge economic potential, contributing to European belonging and unity in our diversity. At the same time, culture is undergoing digitalisation at this time. We are talking about copyright, and this is also about the availability of copyright works on the Internet. Not only about availability, but also about quality, and I would like to emphasise that.  My colleague Zdrojewski's report responds to digitalisation in great detail. It emphasises the need for accessibility for disadvantaged groups. Culture must not only be exclusive, so I also welcome the pilot project for 18-year-old Discover Europe, in which these young people are to discover European culture on a free ticket. In short, we must seek effective solutions, promote culture from public and private sources as an investment, and it starts with children in need of quality education and education for the future.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, access to culture and opportunities for creative expression are vital to enable democratic freedom and peaceful, equal societies. Member States must ensure that the socio-economic, personal or cultural background of citizens does not prevent them from participating in the cultural life of their local, national or international community. Cultural participation should be cross-cutting and be embedded within multiple policy areas if it is to truly have an impact.  Digital innovations have opened up new ways for people to access, produce and disseminate cultural content, but we need to do more to ensure that people have the digital skills and infrastructure in order to participate. Many rural areas, including those in my constituency in North West England, are still left behind without adequate broadband coverage. In the United Kingdom, the Conservative Party has chosen to place austerity at the centre of its ideologically-driven political agenda. Civic spaces such as libraries, museums, galleries and swimming pools have closed down at an alarming rate, preventing citizens from accessing information, activities and opportunities to develop skills. For minority groups and those with multiple barriers, the effects have been profound.  So as this report eloquently outlines, access to culture in school is vitally important to encourage lifelong cultural participation. But despite this, the UK Government has introduced policies which actively prevent large numbers of secondary school children from studying any creative and cultural subjects. But working together as a union of Member States, we can always better fight for progressive, inclusive societies where access to culture is seen as the right of the many, not just for the privileged few.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – I believe that there is no political force that does not believe that reaching out to culture and participating in cultural events is important for personal growth and enrichment. There's no question about that. The problem is that although there is ostensibly a political and societal consensus on the issue and everyone agrees on the importance of culture when designing the national and European budgets, it turns out that other areas are more priority.  Today, in the Plenary of the European Parliament, we will once again debate the importance of people having access to various cultural events. However, the next time we draw up the next multiannual financial framework, the European funds earmarked for culture will again be in all likelihood less than 0.5% of the total budget of the European Union.  As regards barriers to access to culture, two are clearly emerging. One is financial and the other is geographical. A lot of people don't attend cultural events just because they can't afford it financially. Those who live in smaller settlements have nowhere to go. I believe that a nation that does not care about the cultural development of its citizens is doomed to doom.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, literacy in culture and art is a literacy-like ability to understand society and change around us. In fact, the art of making and reading culture and art is a science-comparable ability to explain, understand and perceive new things around us. It is a key part of our civilisation and civilisation, with the difference that if early childhood lacks the conditions for understanding cultural and art expression, it will take much longer to learn at a later stage of life and will be more difficult. That is why our common task, both in the Member States and in the European Union, is to put pressure on and invest in the fact that we also receive the same funding for cultural education in schools as for science, technology, engineering and mathematics, and that cultural education should also be part of early childhood education and care already in kindergartens. In particular, this is necessary for children and young people whose home background does not provide the prerequisites or opportunities for access to a broad culture and art.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, cultural diversity is protected by the treaties of the European Union, while the right to cultural heritage is laid down in the Faro Convention. And cultural heritage also means the protection of cultural goods. And here we come to the subject of cloughed archaeological treasures. A serious issue which is not raised in the report. And I am referring specifically to the pruning archaeological treasures from the Nazi occupation troops in Greece in the period 1941-1944. We're still waiting for these archaeological treasures to be returned! Moreover, it is obvious that there should be accessibility to culture. No one disputes that funds should be invested. No one disputes that digitisation should be exploited and that remote areas, islands, where access to culture and cultural goods is difficult should be supported. But I come back to the question of the return of pruning archaeological treasures from Nazi occupation troops to Greece. Something needs to be done about this, Mr Navracsics. I have raised this issue with you on several occasions, and I even raised it with you on the day you came to the European Parliament to be adopted as Commissioner. We must not be deaf to this issue.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, I believe that structural and financial barriers to access to culture are a major problem. Yes, probably not the biggest, but still definitely significant. Access to culture is one of the fundamental rights of all citizens and deserves our attention.  The famous Czech actor Jan Werich once said, "I don't think civilization is good when it's cultureless. One needs not only physical comfort but also mental comfort for happiness and satisfaction. Culture and civilization must go hand in hand." I fully agree with this quote.  In the post-economic crisis, we should make sure that culture is accessible to all and not just the chosen. Culture is not a matter for the elites, but for all of them in no way. Culture is a matter so human that if we don't take care of it, we're risking a lot more than we think.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me once more thank Mr Zdrojewski for this report, which very eloquently identifies all the barriers – structural and financial barriers – to access to culture. This is very important for us because, if we think of culture not only as a leisure-time activity or as a hobby, we have to acknowledge that culture plays a very important role in establishing and creating communities and also in keeping those communities alive, not only in urban areas but also in rural and remote areas. In some areas, culture is the only link of belonging, of community, which can keep the people there and keep people interested in living there. That is why access to culture is a very important aspect of developing cultural policy at European level for the future. The report is a significant contribution in mapping out all these problems and we can design our road map for the future on the basis of your comments and contributions. I would like to thank Parliament for this fruitful debate and for the report. We will work on overcoming all the barriers and difficulties in culture.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Thank you very much for your compliments, including compliments from the Commissioner. I also accept it as a thank you to the work of all those who prepared the data for this report, because it lasted the longest. On the other hand, as regards the conclusions, I would like to remind you that it is education that can today be regarded as the most important element in determining the quality of participation in culture. Yes, the size of this participation is also determined by other elements, including material, infrastructure, etc., while education, shortcomings, shortcomings, errors in educational processes are absolutely crucial and decisive for the quality of life and participation in culture. The second conclusion, which is very important, is a little surprising: today demand is more important than supply in the cultural area. It has happened that, as a result of the various barriers that I am talking about in this report, supply is very, very attractive and, it can be said, interesting also from the point of view of diversity, quantity and size, etc., etc., but we have problems with demand. As many as 40% of Europeans do not consider participation in culture to be important, crucial, in some cases even necessary. The third element: the rudimentary role in adopting participation in culture belongs to the family and the school. These two elements, these two addresses are especially important. I draw attention to this in my report. Another thing: the need to remove fiscal obstacles to the mobility of artists and cultural professionals. Lastly, a necessary new coherent digital strategy focused on cultural activities. What do I want to wish us all? In order for us to talk about such important issues in the next parliamentary term, to talk at a better time, in prime time, maybe not at night. I wish this to the Commissioner and to all of us. Then we will feel that culture is indeed even more important.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 14 June 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. In the village square, the last café closed a few months ago, the buralist, scalded by the rise of tobacco and delinquency, is about to pack up. As for the cinema, suspended from the municipal subsidies that will soon dry up, it is little to say that his films screened with a delay of several weeks are struggling to draw the crowds.  This is, brushed with a touch of lyricism, the fate of so many rural French municipalities, where the destitution of the cultural offer is a reflection of a dramatic desertification, which sees the key under the door 7,000 cafes per year and the commercial vacancy rate peak at 10%.  Far from being incidental, access to culture conditions the prospects of these cities, because why would a company invest in it tomorrow if it cannot offer its employees the living environment they take? Given the persistence of 'white zones', digitization alone will not suffice. But the great tradition of a truly popular and itinerant theatre reminds us that these territories are not doomed to oblivion and that, in the face of their agony, resolute national action is urgent and necessary.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Written. Mr President, access to culture is not self-evident. Neither is participating in culture. In the Netherlands, a year of cuts in the cultural sector was implemented in 2011. Eur 200 million was cut in the cultural sector. Subsidies were cancelled, because Secretary of State Halbe Zijlstra felt that individuals could also pay for art and culture themselves. Art and Culture thus became a matter for the elite. In fact, tax regulations in the Netherlands make it possible for the elite to invest in art and culture. This is despite the fact that both are enriching society as a whole.  These cuts have still not been completely reversed. As far as I am concerned, this must be changed: access to culture from schools, community centres and libraries must be restored. That is why I am calling for a European approach to making culture accessible to all. The structural and financial barriers to culture must be removed.  Europe calls on the Member States not to go bald in times of tightness. Public access to art and culture increases people's involvement in (European) society. Equal opportunities for all, that is what my Europe stands for.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The problem of barriers to access to culture concerns cultural institutions, Member States and regional authorities. Free participation in culture should be one of the fundamental issues of national but also Community policy, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. An active and accessible cultural sector is important for strengthening civic activity and knowledge while promoting cultural heritage and developing cultural diversity. It is necessary to facilitate investment and diversify the funding of the cultural and creative sectors in order to unlock the potential of these sectors to generate growth and jobs. They have an impact on artistic activities, skills development, digitalisation, innovation and the formulation of new business models, as well as strengthening the competitiveness of the European cultural and creative sectors. The report cites useful solutions, calling for the inclusion of access to culture and participation in culture in other policy areas. The report highlights the cross-cutting of cultural issues and their impact on other areas of social life, including the importance for economic growth, recognising the need for Member States to ensure that artists and audiences are adequately educated, as well as the state of artistic infrastructure and material cultural heritage.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – One of the objectives of the EU and its Member States should be to reduce social and economic inequalities. Participation in cultural activities is one of the ways in which a sense of belonging to society is created. As we discuss the accessibility of culture, let us remember that cultural activities can help to strengthen self-confidence and improve quality of life, especially for those who suffer from some marginalisation as a result of unemployment, illness or other causes. Taking this opportunity, it is worth considering the rapporteur's proposal for supporting the inclusive cultural sector, in which everyone can have equal opportunities to participate and develop their creative skills, regardless of their socio-economic, cultural or religious context or disability. As far as culture is concerned, we must take into account the fact that Europe's cultural heritage is unique in the world with its diversity and the richness of Christian culture. It is worth using the opportunity to expand cultural and religious tourism, which can be one of the key factors determining economic development, as well as to promote social cohesion and inclusion. Unfortunately, financial aspects are always one of the main obstacles to cultural accessibility and the participation of cultural activities. There is therefore a need for constant support for the cultural sector. The promotion of cultural interest and its understanding through the education system are important.
